messages.content: What should you do if a piece of tooth has broken off? A) Put it in milk or saliva B) Throw it away C) Put it in water D) Put it in alcohol E) Put it in juice
A
Who should you see for a chipped, broken, or cracked tooth? A) A dentist B) A GP C) A pharmacist D) A nurse E) A chiropractor
A
What should you do if your dentist is closed? A) Call the dentist's answerphone B) Go to the emergency room C) Call a friend D) Wait until the next day E) Call a chiropractor
A
What should you do if you don't have a dentist? A) Call 111 B) Go to the pharmacy C) Call a friend D) Wait until the next day E) Call a chiropractor
A
What is one possible treatment for a chipped tooth? A) Gluing the fragment back on B) Removing the tooth C) Putting a brace on D) Applying a bandage E) Using a cream
A
What should you do if you cannot get an emergency dental appointment? A) Call 111 B) Go to the pharmacy C) Call a friend D) Wait until the next day E) Call a chiropractor
A
What is a treatment option for a badly broken tooth where the nerves are exposed? A) Root canal treatment B) Applying a bandage C) Putting a brace on D) Using a cream E) Removing the tooth
A
What should you do if you or your child has chipped, cracked, or broken a tooth? A) See a dentist B) Call a friend C) Go to the pharmacy D) Wait until the next day E) Call a chiropractor
A
What is a possible treatment for a broken tooth? A) A filling or a crown B) Applying a bandage C) Putting a brace on D) Using a cream E) Removing the tooth
A
What should you do if you need to see a dentist in an emergency or out of hours? A) Call a dentist B) Go to the pharmacy C) Call a friend D) Wait until the next day E) Call a chiropractor
A
What is hepatitis C? A) A bacterial infection of the lungs B) A virus that can infect the liver C) A fungal infection of the skin D) A parasitic infection of the intestines E) A genetic disorder
B
How is hepatitis C usually spread? A) Through airborne particles B) Through contaminated food C) Through blood-to-blood contact D) Through mosquito bites E) Through sneezing
C
What are some symptoms of hepatitis C? A) Rash and itching B) Muscle aches and fever C) Difficulty breathing D) Blurred vision E) Loss of appetite
B,E
What is the estimated number of people with chronic hepatitis C in the UK in 2019? A) 50,000 B) 118,000 C) 200,000 D) 300,000 E) 500,000
B
What are some ways to get tested for hepatitis C? A) Urine test B) Blood test C) Finger-prick test at home D) X-ray E) MRI scan
B,C
What are some treatments for hepatitis C? A) Antibiotics B) Pegylated interferon and ribavirin C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Sofosbuvir and daclatasvir
B,E
What are some complications of untreated hepatitis C? A) Kidney failure B) Cirrhosis C) Lung cancer D) Skin cancer E) Liver failure
B,E
What is the main way to prevent hepatitis C infection? A) Vaccination B) Not sharing drug-injecting equipment C) Wearing a mask D) Avoiding crowded places E) Drinking plenty of water
B
What is the percentage of people with hepatitis C who may be cured using the latest medications? A) 50% B) 70% C) 90% D) 95% E) 100%
C

What are some ways hepatitis C can be spread through unprotected sex? A) Through saliva B) Through vaginal secretions C) Through menstrual blood D) Through minor bleeding during anal sex E) Through sweat
C,D

What is the main symptom of prosopagnosia? A) Difficulty recognising faces B) Difficulty recognising numbers C) Difficulty recognising voices D) Difficulty recognising smells E) Difficulty recognising colors
A,B,C
Which of the following can cause prosopagnosia? A) Stroke B) Head injury C) Inflammation of the brain D) Being autistic E) Eating disorders
A,B,C
What are some strategies to help with prosopagnosia? A) Use people's voices B) Ask people to introduce themselves C) Make a note of distinctive features D) Use name tags E) Avoid social interactions
A,B,C

What other symptoms can occur with prosopagnosia? A) Difficulty recognising emotions on people's faces B) Difficulty recognising people's age and gender C) Difficulty recognising characters in TV programmes D) Difficulty recognising other things, such as cars E) Difficulty recognising shapes
A,B,C
What mental health issues can prosopagnosia lead to? A) Social anxiety B) Depression C) Schizophrenia D) Bipolar disorder E) OCD
A,B,C
Who should you see if you're struggling to recognise people's faces? A) GP B) Dentist C) Optician D) Psychiatrist E) Physiotherapist
A,B,C
What can prosopagnosia affect in daily life? A) Forming relationships B) Problems at work or school C) Finding your way around D) Ability to drive E) Ability to read
A,B,C
What are some causes of prosopagnosia? A) Not developing the ability to recognise faces B) Brain damage C) Alzheimer's disease D) Being autistic E) Diabetes
A,B,C

What are some things you can do to help with prosopagnosia? A) Tell people about the condition B) Ask people you're close to for help C) Use people's voices or body language D) Avoid crowded places E) Wear sunglasses
A,B,C
What are some conditions that can cause brain damage leading to prosopagnosia? A) Stroke B) Head injury C) Encephalitis D) Alzheimer's disease E) Flu
A,B,C

Which symptoms indicate you should see a GP for a skin abscess? A) A lump that is getting bigger B) A lump anywhere on your body that lasts more than 2 weeks C) A lump that is soft and moves D) A lump that is blue E) A lump that is itchy
A,B

What should you do if you have a lump that is painful, red or hot, or you feel hot and shivery? A) Ignore it and wait for it to go away B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Apply ice to the lump D) Take a hot shower E) Call 911
B,C
What are the common treatments for a skin abscess? A) Draining the pus B) Giving antibiotics C) Applying a cream D) Taking painkillers E) Surgery to remove the lump
A,B
What are the usual causes of skin abscesses? A) Bacteria getting into the skin B) Viral infection C) Fungal infection D) Allergic reaction E) Heat exposure
A,D
Which factors increase the likelihood of getting skin abscesses? A) Smoking B) Eating junk food C) Drinking alcohol D) Having diabetes E) Being between 15 and 40 years old
A,E
What are the characteristics of a skin abscess? A) A painful lump B) A lump that feels warm C) A lump with soft middle D) A lump that is blue E) A lump that is cold
A,C

What should you do if you have swelling or redness spreading away from the lump? A) Apply a warm compress B) Ignore it and wait for it to go away C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Take a cold shower E) Drink plenty of water
A,C
What actions can be taken if the abscess is infected? A) Draining the pus B) Giving antibiotics C) Applying ice D) Taking aspirin E) Applying a bandage
A,B
Which of the following is NOT a symptom of a skin abscess? A) A lump that is painful B) A lump that feels warm C) A lump with soft middle D) A lump that is itchy E) Pus leaking from the lump
C,D

What should you do if you have a lump and a weakened immune system or a long-term condition such as diabetes? A) Ignore it and wait for it to go away B) See a GP C) Apply a cream D) Take a hot shower E) Drink plenty of water
B,E
What are the tiny filters inside your kidneys called? A) Glomeruli B) Nephrons C) Renal arteries D) Ureters E) Bladder
A
What is a common symptom of severe glomerulonephritis? A) Green urine B) Dark urine C) Clear urine D) No urine E) Pink urine
B
What condition can develop if a lot of protein leaks into your urine? A) Nephrotic syndrome B) Renal failure C) Polycystic kidney disease D) Kidney stones E) Urinary tract infection
A
Which of the following is a symptom of glomerulonephritis? A) Swelling of the legs B) Hair loss C) Dry mouth D) Sweating E) Nausea
A
What is creatinine? A) A waste product produced by your muscles B) A type of protein C) A vitamin D) A hormone E) A mineral
A
What type of scan is used to check the size of your kidneys? A) Ultrasound scan B) MRI scan C) CT scan D) X-ray E) PET scan
A
What is a common cause of glomerulonephritis? A) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) B) Diabetes C) Hypertension D) Alzheimer's disease E) Asthma
A

What type of medicine is commonly prescribed to protect the kidneys in glomerulonephritis? A) Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors B) Antibiotics C) Antihistamines D) Antacids E) Antidepressants
A
What is a possible complication of glomerulonephritis? A) High blood pressure B) Low blood pressure C) High blood sugar D) Low blood sugar E) High cholesterol
A,E
What is a possible test to diagnose glomerulonephritis? A) Blood tests B) Urine test C) Biopsy D) Ultrasound scan E) All of the above
E

What is endocarditis? A) A common infection of the outer heart B) A rare and potentially fatal infection of the inner lining of the heart C) A chronic condition of the lungs D) An infection of the digestive system E) A type of skin disease
B
What is the most common cause of endocarditis? A) Virus entering the blood B) Fungi entering the blood C) Bacteria entering the blood D) Parasites entering the blood E) Allergens entering the blood
C
What condition makes it easier for bacteria to bypass the immune system to the heart? A) High blood pressure B) Artificial heart valve C) Asthma D) Diabetes E) Obesity
B
What is valve replacement surgery used for? A) To treat asthma B) For narrowing of one of their heart valves C) To treat kidney failure D) To treat liver disease E) To treat cancer
B
What is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? A) A condition where the heart muscle cells have enlarged B) A type of cancer C) A lung disease D) A skin condition E) A digestive disorder
A
Who is more likely to develop endocarditis? A) People who drink alcohol B) People who inject drugs C) People who smoke D) People who exercise regularly E) People who eat a lot of junk food
B
What are the initial symptoms of endocarditis? A) Sneezing and coughing B) High temperature, chills, headache, joint and muscle pain C) Blurred vision D) Diarrhea E) Fatigue
B
What is a potential complication of endocarditis? A) Kidney failure B) Heart failure C) Liver failure D) Diabetes E) Asthma
B
How is endocarditis treated? A) With painkillers B) With antibiotics given via a drip C) With surgery alone D) With dietary changes E) With physical therapy
B
In which age group is endocarditis more common? A) Infants B) Teenagers C) Older people D) Young adults E) Children
C
What is rickets? A) A condition that affects bone development in children. B) A type of skin infection. C) A mental health disorder. D) A respiratory disease. E) A form of arthritis.
A)
What is the most common cause of rickets? A) Lack of vitamin D or calcium. B) Exposure to radiation. C) Genetic mutations. D) Viral infection. E) High sugar intake.
A)
Which nutrient is essential for the formation of strong and healthy bones in children? A) Vitamin D. B) Iron. C) Zinc. D) Vitamin C. E) Omega-3 fatty acids.
A)
What is the condition known as osteomalacia? A) Soft bones in adults. B) Brittle bones in teens. C) Bone cancer. D) Muscle wasting. E) Iron deficiency.
A)

How can rickets be prevented? A) By eating a diet that includes vitamin D and calcium, spending some time in sunlight, and taking vitamin D supplements if necessary. B) By avoiding dairy products. C) By staying indoors. D) By consuming high amounts of sugar. E) By eating a high-fat diet.
A)

Which children are more at risk of developing rickets? A) Children with dark skin, children born prematurely, or children taking medication that interferes with vitamin D. B) Children with light skin. C) Children who consume a lot of meat. D) Children who exercise regularly. E) Children who eat a lot of fruits.
A)

What should you do if your child shows signs and symptoms of rickets? A) Take your child to see your GP. B) Give them more sugar. C) Keep them indoors. D) Increase their protein intake. E) Avoid dairy products.
A)
What is the primary test to confirm a diagnosis of rickets? A) Blood test. B) Urine test. C) Saliva test. D) Hair analysis. E) Skin biopsy.
A)

What is the Healthy Start scheme? A) A government scheme that provides free vitamin supplements. B) A fitness program for children. C) A diet plan. D) A mental health support group. E) A community service.
A)
What is a bone density scan also known as? A) DEXA scan. B) MRI. C) CT scan. D) Ultrasound. E) EKG.
A)
What is the first step if you experience postmenopausal bleeding? A) Go to the emergency room B) See a GP C) Wait for a week D) Take painkillers E) Ignore it
B)
How long should you wait to see a specialist after being referred for postmenopausal bleeding? A) 1 month B) 2 weeks C) 3 months D) 6 months E) 1 year
B)
What is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding? A) Ovarian cancer B) Womb cancer C) Inflammation and thinning of the vaginal lining D) Uterine fibroids E) Hormonal imbalance
C)
Which test might involve inserting a speculum into the vagina? A) Vaginal ultrasound scan B) Examination of the pelvis and vagina C) Hysteroscopy D) CT scan E) MRI scan
B)
What is endometrial hyperplasia? A) A type of skin condition B) A thickened womb lining C) A bacterial infection D) A side effect of antibiotics E) A form of arthritis
B)
What is the recommended treatment for cervical polyps causing postmenopausal bleeding? A) Antibiotics B) Removal by a specialist C) Hormone replacement therapy D) Physical therapy E) Dietary changes
B)
What is the treatment for vaginal or endometrial atrophy? A) Surgery B) Oestrogen cream or pessaries C) Radiotherapy D) Chemotherapy E) Physical therapy
B)
What is the typical treatment for womb cancer? A) Dietary changes B) Total hysterectomy C) Antibiotics D) Physical therapy E) Painkillers
B)
What is often recommended after a total hysterectomy for womb cancer? A) Antibiotics B) Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy C) Dietary changes D) Physical therapy E) Painkillers
B)
What is the typical treatment for ovarian cancer? A) Painkillers B) Surgery to remove ovaries, and sometimes womb C) Physical therapy D) Dietary changes E) Antibiotics
B)

What should you do if you fall and are not hurt but feel strong enough to get up? A) Get up quickly B) Roll onto your hands and knees C) Stay lying down D) Call 999 immediately E) Ignore the fall and continue your activities
B,D,
What are some common causes of falls in older people? A) Dim lighting B) Reaching for storage areas C) Recently polished floors D) High blood pressure E) Good eyesight
A,B,C,

What should you do if you are hurt or unable to get up after a fall? A) Crawl to a telephone and dial 999 B) Try to get someone's attention by calling out for help C) Stay as comfortable as possible and try to change your position every half an hour D) Eat something E) Call a friend
A,B,C,

What are some measures to prevent falls in the home? A) Using non-slip mats in the bathroom B) Ensuring all rooms, passages, and staircases are well lit C) Mopping up spills to prevent wet, slippery floors D) Leaving clutter around E) Keeping the house dark
A,B,C,

What can a GP do to help prevent falls in older people? A) Carry out simple tests to check your balance B) Review any medicines you're taking for side effects C) Recommend exercises to improve your strength and balance D) Prescribe sedatives E) Suggest drinking more coffee
A,B,C,
What are some common health conditions that can lead to falls in older people? A) Heart disease B) Dementia C) Low blood pressure (hypotension) D) High blood pressure E) Diabetes
A,B,C,

What should you do if you are living with or caring for an elderly person who has had a fall? A) Read what to do after an incident B) Ignore the incident C) Call the police D) Take them to the park E) Give them a sedative
A,

What are some physical activities recommended to prevent falls? A) Physical activity guidelines for older adults B) Heavy weightlifting C) Running marathons D) Doing exercises to improve your strength and balance E) Playing video games
A,D,

What are some common reasons for falls in older men? A) Falling from a ladder while carrying out home maintenance work B) Drinking excessive amounts of alcohol C) Taking steroid medicine D) Playing sports E) Watching TV
A,B,C,

What are some measures to stay safe after a fall? A) Get a personal alarm system B) Always keep a mobile phone in your pocket C) Call for help using your personal alarm or security system D) Stay in bed for a week E) Ignore the fall and continue your activities
A,B,C,

What is lymphoedema? A) A short-term condition that causes swelling in the body's tissues. B) A long-term (chronic) condition that causes swelling in the body's tissues. C) A condition that only affects the lungs. D) A condition that causes pain in the joints. E) A condition that affects the digestive system.
B)
Which part of the body does lymphoedema usually develop? A) Stomach B) Arms or legs C) Eyes D) Ears E) Heart
B)
What is the main symptom of lymphoedema? A) Fever B) Swelling in all or part of a limb or another part of the body C) Nausea D) Headache E) Sneezing
B)
What are the main types of lymphoedema? A) Primary and secondary B) Acute and chronic C) Internal and external D) Mild and severe E) Infectious and non-infectious
A)
Which type of lymphoedema is caused by damage to the lymphatic system? A) Primary B) Secondary C) Tertiary D) Quaternary E) None of the above
B)
What is the most common complication of lymphoedema? A) Flu B) Cellulitis C) Diabetes D) Hypertension E) Asthma
B)

How is lymphoedema usually diagnosed? A) Through blood tests B) Through symptoms, medical history, and examination of the affected body part C) Through X-rays D) Through DNA testing E) Through urine tests
B)

What is the main function of the lymphatic system? A) Helping fight infection and draining excess fluid from tissues B) Regulating blood pressure C) Producing hormones D) Aiding in digestion E) Filtering air in the lungs
A)
Which cancers often lead to secondary lymphoedema? A) Lung cancer B) Breast cancer, vulval cancer, penile cancer, and head and neck cancer C) Brain cancer D) Stomach cancer E) Liver cancer
B)

How can lymphoedema be treated? A) Through surgery B) Through techniques to minimize fluid build-up and stimulate the flow of fluid through the lymphatic system C) Through chemotherapy D) Through dialysis E) Through radiation therapy
B)

What is diabetes? A) A condition causing blood sugar levels to drop too low B) A condition causing blood sugar levels to become too high C) A condition causing blood sugar levels to fluctuate randomly D) A condition causing blood sugar levels to remain constantly low E) A condition causing blood sugar levels to increase only during exercise
B)

Which type of diabetes is caused by the body's immune system attacking insulin-producing cells? A) Type 2 diabetes B) Type 1 diabetes C) Non-diabetic hyperglycaemia D) Gestational diabetes E) Type 3 diabetes
B)

What is gestational diabetes? A) A type of diabetes that occurs only in men B) A type of diabetes that occurs only in children C) A type of diabetes that occurs during pregnancy D) A type of diabetes that occurs only in the elderly E) A type of diabetes that occurs only in athletes
C)

What is non-diabetic hyperglycaemia? A) A condition where blood sugar levels are below the normal range B) A condition where blood sugar levels are above the normal range but not high enough for a diabetes diagnosis C) A condition where blood sugar levels are constantly low D) A condition where blood sugar levels are constantly high E) A condition where blood sugar levels are unaffected by diet
B)

What is the NHS Diabetes Prevention Programme designed to help with? A) Preventing type 1 diabetes B) Preventing type 2 diabetes C) Preventing gestational diabetes D) Preventing non-diabetic hyperglycaemia E) Preventing all types of diabetes
B)
Which of the following is a main symptom of diabetes? A) Excessive sweating B) Feeling very thirsty C) Constant headaches D) Increased appetite E) Feeling very cold
B)
Which type of diabetes can develop quickly over weeks or even days? A) Type 2 diabetes B) Type 1 diabetes C) Gestational diabetes D) Non-diabetic hyperglycaemia E) Type 3 diabetes
B)

What can you do to reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes? A) Increase sugar intake B) Reduce physical activity C) Maintain a healthy diet and regular exercise D) Increase alcohol consumption E) Increase smoking
C)

What is diabetic retinopathy? A) A condition that affects the kidneys B) A condition that affects the heart C) A condition that affects the eyes D) A condition that affects the liver E) A condition that affects the lungs
C)
How often should adults with diabetes have their feet checked by a healthcare professional? A) Every month B) Every year C) Every 5 years D) Every 10 years E) Every day
B)

What is herpetic whitlow? A) A bacterial infection of the finger B) A fungal infection of the toe C) A painful infection of the finger caused by the herpes virus D) A skin condition caused by allergies E) A viral infection of the ear
C
Which part of the finger is usually affected by herpetic whitlow? A) The base of the finger B) The middle of the finger C) The top of the finger (fingertip) D) The side of the finger E) The nail bed
C
What are the symptoms of herpetic whitlow? A) Itchiness and rash B) Swelling and pain in your finger C) Nausea and vomiting D) Loss of appetite E) Difficulty breathing
B

What should you do if you have herpetic whitlow? A) Ignore it and let it heal on its own B) See a GP within 48 hours of symptoms C) Apply ice to the affected area D) Take antibiotics E) Drink plenty of fluids
B
What medication may be prescribed for herpetic whitlow? A) Antibiotics B) Antiviral tablets C) Steroids D) Antihistamines E) Painkillers
B
How long does herpetic whitlow usually last without treatment? A) 1 week B) 2 to 3 weeks C) 1 month D) 2 months E) 6 months
B

What should you do to ease the symptoms of herpetic whitlow? A) Apply heat to the affected area B) Keep the affected finger clean and covered with a dressing C) Use a cream D) Take a hot bath E) Massage the infected finger
B
What causes herpetic whitlow? A) A virus called herpes simplex B) Bacteria C) Fungus D) Allergies E) Insect bites
A

How can herpetic whitlow be transmitted? A) By touching a cold sore or blister of another infected person B) Through the air C) By drinking contaminated water D) By eating contaminated food E) By contact with animals
A

Who is more likely to get herpetic whitlow? A) People who have had cold sores or genital herpes B) People who have never had any infections C) People who have a strong immune system D) People who are very healthy E) People who are very young
A
What is toxocariasis caused by? A) Small worms in dog poo B) Small worms in cat poo C) Small worms in fox poo D) Small worms in human poo E) Small worms in bird poo
A,B,C

How is toxocariasis transmitted? A) Through fresh poo B) Through soil or sand containing worm eggs C) By eating meat from infected animals D) By drinking contaminated water E) By direct contact between people
B
What are the symptoms of toxocariasis? A) High temperature B) Coughing or wheezing C) Stomach ache D) Itchy rash E) Loss of vision
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you think you've swallowed soil, sand, or animal poo and have symptoms? A) Go to the emergency room B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Ignore the symptoms D) Take over-the-counter medication E) Call NHS 111
B,E
What is the main treatment for toxocariasis? A) Surgery B) Medicine to kill the worms C) Antibiotics D) Steroid medicine E) Herbal remedies
B,D

What should you do to reduce the risk of toxocariasis? A) Wash your hands regularly B) Wear gloves when gardening C) Teach young children not to eat soil or sand D) Wash vegetables before eating them E) Let animals poo in sandboxes
A,B,C,D
What happens if the worms spread to your eye? A) No treatment is needed B) Surgery may be required C) Steroid medicine may be used D) The worms will die naturally E) Eye drops are sufficient
B,C

How does toxocariasis spread in the body? A) Through the bloodstream B) Through the lymphatic system C) To parts of the body like the liver, lungs, or eyes D) Through the skin E) Through the respiratory system
C
What should you do if you find small, white worms in your poo? A) Assume it's toxocariasis B) Assume it's threadworms C) Ignore it D) Consult a GP E) Take medication immediately
B,D

What measures should be taken for pet dogs and cats to prevent toxocariasis? A) Feed them special diets B) De-worm them regularly C) Keep them indoors D) Bathe them daily E) Vaccinate them against toxocariasis
B

What is Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) A rare autoimmune condition affecting the nerves in your eyes and spinal cord B) A common genetic disorder C) A bacterial infection affecting the brain D) A type of cancer affecting the nervous system E) A viral infection causing vision loss
A

What are the symptoms of Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Eye pain and problems with eyesight or colour vision B) Sharp, burning or shooting pain in your back, neck, arms or legs C) Weakness, numbness or paralysis in your arms or legs D) Muscle spasms E) Problems with your bladder and bowels
A,B,C,D,E
Which diagnostic tests are used for Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Blood tests B) MRI scan C) Lumbar puncture D) Eye examinations E) X-ray
A,B,C,D
What treatments are used for relapses in Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) High dose steroid injections B) Plasma exchange C) Antibiotics D) Radiation therapy E) Chemotherapy
A,B
Which medicines are used to treat symptoms of Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Painkillers B) Amitriptyline or gabapentin C) Baclofen or carbamazepine D) Oxybutynin E) Laxatives
A,B,C,D,E
What therapies can help with muscle weakness and mobility problems in Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Physiotherapy B) Occupational therapy C) Acupuncture D) Massage therapy E) Chiropractic care
A,B

What medicines are used to prevent relapses in Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine B) Steroid tablets such as prednisolone C) Biological medicines such as rituximab D) Antihistamines E) Antidepressants
A,B,C
What causes Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Autoimmune condition B) Genetic mutation C) Bacterial infection D) Virus or infection E) Environmental factors
A,D

Which groups are more likely to be affected by Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) Women B) People of Asian or Black African origin C) People with close relatives who have autoimmune conditions D) People over 65 years old E) Children under 10 years old
A,B,C

What organizations provide support for people with Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO)? A) The Brain Charity B) The Brain & Spine Foundation C) The Transverse Myelitis Society D) The Heart Foundation E) The Cancer Society
A,B,C
Which of the following are common medically unexplained symptoms? A: Pains in the muscles or joints B: Back pain C: Allergic reactions D: Tooth decay E: Heart palpitations
A,B,E
What are some possible causes of medically unexplained symptoms? A: Depression B: Fungal infection C: Anxiety D: Broken bones E: Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS)
A,C,E
Which of the following might a GP consider when treating medically unexplained symptoms? A: Blood tests B: Changes in diet C: Associated psychological problems D: Allergies E: Physical examination
A,C,E

Which of the following might be recommended to help manage medically unexplained symptoms? A: Regular physical activity B: Chemotherapy C: Better rest D: Surgery E: Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
A,C,E
What are some less common medically unexplained symptoms? A: Fits (seizures) B: Breathlessness C: Weakness and paralysis D: Acne E: Numbness and tingling
A,B,C

Which of the following syndromes might be associated with medically unexplained symptoms? A: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) B: Flu C: Fibromyalgia D: Common cold E: Functional neurological disorders (FNDs)
A,C,E

What might a GP investigate when dealing with medically unexplained symptoms? A: Whether medicine might be causing symptoms B: Whether you have an associated problem like depression or anxiety C: Whether you have a broken arm D: Whether you have a skin infection E: What your symptoms are like
A,B,E

What are some self-help strategies for managing medically unexplained symptoms? A: Taking regular exercise B: Eating spicy food C: Managing stress D: Drinking alcohol E: Planning pleasurable personal time
A,C,E

Which of the following might be considered if symptoms are thought to be caused by a problem with the nervous system? A: Referral to a neurologist B: Referral to a dentist C: Psychotherapy D: Occupational therapy E: Physiotherapy
A,C,E

What are the potential side effects to consider when using medicine for medically unexplained symptoms? A: Dependence B: Increased appetite C: Weight loss D: Improved mood E: Side effects vary by medication
A,E
Which of the following are symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Tingling in the feet and hands B) Muscle weakness C) Problems breathing D) Fever E) Rash
A, B, C

What should you do if you think you have Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Wait a few days to see if symptoms improve B) Call 999 immediately C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Self-medicate with over-the-counter drugs E) Get help from NHS 111
C, E
Which of the following are treatments for Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) B) Plasma exchange C) Antibiotics D) Surgery E) Physical therapy
A, B, E

What should you do if you have trouble swallowing or speaking due to Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Call your GP B) Call 999 C) Take over-the-counter painkillers D) Visit a pharmacy E) Stay home and rest
A, B
Which of the following tests may be used to diagnose Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) MRI B) Electrical test of nerves and muscles C) Lumbar puncture D) X-ray E) Breathing test
B, C, E
What are some long-term problems that may occur after Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Tingling in the hands and feet B) Depression C) Muscle weakness D) Blindness E) Hair loss
A, B, C

What should you do if you have long-term symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome that are getting worse? A) Call your GP B) Contact your specialist C) Stop all medication D) Visit a pharmacy E) Ignore the symptoms
A, B
Which of the following are common initial symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Numbness B) Sharp, shooting pain C) Difficulty moving joints D) Headache E) Cough
A, B, C
What is the usual duration of a hospital stay for someone with Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) A few days B) Several weeks C) A few months D) A year E) A few hours
B, C
Which of the following are supportive therapies for Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Massage therapy B) Physiotherapy C) Occupational therapy D) Aromatherapy E) NHS talking therapies
B, C, E
What is the primary cause of a black eye? A) Infection B) Allergic reaction C) A blow to the area D) Excessive crying E) Stress
C)
What is the typical duration for a black eye to get better? A) 1 day B) 5 days C) 2 to 3 weeks D) 1 month E) 6 months
C)
Which method can help ease pain or swelling from a black eye? A) Applying hot compresses B) Rubbing the area C) Applying an ice pack D) Taking aspirin E) Eating spicy food
C)
Which painkiller is recommended for a black eye? A) Antibiotics B) Paracetamol C) Morphine D) Aspirin E) Ibuprofen
B), E)
When should you apply a warm (not hot) heat pack to the area around your eye? A) Immediately after the injury B) After the first 2 days C) Only at night D) Never E) After 1 week
B)
What should you do if a black eye does not go away within 3 weeks? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Apply more ice D) Take more aspirin E) Exercise more
B)
What should you do if you have a black eye and a headache that does not go away? A) Take aspirin B) See a GP urgently C) Drink more water D) Sleep more E) Apply a cold compress
B)
When should you go to A&E immediately with a black eye? A) If you have bruising around both eyes B) If you have a fever C) If you are feeling cold D) If you have a mild headache E) If you have a rash
A)
What should you do if you have a black eye and are taking blood-thinning medicine? A) Stop taking the medicine B) See a GP urgently C) Drink alcohol D) Exercise more E) Eat more vegetables
B)
What should you do if you have a black eye and have problems with your vision? A) Ignore it B) Go to A&E immediately C) Take more painkillers D) Wear sunglasses E) Drink coffee
B)
What are threadworms commonly known as? A: Pinworms B: Tapeworms C: Hookworms D: Roundworms E: Flatworms
A,D
Where can you see threadworms? A: In your poo B: Around your child's bottom C: On the skin D: In the hair E: On the teeth
A,B
What is a common symptom of threadworms? A: Extreme itching around the anus B: Headache C: Fever D: Stomach ache E: Irritability and waking up during the night
A,E
What medicine can you buy for threadworms from pharmacies? A: Mebendazole B: Aspirin C: Ibuprofen D: Paracetamol E: Penicillin
A,C
For how long should hygiene methods be used to treat threadworms without medicine? A: 2 weeks B: 6 weeks C: 1 month D: 3 months E: 1 year
B,D
What should you do to prevent threadworm infection? A: Wash hands regularly B: Shower every morning C: Shake clothing and bedding D: Share towels E: Vacuum and dust with a damp cloth
A,B,E
What surfaces can threadworm eggs get stuck on? A: Clothes B: Toys C: Toothbrushes D: Furniture E: Food
A,B,C,E
How long can threadworm eggs survive? A: 1 week B: 2 weeks C: 1 month D: 2 months E: 6 months
B,D
How long does it take for threadworm larvae to mature into threadworms? A: 1 day B: 1 week C: 1 month D: 2 months E: 6 months
D,E
What should you do with sleepwear and sheets after threadworm treatment? A: Wash them daily B: Burn them C: Freeze them D: Keep them unwashed E: Wash them every day for several days after treatment
A,E

What should you do to make it easier to swallow pills? A) Take pills with water B) Lean forward slightly when you swallow C) Practise swallowing with small sweets or bits of bread D) Throw pills towards the back of your throat E) Tip your head back too much when you swallow
A,B,C

What should you avoid doing when trying to swallow pills? A) Take pills with water B) Lean forward slightly when you swallow C) Practise swallowing with small sweets or bits of bread D) Throw pills towards the back of your throat E) Tip your head back too much when you swallow
D,E
Which techniques can help with swallowing pills? A) Lean forward technique B) Pop bottle technique C) Chewing technique D) Swallowing with eyes closed E) Drinking hot tea
A,B

What should you not do with pills without medical advice? A) Take pills with water B) Lean forward slightly when you swallow C) Practise swallowing with small sweets or bits of bread D) Crush pills E) Open capsules
D,E

What can a pharmacist advise you about regarding pill swallowing? A) Other versions of your medicine B) Crushing, dividing or opening up tablets and capsules C) Practising swallowing with small sweets or bits of bread D) Eating spicy food E) Drinking alcohol
A,B
What are some causes of problems swallowing pills? A) Fear of choking B) Dry mouth C) General swallowing difficulties (dysphagia) D) Lack of sleep E) Allergies
A,B,C

What should you not do if you have difficulty swallowing food and drink (not just pills)? A) Try the lean forward technique B) Try the pop bottle technique C) See a pharmacist or GP for advice D) Eat spicy food E) Drink alcohol
C

What should you do if you cannot swallow pills? A) See a pharmacist B) Try crushing pills without advice C) Practise swallowing with small sweets or bits of bread D) Drink hot tea E) Tip your head back too much when you swallow
A

What should you do before trying new pill-swallowing techniques? A) Practise with small sweets B) See a pharmacist or GP for advice C) Drink hot tea D) Eat spicy food E) Tip your head back too much when you swallow
B
What can cause swallowing difficulties? A) Fear of choking B) Dry mouth C) Stroke D) Lack of sleep E) Allergies
A,B,C
Where do most salivary gland stones form? A) Above the tongue B) Below the tongue C) In the throat D) In the nasal cavity E) On the roof of the mouth
B)
What color are salivary gland stones? A) Brown B) White C) Red D) Black E) Yellow
B)
What is the usual size of salivary gland stones? A) As big as a marble B) As big as a pea C) As big as a grain of rice D) As big as a pinhead E) As big as a plum
B)
Which symptoms can salivary gland stones cause? A) Constant sharp pain B) Dull pain that comes and goes C) Swelling that flares up D) Instant fever E) Nausea
B),C)
What can you do to try to remove a salivary gland stone? A) Sucking on a lemon B) Drinking plenty of water C) Massaging around the stone D) Using a sharp object E) Taking antibiotics
What should you do if you have pain and swelling from a salivary gland stone? A) Take paracetamol B) Suck ice cubes C) Apply heat D) Avoid drinking water E) Use a sharp object
A),B)
When should you see a GP about a salivary gland stone? A) If it's too small B) If you can't remove it yourself C) If it causes an infection D) If it's painless E) If it's white
B),C)
What can a GP do to remove a salivary gland stone? A) Use a thin, blunt instrument B) Prescribe antibiotics C) Perform surgery immediately D) Recommend using sharp objects E) Ignore the stone
A)

What is the usual course of action if a salivary gland stone cannot be removed by a GP? A) Leave it alone B) Use a sharp object C) Remove it in hospital D) Wait for it to dissolve E) Take strong medication
C)
What is not clear about salivary gland stones? A) Their cause B) Their color C) Their size D) Their prevention E) Their symptoms
A),D)
What are the common causes of ARDS? A) Asthma B) Sepsis C) Common cold D) Diabetes E) Pneumonia
B), E)
What are the immediate symptoms of ARDS? A) Runny nose B) Shortness of breath C) Fever D) Headache E) Taking short, fast breaths
B), E)

What should you do if someone has sudden shortness of breath and pain in their arms, back, neck, or jaw? A) Give them water B) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately C) Give them aspirin D) Wait and see E) Call a friend
B), D)
Where is ARDS typically treated? A) At home B) In an intensive care unit (ICU) C) In a general ward D) In a clinic E) In a rehabilitation center
B), D)
What treatments might be used for ARDS? A) Massage therapy B) Oxygen C) Ventilation D) Herbal remedies E) Medicines such as antibiotics
B), E)
What are some long-term effects of ARDS? A) Improved lung function B) Shortness of breath C) Increased energy D) Better sleep E) Muscle weakness
B), E)

What are some immediate actions to take if someone has severe difficulty breathing? A) Give them a sedative B) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately C) Encourage them to walk around D) Give them a warm drink E) Drive them to A&E
B), D)
What are some causes of ARDS related to injuries? A) Minor cuts B) Severe injuries C) Bruises D) Sprained ankle E) Food poisoning
B), D)
What are some causes of ARDS related to infections? A) Flu B) Pneumonia C) Common cold D) Food poisoning E) Acute pancreatitis
B), E)

What are some immediate actions to take if someone has sudden shortness of breath and is coughing up blood? A) Give them a warm drink B) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately C) Encourage them to rest D) Give them a painkiller E) Drive them to A&E
B), D)

Which of the following are symptoms of craniosynostosis? A) Head is long and narrow B) Forehead is pointy or triangular C) One side of the head is flattened or bulging out D) Baby cries excessively E) Baby has a rash on their head
A,B,C

What should you do if you suspect your child has craniosynostosis? A) See a GP B) Wait for the symptoms to resolve C) Give the child painkillers D) Monitor the child’s sleeping patterns E) Consult a dentist
A,D,E
Which of the following are types of craniosynostosis? A) Sagittal craniosynostosis B) Coronal craniosynostosis C) Metopic craniosynostosis D) Nasal craniosynostosis E) Lambdoid craniosynostosis
A,B,C
What can craniosynostosis affect besides the head? A) Arms B) Legs C) Breathing D) Hearing E) Sight
C,D,E

Which hospitals are specialized NHS centres for craniosynostosis? A) Alder Hey Children's Hospital B) St. Thomas' Hospital C) Great Ormond Street Hospital D) John Radcliffe Hospital E) Birmingham Children's Hospital
A,C,D
What are some of the treatments for craniosynostosis? A) Regular hearing and eye tests B) Speech and language therapy C) Surgery D) Acupuncture E) Psychological counselling
A,B,C
Which of the following are rare symptoms of craniosynostosis? A) Learning difficulties B) Sight or hearing loss C) Breathing problems D) Frequent sneezing E) Dental problems
A,B,C

What should you do if you have concerns about the development of your child’s head? A) See a GP B) Consult a nutritionist C) Take your child to a physiotherapist D) Monitor the child’s diet E) Consult a specialist centre
A,C,E
What are some long-lasting effects of craniosynostosis? A) Scar on the head B) Learning difficulties C) Hearing loss D) Problems with sight E) Excessive hair growth
A,B,C
Which of the following are not invasive procedures for treating craniosynostosis? A) Endoscopy B) Wearing a specially designed helmet C) Surgery D) Regular check-ups E) Psychological counselling
A,B,E
Which of the following are symptoms of eye cancer? A) Shadows in your vision B) Blurred vision C) A dark patch in your eye D) Eye irritation E) Chest pain
A,B,C,D
What types of cancer can affect the eyes? A) Eye melanoma B) Squamous cell carcinoma C) Lymphoma D) Retinoblastoma E) Neck cancer
A,B,C,D
Which factors increase the risk of developing eye melanoma? A) Lighter eye colour B) White or pale skin C) Unusual moles D) Overexposure to sunlight E) Smoking
A,B,C,D
What are the main treatments for eye melanoma? A) Brachytherapy B) External radiotherapy C) Surgery to remove the tumour D) Removal of the eye E) Acupuncture
A,B,C,D
Which tests are commonly used to diagnose melanoma of the eye? A) Eye examination B) Ultrasound scan of the eye C) Fluorescein angiogram D) Biopsy E) Blood test
A,B,C,D
What is the survival rate for people with eye cancer in England for at least 1 year after diagnosis? A) 95% B) 70% C) 60% D) 50% E) 30%
A,B,C,D
Which parts of the eye can be affected by eye melanoma? A) Eyeball B) Conjunctiva C) Eyelid D) Cornea E) Ear
A,B,C,D
What are the symptoms that may indicate eye cancer? A) Flashes of light in your vision B) Partial loss of vision C) Bulging of 1 eye D) A lump on your eyelid E) Nausea
A,B,C,D
How is melanoma of the eye diagnosed? A) Eye examination B) Ultrasound scan C) Fluorescein angiogram D) Biopsy E) X-ray
A,B,C,D
What is the outlook for melanoma of the eye? A) 95% live at least 1 year B) 70% live at least 5 years C) 60% live at least 10 years D) 80% live at least 15 years E) 40% live at least 20 years
A,B,C,D
What type of imaging is used in NHS breast screening? A) Ultrasound B) MRI C) X-rays D) CT scan E) PET scan
C,E
What are the images obtained during breast screening called? A) Echocardiograms B) Mammograms C) Radiographs D) Sonograms E) Electrocardiograms
B,C
Who is typically invited for breast screening? A) Men over 50 B) Women over 50 C) Children D) Teenagers E) Young adults
B,E
What is the purpose of breast screening? A) To diagnose heart disease B) To look for cancers C) To measure blood pressure D) To test lung function E) To check for diabetes
B,E
How can you decide if you want breast screening? A) By consulting a dentist B) By discussing with family C) By seeking information D) By checking with a chiropractor E) By talking to a counselor
C,E
What can you do if you need to change a breast screening appointment? A) Call a taxi B) Contact the NHS C) Visit a pharmacy D) Go to the gym E) Talk to a lawyer
B,E
What happens during a breast screening appointment? A) You get a blood test B) X-rays are taken C) You have a physical exam D) You receive a vaccine E) You discuss your medical history
B,E
How are the results of breast screening provided? A) By mail B) Via text message C) On a website D) Through a phone call E) In person
A,E
Where can you find further help and support for breast screening? A) At a grocery store B) At a library C) From the NHS D) At a car dealership E) From a support group
C,E
What is the primary tool used in NHS breast screening? A) Stethoscope B) X-ray machine C) Ultrasound probe D) Blood pressure cuff E) Thermometer
B,E
What is Tay-Sachs disease? A) A common infectious disease B) A rare inherited condition C) A mental health disorder D) A skin disease E) A nutritional deficiency
B
Which ethnic background was Tay-Sachs disease most commonly associated with in the UK? A) Chinese B) Indian C) Ashkenazi Jewish D) African E) Hispanic
C
When do symptoms of infantile Tay-Sachs disease usually start? A) At birth B) 1-2 months old C) 3-6 months old D) 7-12 months old E) 1-2 years old
C

What are the main symptoms of infantile Tay-Sachs disease? A) Rashes and itching B) Being overly startled by noises and movement C) High fever D) Rapid weight gain E) Being very slow to reach milestones like learning to crawl, and losing skills they have already learnt
B,E
How is Tay-Sachs disease inherited? A) Through a dominant gene B) Through a recessive gene C) Through environmental factors D) Through diet E) Through viral infection
B
What is the chance that a child will inherit Tay-Sachs disease if both parents are carriers? A) 1 in 2 (50%) B) 1 in 4 (25%) C) 1 in 3 (33%) D) 1 in 5 (20%) E) 1 in 6 (16.67%)
B

What should you do if you are planning a pregnancy and have an Ashkenazi Jewish background? A) Avoid planning a pregnancy B) Speak to your GP C) Take vitamin supplements D) Exercise regularly E) Avoid all medical advice
B

What treatments are available for Tay-Sachs disease? A) Surgery B) Chemotherapy C) Medicines for seizures and stiffness D) Radiation therapy E) Speech and language therapy for feeding and swallowing problems
C,E
What is the usual age of fatality for infantile Tay-Sachs disease? A) 1-2 years old B) 3-5 years old C) 5-10 years old D) 10-15 years old E) 15-20 years old
B
Which specialists might be involved in the care of a child with Tay-Sachs disease? A) Dermatologists B) Orthopedic surgeons C) A team of specialists D) Dentists E) Optometrists
C
How many units of alcohol are men and women advised not to regularly drink more than a week? A) 10 units B) 14 units C) 20 units D) 30 units E) 5 units
B)
A unit of alcohol is equivalent to: A) 1 pint of beer B) 1 glass of wine C) 10ml of pure alcohol D) 1 bottle of spirits E) 1 litre of cider
C)
To keep the risk of alcohol-related harm low, you should spread your weekly alcohol intake over: A) 1 day B) 2 days C) 3 or more days D) 5 days E) 7 days
C)

What is the safest approach for pregnant women regarding alcohol consumption? A) Drink no more than 7 units a week B) Drink only on weekends C) Avoid alcohol completely D) Drink only water E) Drink only wine
C)
Which of the following is NOT a short-term risk of alcohol misuse? A) Head injury B) Unprotected sex C) Diabetes D) Loss of personal possessions E) Alcohol poisoning
C)
Persistent alcohol misuse increases the risk of which serious health condition? A) Flu B) Liver disease C) Common cold D) Diarrhea E) Hay fever
B)
Someone who is severely dependent on alcohol may experience which of the following withdrawal symptoms? A) Increased appetite B) Hand tremors C) Stronger bones D) Improved memory E) Better sleep
B)
You may be misusing alcohol if: A) You drink only on holidays B) You feel you should cut down on your drinking C) You drink only water D) You never drink alone E) You only drink with friends
B)
Which of the following is a treatment option for alcohol misuse? A) Surgery B) Counselling C) Exercise D) Dieting E) Sleeping pills
B)
Which medicine is commonly used to help stop withdrawal symptoms in alcohol misuse treatment? A) Aspirin B) Chlordiazapoxide C) Ibuprofen D) Paracetamol E) Antibiotics
B)

What is hydrocephalus? A) A build-up of blood in the brain B) A build-up of fluid in the brain C) A build-up of air in the brain D) A build-up of solid matter in the brain E) A build-up of water in the brain
B)
What are the main symptoms of hydrocephalus? A) Headache B) Being sick C) Blurred vision D) Difficulty walking E) Fever
What are the three main types of hydrocephalus? A) Congenital hydrocephalus B) Acquired hydrocephalus C) Normal pressure hydrocephalus D) Chronic hydrocephalus E) Acute hydrocephalus
What can cause congenital hydrocephalus? A) Spina bifida B) Mumps C) Rubella D) Flu E) Chickenpox
What are some long-term complications of congenital hydrocephalus? A) Learning disabilities B) Speech problems C) Epilepsy D) Diabetes E) Heart disease
What can cause acquired hydrocephalus? A) Serious head injury B) Brain tumour C) Stroke D) Appendicitis E) Kidney failure
A),B)
What are the main symptoms of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH)? A) Mobility problems B) Dementia C) Urinary incontinence D) High blood pressure E) Weight loss
What is used to diagnose congenital and acquired hydrocephalus? A) CT scans B) MRI scans C) X-rays D) Blood tests E) Ultrasound
A),B)
What treatment can be used for hydrocephalus? A) A thin tube (shunt) B) Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) C) Medication D) Physical therapy E) Diet changes
A),B)

What are the functions of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)? A) Protects the brain from damage B) Removes waste products from the brain C) Provides the brain with nutrients D) Regulates body temperature E) Aids in digestion
What is endocarditis? A) A rare and potentially fatal infection of the inner lining of the heart B) A common viral infection C) A skin condition D) A type of diabetes
A
What is the most common cause of endocarditis? A) Bacteria entering the blood and travelling to the heart B) A genetic mutation C) Exposure to radiation D) A dietary deficiency
A
Who is more likely to develop endocarditis? A) People who have an artificial heart valve B) People with allergies C) People with asthma D) People with arthritis
A

What are the initial symptoms of endocarditis? A) A high temperature, chills, headache, joint and muscle pain B) Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea C) Coughing, wheezing, chest pain D) Abdominal pain, constipation
A
What complications can arise from untreated endocarditis? A) Heart failure, stroke B) Kidney failure, liver failure C) Vision loss, hearing loss D) Hair loss, skin rash
A
How is endocarditis treated? A) With a course of antibiotics given via a drip B) With surgery alone C) With a strict diet D) With physical therapy
A
What is the preferred method for treating endocarditis? A) Hospital admission for antibiotic treatment B) Home remedies C) Pain relievers D) Antiviral medication
A
Who is more commonly affected by endocarditis? A) Older people B) Young adults C) Teenagers D) Infants
A
What is the gender distribution of endocarditis? A) Twice as many men are affected as women B) Equal numbers of men and women C) Twice as many women are affected as men D) Men are rarely affected
A
Why are rates of endocarditis increasing? A) Because of advances in medical care B) Due to environmental factors C) Due to poor hygiene D) Due to increased air pollution
A

What is the definition of euthanasia? A) The act of deliberately ending a person's life to relieve suffering. B) The act of deliberately assisting another person to kill themselves. C) The act of giving a patient a drug they need. D) The act of providing palliative care. E) The act of making an advance decision to refuse treatment.
A

Which law makes assisted suicide illegal in England? A) The Mental Health Act (1983). B) The Suicide Act (1961). C) The Human Rights Act (1998). D) The Criminal Justice Act (2003). E) The Protection of Patients Act (2010).
B
What is the maximum penalty for euthanasia under English law? A) 5 years' imprisonment. B) 10 years' imprisonment. C) Life imprisonment. D) A fine of £5000. E) Community service.
C

What is voluntary euthanasia? A) Where a person makes a conscious decision to die and asks for help to do so. B) Where a person is unable to give their consent. C) Where a person is in a coma. D) Where a person refuses all treatment. E) Where a person receives hospice care.
A

What is non-voluntary euthanasia? A) Where a person makes a conscious decision to die and asks for help to do so. B) Where a person is unable to give their consent and another person takes the decision on their behalf. C) Where a person refuses all treatment. D) Where a person receives hospice care. E) Where a person is in a coma and previously expressed a wish for their life to be ended.
E

What is the right of a person approaching the last stage of their life? A) To receive experimental treatments. B) To high quality, personalised end of life care that helps them live as well as possible until they die. C) To choose their own medication. D) To refuse all medical assistance. E) To select their own caregiver.
B

What can you find out more about regarding end of life care? A) Where you can be cared for. B) Coping with a terminal illness. C) Starting to talk about your illness. D) Managing pain and other symptoms. E) All of the above.
E

What is an advance decision to refuse treatment? A) A legal document to choose your caregiver. B) A legal document to select your medication. C) A legal document to refuse all medical treatments. D) A legally binding document to refuse specific treatments. E) A document to plan your funeral.
D

What is a lasting power of attorney? A) A document to plan your funeral. B) A legally binding document allowing someone you trust to make decisions for you if you cannot make them in the future. C) A document to choose your caregiver. D) A document to select your medication. E) A document to refuse all medical treatments.
B

What is the penalty for assisted suicide under the Suicide Act (1961)? A) Up to 7 years' imprisonment. B) Up to 14 years' imprisonment. C) Up to 20 years' imprisonment. D) A fine of £1000. E) Community service.
B

What type of cancer affects the part of the throat connecting the back of the nose to the back of the mouth? A) Laryngeal cancer B) Oesophageal cancer C) Nasopharyngeal cancer D) Stomach cancer E) Lung cancer
C
What is a common symptom of nasopharyngeal cancer that persists for more than 3 weeks? A) Lump in the neck B) Chest pain C) Abdominal pain D) Fever E) Joint pain
A
Which virus is associated with an increased risk of developing nasopharyngeal cancer? A) Herpes Simplex Virus B) Epstein-Barr Virus C) Influenza Virus D) Rotavirus E) Zika Virus
B
What type of imaging scan is commonly used to diagnose nasopharyngeal cancer? A) X-ray B) MRI scan C) Ultrasound D) Doppler E) ECG
B
What is the most commonly used treatment for nasopharyngeal cancer? A) Surgery B) Radiotherapy C) Chemotherapy D) Immunotherapy E) Hormone therapy
B
What is a common side effect of radiotherapy for nasopharyngeal cancer? A) Hair loss B) Constipation C) Blurred vision D) Muscle pain E) Kidney problems
A
What is the average age at diagnosis for nasopharyngeal cancer? A) 20 B) 30 C) 40 D) 50 E) 60
D
What is a common symptom of nasopharyngeal cancer related to hearing? A) Hearing loss in one ear B) Hearing loss in both ears C) Ringing in both ears D) Dizziness E) Ear pain
A
What type of endoscopy is used to examine the throat for nasopharyngeal cancer? A) Nasendoscopy B) Colonoscopy C) Bronchoscopy D) Gastroscopy E) Cystoscopy
A
What is a common risk factor for developing nasopharyngeal cancer related to diet? A) High sugar diet B) High fat diet C) High salt-cured meats and fish diet D) High fiber diet E) Low protein diet
C
What is an acoustic neuroma? A) A type of non-cancerous brain tumour B) A type of bacterial infection C) A type of viral infection D) A type of autoimmune disease E) A type of benign brain tumour
A,E
Which symptoms are associated with an acoustic neuroma? A) Hearing loss B) Tinnitus C) Vertigo D) Fever E) Cough
A,B,C
What is the typical age range for people affected by acoustic neuromas? A) 10 to 20 B) 20 to 30 C) 30 to 60 D) 60 to 70 E) 70 to 80
C
What is a possible genetic cause of acoustic neuromas? A) Neurofibromatosis type 1 B) Neurofibromatosis type 2 C) Cystic fibrosis D) Huntington's disease E) Sickle cell anemia
B
Which tests may be used to diagnose an acoustic neuroma? A) Blood test B) Hearing tests C) MRI scan D) X-ray E) CT scan
B,C,E
What are the main treatment options for an acoustic neuroma? A) Monitoring the tumour B) Brain surgery C) Stereotactic radiosurgery D) Chemotherapy E) Physical therapy
A,B,C
What are some risks associated with the treatment of acoustic neuromas? A) Facial numbness B) Paralysis C) Hair loss D) Nausea E) Vomiting
A,B
What can a large acoustic neuroma cause? A) Hydrocephalus B) Diabetes C) Heart disease D) Kidney failure E) Liver failure
A
Which condition can have similar symptoms to an acoustic neuroma? A) Ménière's disease B) Parkinson's disease C) Alzheimer's disease D) Asthma E) Arthritis
A

What is the outlook for acoustic neuromas? A) They often grow very slowly B) They can be life-threatening C) They always cause hearing loss D) They always cause vertigo E) They often require chemotherapy
A,B

What is an arthroscopy? A) A type of keyhole surgery for checking or repairing your joints B) A method for diagnosing skin diseases C) A technique for repairing broken bones D) A procedure for removing gallbladder E) A type of surgery for repairing muscles
Which of the following joints can be treated with arthroscopy? A) Knees B) Ankles C) Hips D) Shoulders E) Toes

Arthroscopy is mainly used for which purpose? A) To find what's causing pain, swelling and stiffness in your joints B) To treat respiratory issues C) To diagnose digestive problems D) To repair nerve damage E) To perform heart surgery
What type of surgery is arthroscopy? A) Keyhole surgery B) Open surgery C) Endoscopic surgery D) Laparoscopic surgery E) Robotic surgery
Which body parts can arthroscopy also be used on besides the knees? A) Ankles B) Spine C) Wrists D) Elbows E) Ears

What is the primary benefit of arthroscopy? A) Only small cuts are made into the body B) It is a non-invasive procedure C) It requires no anesthesia D) It is used for cosmetic purposes E) It is a quick procedure
What symptoms can arthroscopy help diagnose? A) Pain B) Swelling C) Stiffness D) Fever E) Dizziness
Which of the following is not a common use of arthroscopy? A) Knees B) Wrists C) Elbows D) Ears E) Hips
What is the main purpose of arthroscopy? A) Checking or repairing your joints B) Removing tumors C) Treating cancer D) Correcting vision E) Repairing ligaments
Which of the following is a benefit of arthroscopy? A) Smaller incisions B) Faster recovery time C) Less pain D) Higher risk of infection E) Longer hospital stay
At what altitude are you more likely to get altitude sickness? A) 500 metres B) 1,000 metres C) 2,500 metres D) 3,500 metres E) 4,000 metres
C,D,
What are the main symptoms of altitude sickness? A) Chest pain B) Headache C) Loss of appetite D) Sweating E) Increased appetite
B,C,
What should you do if you feel unwell at a high altitude? A) Climb higher B) Take anti-sickness medicine C) Rest at the same altitude D) Drink alcohol E) Ignore the symptoms
B,C,
When do symptoms of altitude sickness usually start? A) Immediately B) 1-2 hours C) 6-10 hours D) 12-24 hours E) After a week
C,D,
What should you do if your symptoms do not improve after 1 day? A) Climb higher B) Go to a lower altitude C) Drink more alcohol D) Take a hot bath E) Ignore the symptoms
B,E,

What is a sign that you need urgent medical help at a high altitude? A) Feeling very unwell B) Having a cough C) Seeing or hearing things that are not real D) Feeling short of breath E) Feeling very sleepy
A,E,

What are some treatments for more serious symptoms of altitude sickness? A) Steroid medicine B) Oxygen through a mask C) Increasing physical activity D) Drinking coffee E) Medicine to lower blood pressure
A,E,

What should you do to reduce your risk of altitude sickness? A) Travel or climb to a high altitude slowly B) Drink alcohol C) Sleep more than 500 metres higher than the night before D) Spend a few days at an altitude below 2,500 metres E) Ignore dehydration
A,D,
What can you take to ease symptoms of altitude sickness? A) Anti-sickness medicine B) Painkillers such as ibuprofen C) Painkillers such as paracetamol D) Vitamin supplements E) Energy drinks
A,B,
Where cannot you get altitude sickness? A) Mount Everest B) Mount Kilimanjaro C) Alps D) UK E) La Paz
D,E,
What are fibroids made of? A: Muscle and fibrous tissue B: Fat and bone C: Cartilage and nerves D: Skin and hair E: Blood vessels
A
What are the common symptoms of fibroids? A: Heavy periods B: Painful periods C: Tummy pain D: Constipation E: Weight gain
A,B,C
Which hormone is linked to the development of fibroids? A: Testosterone B: Oestrogen C: Insulin D: Progesterone E: Cortisol
B
When do fibroids usually develop? A: During childhood B: During menopause C: During a woman's reproductive years D: During old age E: During pregnancy
C
Who is more likely to develop fibroids? A: Women of African-Caribbean origin B: Women who have had children C: Thin women D: Elderly women E: Men
A
What are the main types of fibroids? A: Intramural fibroids B: Subserosal fibroids C: Submucosal fibroids D: Pedunculated fibroids E: Extramural fibroids
A,B,C
How are fibroids usually diagnosed? A: Blood test B: Ultrasound scan C: X-ray D: MRI E: Physical examination
B
What happens to fibroids after menopause? A: They grow larger B: They shrink C: They become cancerous D: They cause more pain E: They change color
B

Which group of women has a lower risk of developing fibroids? A: Women who have had children B: Women of African-Caribbean origin C: Overweight women D: Women under 30 E: Women with high oestrogen levels
A
What are the complications caused by fibroids? A: Infertility B: Cancer C: Hair loss D: Pregnancy E: Depression
A,D
What is the primary cause of smelly feet? A) Lack of nutrition B) Build-up of sweat and bacteria C) Lack of sleep D) Excessive walking E) Poor diet
B
How often should you wash your feet to prevent smelly feet? A) Once a week B) Once a day C) Twice a week D) Once a month E) Twice a day
B
Which type of fabrics should you wear on your feet to prevent smelly feet? A) Synthetic fabrics B) Wool C) Cotton D) Plastic E) Leather
C,E
What should you do if you have smelly feet? A) Wear the same socks for a week B) Wear tight shoes C) Use foot powder D) Walk barefoot in public showers E) Use antibacterial soap
C,E
What can a pharmacist help with for smelly feet? A) Medicated insoles B) Antibacterial socks C) Special foot deodorant D) Antibacterial soaps E) Shoe polish
A,B,C,D
What are the main causes of smelly feet? A) Fungal infections B) Athlete's foot C) Excessive sweating D) Poor hygiene E) Lack of exercise
A,B,C
What factors can affect the amount you sweat? A) Hot weather B) Exercise C) Standing all day D) Eating spicy food E) Watching TV
A,B,C
When should you see a GP about smelly feet? A) When they have not improved after treatment B) When they affect your daily life C) When you are bored D) When you feel like it E) When you have a cold
A,B
What treatment might a GP suggest for smelly feet caused by sweating? A) Stronger antiperspirant B) Iontophoresis C) Surgery D) Vitamin supplements E) Yoga
A,B

What should you do with your shoes to prevent smelly feet? A) Wear the same shoes every day B) Let shoes dry out before wearing them again C) Wear shoes in the rain D) Leave shoes outside E) Wear shoes without socks
B

What are the symptoms of blepharitis? A) Sore eyelids B) Itchy eyes C) A gritty feeling in the eyes D) Flakes or crusts around the roots of the eyelashes E) Eyelids not sticking together in the morning
A,B,C,D

What should you do to treat and prevent blepharitis? A) Clean your eyelids twice a day B) Continue to clean your eyes, even if your symptoms clear up C) Wear contact lenses while you have symptoms D) Use eye makeup, especially eyeliner and mascara, while you have symptoms E) Clean your eyelids once a day as your symptoms improve
A,B,E

What steps are involved in cleaning your eyes for blepharitis? A) Soak a clean flannel or cotton wool in warm water and place it on your closed eyelid for 5 to 10 minutes B) Gently massage your eyelids for around 30 seconds C) Clean your eyelids using cotton wool or a cotton bud D) Use a small amount of baby shampoo in water E) Wipe along the edge of your eyelids to remove any flakes or crusts
A,B,C,D,E
What can a pharmacist suggest to help with blepharitis? A) Eye pads and wipes B) Eyedrops C) Antibiotic cream D) Surgery E) Referral to a specialist
A,B

When should you see a GP for blepharitis? A) If blepharitis symptoms do not improve after a few weeks of cleaning your eyelids B) If treatment involves surgery C) If you have other eye symptoms D) If blepharitis has caused other problems, such as a lump of fluid under the skin (cyst) E) If blepharitis is severe
A,D,E
What treatments might a GP suggest for blepharitis? A) Antibiotic cream or ointment B) Antibiotic eyedrops C) Antibiotic tablets D) Surgery E) Referral to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist)
A,B,C,E

What can cause blepharitis? A) A type of bacteria that lives on the skin B) A skin condition, such as seborrhoeic dermatitis C) The glands inside the eyelids not producing enough oil D) A virus E) Allergies
A,B,C

What should you avoid while you have blepharitis symptoms? A) Wearing contact lenses B) Using eye makeup, especially eyeliner and mascara C) Cleaning your eyelids D) Applying antibiotic cream E) Visiting a pharmacy
A,B

How can blepharitis be managed at home? A) Cleaning your eyelids twice a day B) Using eye pads and wipes C) Applying an antibiotic cream D) Wearing contact lenses E) Continuing to clean your eyes even if symptoms clear up
A,B,E
What are some possible complications of blepharitis? A) A lump of fluid under the skin (cyst) B) Severe pain C) Blindness D) Need for surgery E) Referral to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist)
A,E
What are the symptoms of varicose veins? A) Pain, aching, feeling of heaviness B) Numbness, tingling C) Fever D) Vomiting E) Skin changes such as itching, colour changes, dry, scaly skin
A,E,
What are the recommended treatments for varicose veins? A) Surgery B) Compression stockings C) Foam sclerotherapy D) Endothermal ablation E) Acupuncture
A,B,D,
Which of the following can help with varicose veins symptoms? A) Exercise regularly B) Stand for long periods C) Smoke regularly D) Use a moisturising cream E) Keep to a healthy weight
A,D,E,
What are some potential complications of varicose veins? A) Bleeding B) Itchy, flaky, dry skin C) Diabetes D) Hair loss E) Sores that take a long time to heal
A,B,E,

What are the main steps in endothermal ablation? A) Using a local anaesthetic B) Passing a catheter up the vein C) Heating the vein with radio waves D) Cutting the vein E) Using ultrasound to place the catheter
A,B,C,
What should you do if you have varicose veins and experience bleeding? A) Apply a bandage B) Call NHS 111 C) Stand for a long time D) Take a painkiller E) Ask for an urgent GP appointment
B,E,
Which parts of the body are varicose veins most common on? A) Arms B) Legs C) Chest D) Back E) Face
B,
What is the first choice of treatment for varicose veins? A) Surgery B) Foam sclerotherapy C) Endothermal ablation D) Massage therapy E) Compression stockings
C,
What are the risks of varicose veins during pregnancy? A) They get worse B) They go away C) They cause complications D) They require surgery E) They cause fever
A,B,
What are the causes of varicose veins? A) Being overweight B) Pregnancy C) Spending a lot of time sitting D) Diabetes E) Family history of varicose veins
A,B,C,

What is the main purpose of the guide on autism provided by the NHS? A) To provide a detailed history of autism research B) To explain how to cure autism C) To help people understand and manage autism D) To list all autistic people in the UK E) To describe the economic impact of autism
C

What does the 'Signs of autism' section aim to cover? A) The genetic causes of autism B) How to get diagnosed with autism C) The main signs of autism and when to seek advice D) The impact of autism on employment E) Autism in adults over 60
C

What information can you find in the 'Getting diagnosed' section? A) How to apply for disability benefits B) The process of getting diagnosed as autistic and its benefits C) The best schools for autistic children D) How to detect autism in pets E) Autism in different cultures
B

What kind of support does the 'Newly diagnosed: things to help' section offer? A) Information on financial support B) Advice for parents of newly diagnosed autistic children C) List of famous autistic people D) How to join autism research studies E) Tips for traveling with autistic individuals
B

What is the focus of the 'Autism and everyday life' section? A) How to cope with autism in the workplace B) Information and advice for caring for an autistic child C) Autism and dietary restrictions D) Autism and sports E) Autism and technology
B

What can you learn from the 'Other conditions that affect autistic people' section? A) How autism affects other family members B) Which conditions often affect autistic people and their symptoms C) Autism and mental health D) Autism and physical health E) Autism and addiction
B

Where can you get support if you or your child are autistic, according to the guide? A) Only from private clinics B) From charities and your council C) From social media groups D) From online forums E) From your local library
B

What format is the 'Easy read information and videos' section available in? A) Audio books B) Podcasts C) Information in an easy read format or video D) Interactive games E) Virtual reality experiences
C

What is the primary goal of the 'What is autism?' section? A) To discuss the social stigma around autism B) To introduce what autism is and how it affects people C) To compare autism with other neurodevelopmental disorders D) To provide statistics on autism prevalence E) To explain the legal rights of autistic individuals
B

What is the main focus of the guide as a whole? A) To provide a comprehensive list of autism symptoms B) To help if you or someone you care about is autistic or might be autistic C) To discuss the history of autism research D) To provide a list of famous autistic individuals E) To explain the causes of autism
B
What is the most common cause of hip pain in children? A) Infected hip joint B) Irritable hip C) Broken bone D) Perthes' disease E) Influenza
B

What should you do if your child gets sudden pain in their hip, thigh, or knee? A) Ignore it B) Give them painkillers C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Wait for it to go away E) Put ice on the area
C

What might a doctor or nurse do to find out the cause of your child's hip pain? A) Perform surgery B) Look at and feel your child's hip C) Give them antibiotics D) Prescribe physical therapy E) Arrange an X-ray
B,E
How long does irritable hip usually take to get better? A) A few hours B) 1 or 2 weeks C) Several months D) A few days E) More than a year
B

What should you do if your child has irritable hip? A) Make sure they rest their leg B) Give them ibuprofen for children C) Attend any follow-up appointments D) Encourage them to run E) Apply a heating pad
A,B,C
What should you avoid doing if your child has irritable hip? A) Let them do strenuous activities B) Give them paracetamol C) Keep them off school D) Apply ice to the area E) Have them swim
A
What should you do if your child's hip pain is getting worse or has not improved? A) Wait and see B) Give them more painkillers C) Take them back to the GP D) Apply heat E) Encourage them to walk
C
What is a possible cause of hip pain in children besides irritable hip? A) Flu B) Septic arthritis C) Stomach ache D) Headache E) Toothache
B

What might indicate a more serious problem if your child has hip pain? A) If they are still in pain after 2 weeks B) If they have a high temperature C) If their hip pain comes back D) If they are hungry E) If they are tired
A,B,C
What is a good activity for your child to do once they are feeling better from irritable hip? A) Running B) Swimming C) Jumping D) Climbing E) Weightlifting
B
What are the signs of constipation in adults? A) Not pooing as often B) Straining or pain when pooing C) Poo is unusually large or small and dry D) Feeling bloated E) Frequent urination
A,B,C,D
What are some common causes of constipation in adults? A) Not drinking enough fluids B) Stress, anxiety, or depression C) Not eating enough fibre D) Being less active E) Sleeping too much
A,B,C,D
What dietary changes can help treat constipation? A) Eating a healthy balanced diet B) Drinking plenty of water C) Adding wheat bran to your diet D) Increasing fibre intake E) Eating more junk food
A,B,C,D
What are some symptoms that may indicate constipation in older people or those with dementia? A) Confusion B) Stomach ache C) Behaviour changes D) Feeling bloated E) Vision problems
A,B,C,D
What can cause constipation during pregnancy? A) Hormonal changes B) Not eating enough fibre C) Not drinking enough fluids D) Being less active E) Eating too much sugar
B,C,D
What are some rare medical conditions that can cause constipation? A) Diverticular disease B) Bowel cancer C) Flu D) Common cold E) Lung infection
A,B
What should you do if diet and lifestyle changes are not helping with constipation? A) Speak to a pharmacist B) Try stronger laxatives C) See a GP D) Try a suppository E) Stop eating completely
A,C
What complications can arise from long-term constipation? A) Faecal impaction B) Diarrhoea C) Dehydration D) Fever E) Headache
A,B

What are some signs that you should see a GP for constipation? A) Constipation not getting better with treatment B) Regular bloating C) Blood in your poo D) Sudden changes in bowel habits E) Feeling fine
A,B,C,D

What can help with constipation in adults? A) A daily walk or run B) Resting feet on a low stool while going to the toilet C) Not delaying the urge to poo D) Drinking alcohol E) Eating more processed foods
A,B,C
What are the symptoms of oral mucositis? A) Dry mouth B) Headache C) Mouth ulcers D) Sore throat E) Oral thrush
A, C

When do symptoms of mucositis in your gut usually begin? A) Immediately after starting treatment B) 2 weeks after starting treatment C) 1 month after starting treatment D) 6 months after starting treatment E) 1 year after starting treatment
B, E
What should you do if you have diarrhoea or bloody stools during cancer treatment? A) Ignore it B) Take painkillers C) Get help from NHS 111 D) Drink more alcohol E) Use alcohol-based mouthwash
C, E
What are some things you can do to ease the symptoms of mucositis? A) Brush your teeth with a soft toothbrush B) Smoke cigarettes C) Chew sugar-free gum D) Eat spicy food E) Drink plenty of water
A, C
What treatments are offered for mucositis in your mouth? A) Painkillers B) Oral surgery C) Mouthwashes D) Saliva substitutes E) Hot drinks
A, C
What is low-level laser therapy used for? A) Treating headaches B) Treating oral mucositis C) Treating stomach ulcers D) Preventing hair loss E) Relaxing muscles
B, D

What should you do if you have a sore mouth or mouth ulcers during cancer treatment? A) Ignore it B) Tell a GP or your care team C) Use alcohol-based mouthwash D) Eat hard foods E) Stop brushing your teeth
B, C
What are some symptoms of mucositis in your gut? A) Constipation B) Fever C) Stomach cramps D) Coughing E) Bloating
A, C
How long does each session of low-level laser therapy last? A) 5-10 minutes B) 10-15 minutes C) 20-30 minutes D) 30-40 minutes E) 40-50 minutes
C, D
What should you do if you have black or dark red poo during cancer treatment? A) Ignore it B) Get help from NHS 111 C) Drink more alcohol D) Eat spicy food E) Stop all medication
B, E
Which of the following are common symptoms of listeriosis in most people? A) Fever B) Body aches C) Chills D) Nausea E) Diarrhea
A,B,C,D
Which foods are most commonly associated with listeriosis? A) Raw vegetables B) Cooked sliced meats C) Soft cheeses D) Pre-cut fruit E) Unpasteurised milk
B,C,D,E
Which groups of people are at higher risk of serious problems from listeriosis? A) Children under 5 B) Pregnant women C) People with weakened immune systems D) Newborn babies E) Older people
B,C,D,E
What actions should you take if you think you have listeriosis and you are pregnant? A) Call your midwife B) Get help from NHS 111 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Ignore it E) Call 999
A,B,C

What are the symptoms of meningitis caused by listeriosis that require immediate action? A) Severe headache and stiff neck B) Difficulty looking at bright lights C) Seizures D) Sudden confusion E) Blotchy rash that does not fade
A,B,C,D

Which of the following are ways to avoid listeriosis? A) Keep chilled foods cold B) Eat ready-to-eat foods within 4 hours C) Follow storage instructions on food labels D) Keep raw and ready-to-eat foods separate E) Cook foods until steaming hot
A,B,C,D
Which foods should pregnant women avoid to reduce the risk of listeriosis? A) Cooked sliced meats B) Smoked salmon C) Soft cheeses D) Pâté E) Unpasteurised milk
B,C,D,E
What actions should you take if you think your baby might have listeriosis? A) Call NHS 111 B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Ignore it D) Drive to A&E E) Call 999
A,B,E

Which of the following are less common ways to catch listeriosis? A) Eating contaminated food B) Close contact with farm animals C) Handling food from someone with listeriosis D) Drinking tap water E) Breathing contaminated air
B,C
What are the serious and life-threatening problems that listeriosis can cause in babies and people with weakened immune systems? A) Flu B) Sepsis C) Meningitis D) Heart attack E) Kidney failure
B,C
What is considered a low blood pressure reading? A) 120/80mmHg B) 90/60mmHg C) 150/90mmHg D) 80/50mmHg E) 140/100mmHg
B,D
What are some symptoms of low blood pressure? A) High fever B) Dizziness C) Chest pain D) Blurred vision E) Confusion
B,D
What should you do if you keep getting symptoms of low blood pressure? A) Go to the emergency room B) See a GP C) Take a nap D) Drink coffee E) Exercise more
B,E

How can you check your blood pressure? A) By asking a pharmacist B) By using a home blood pressure monitor C) By checking your pulse D) By measuring your temperature E) By asking a GP or practice nurse
A,E

What is postural hypotension? A) Low blood pressure due to dehydration B) Low blood pressure when standing up C) High blood pressure due to stress D) Low blood pressure due to medication E) High blood pressure when lying down
B,D
What are some treatments for low blood pressure? A) Wearing support stockings B) Increasing caffeine intake C) Changing medicines or altering dose D) Surgery E) Drinking less water
A,C

What can you do to ease low blood pressure symptoms yourself? A) Get up slowly from sitting to standing B) Drink more alcohol C) Eat large, infrequent meals D) Increase water intake E) Sit or stand for long periods
A,D
What can cause low blood pressure? A) Being overweight B) Being pregnant C) Some medical conditions D) High cholesterol E) Some medicines
B,E

What should you not do if you have low blood pressure symptoms? A) Get up slowly B) Drink plenty of water C) Sit or stand for long periods D) Bend down or change posture suddenly E) Eat small, frequent meals
C,D
How often should you have your blood pressure checked if you're 40 to 74 years old? A) Every year B) Every 5 years C) Every 10 years D) Every month E) Every 2 years
B,E

Which of the following is an early symptom of Lyme disease? A: A circular or oval shape rash around a tick bite B: A burning sensation at the bite site C: Immediate severe pain D: A sudden outbreak of hives E: Swelling of the lymph nodes
A
