How long after being bitten by an infected tick can the rash appear? A: Up to 3 months B: Within 1 to 4 weeks C: Within a few days D: Immediately E: After a year
A,B

What are some flu-like symptoms that may appear a few days or weeks after being bitten by an infected tick? A: A high temperature B: Headache C: Muscle and joint pain D: Tiredness and loss of energy E: Diarrhea
A,B,C,D
Where are high-risk places for ticks that may cause Lyme disease? A: Grassy and wooded areas in southern and northern England B: Urban parks and gardens C: Scottish Highlands D: Deserts E: Beaches
A,C

What should you do if you find a tick on your skin? A: Use fine-tipped tweezers or a tick-removal tool B: Grasp the tick as close to the skin as possible C: Slowly pull upwards, taking care not to squeeze or crush the tick D: Clean the bite with antiseptic or soap and water E: Apply heat to the tick
A,B,C,D

What are some more severe symptoms of Lyme disease that may develop months or years later? A: Pain and swelling in joints B: Nerve problems C: Heart problems D: Trouble with memory or concentration E: Loss of appetite
A,B,C,D

What should you do if you have flu-like symptoms after being bitten by a tick? A: See a GP B: Take over-the-counter painkillers C: Wait for the symptoms to pass D: Apply a cold compress E: Drink lots of water
A
What are some symptoms that a few people continue to have after being treated for Lyme disease? A: Tiredness B: Aches C: Loss of energy D: Fever E: Cough
A,B,C

What can you do to reduce the chance of being bitten by a tick? A: Cover your skin while walking outdoors B: Use insect repellent on your clothes and skin C: Stay on clear paths D: Wear light-coloured clothing E: Avoid all outdoor activities
A,B,C,D

What should you do if your symptoms come back or do not improve after treatment with antibiotics? A: Speak to a doctor B: Take more antibiotics C: Exercise more D: Drink plenty of fluids E: Take vitamin supplements
A
What is gangrene? A) A type of infection B) A condition where loss of blood supply causes tissue to die C) A type of skin rash D) A type of muscle strain E) A type of bone fracture
B
Which parts of the body are typically affected by gangrene? A) Ears B) Toes, feet, fingers, and hands C) Eyes D) Nose E) Tongue
B

What are the symptoms of gangrene? A) Red, purple or black skin B) Swelling of the skin C) Loss of sensation or severe pain D) Sores or blisters that bleed or produce foul-smelling pus E) Fever and chills
A,B,C,D

What should you do if you suspect you have gangrene? A) Wait and see if it gets better B) See your GP immediately C) Apply ice to the affected area D) Take over-the-counter pain medication E) Ignore the symptoms
B
Who is at a higher risk of developing gangrene? A) People with diabetes B) People with atherosclerosis C) People with peripheral arterial disease D) People with Raynaud's E) People with asthma
A,B,C,D
How is gangrene treated? A) Surgery to remove damaged tissue B) Antibiotics to treat infection C) Surgery to restore blood flow D) Amputation in severe cases E) Chemotherapy
A,B,C,D
What is the medical term for surgery to remove damaged tissue? A) Debridement B) Amputation C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Incision
A
What can be done to prevent gangrene? A) Regular check-ups B) Stopping smoking C) Adopting a healthy lifestyle D) Regular exercise E) Eating a low-fat diet
A,B,C,D,E
What is atherosclerosis? A) A condition where arteries become clogged with plaque B) A type of skin infection C) A type of bone infection D) A type of nerve damage E) A type of viral infection
A
What is Raynaud's? A) A condition where blood vessels react abnormally to cold temperatures B) A type of skin cancer C) A type of bone cancer D) A type of nerve damage E) A type of viral infection
A
At what age do children with Angelman syndrome typically begin to show signs of delayed development? A) 3-6 months B) 6-12 months C) 12-18 months D) 18-24 months E) 24-30 months
B)
What is one of the distinctive behaviours associated with Angelman syndrome? A) Excessive crying B) Frequent laughter and smiling C) Aggressive behaviour D) Extreme shyness E) Constant yawning
B)
Which gene is primarily responsible for Angelman syndrome? A) BRCA1 B) CFTR C) UBE3A D) TP53 E) APOE
C)
What is the characteristic feature of the head in some children with Angelman syndrome? A) Large head B) Small head which may also be flat at the back C) Round head D) Pointed head E) Narrow head
B)
What is a common feeding issue in young babies with Angelman syndrome? A) Overeating B) Difficulty coordinating sucking and swallowing C) Refusal to eat D) Excessive drooling E) Choking frequently
B)
How is Angelman syndrome typically diagnosed? A) MRI scan B) Blood test C) X-ray D) Ultrasound E) ECG
B)

What is a common movement difficulty in children with Angelman syndrome? A) Difficulty running B) Difficulty walking because of issues with balance and coordination (ataxia) C) Difficulty jumping D) Difficulty standing E) Difficulty crawling
B)
What is a potential treatment for seizures in children with Angelman syndrome? A) Antibiotics B) Anti-epileptic medicine C) Painkillers D) Antihistamines E) Steroids
B)
What is a therapy that may help children with Angelman syndrome develop non-verbal language skills? A) Music therapy B) Dance therapy C) Communication therapy D) Art therapy E) Play therapy
C)

What is a potential outcome for people with Angelman syndrome as they age? A) Increased hyperactivity B) Increased mobility C) Loss of mobility and joint stiffening D) Improved speech E) Decreased seizures
C)
What is phenylketonuria (PKU)? A) A viral infection B) A rare but potentially serious inherited disorder C) A common cold D) A fungal infection E) A bacterial infection
B)

What happens to amino acids that are not needed in the body? A) They are stored in fat cells B) They are broken down further and removed from the body C) They are converted to sugar D) They are excreted through sweat E) They are used to make hormones
B)
What is the main treatment for PKU? A) Surgery B) Antibiotics C) A low-protein diet D) Radiation therapy E) Physical therapy
C)
Which foods should be completely avoided by people with PKU? A) Fruits and vegetables B) Meat and fish C) Dairy products D) All carbohydrates E) All fats
B)
How is PKU diagnosed in newborns? A) Blood draw from the arm B) Newborn blood spot screening C) MRI scan D) X-ray E) Urine test
B)
What symptom may occur in untreated PKU? A) Loss of vision B) Hearing loss C) Fairer skin, hair, and eyes than siblings D) Increased appetite E) Chronic cough
C)
What is the prevalence of PKU in the UK? A) 1 in 100 B) 1 in 1,000 C) 1 in 10,000 D) 1 in 100,000 E) 1 in 1,000,000
C)
What is aspartame, and why should people with PKU avoid it? A) A vitamin B) A sweetener C) A mineral D) A preservative E) An antioxidant
B)
What is sapropterin used for in treating PKU? A) To cure PKU B) To treat a mild form of PKU C) To prevent PKU D) To increase protein intake E) To reduce blood sugar levels
B)
How is PKU inherited? A) Through a dominant gene B) Through an X-linked gene C) Through autosomal recessive inheritance D) Through mitochondrial inheritance E) Through a Y-linked gene
C)
Which of the following are symptoms of a brain tumour? A) Headaches B) Fits (seizures) C) Weight gain D) Memory problems E) Dizziness
A,B,D
What are the main treatments for a brain tumour? A) Surgery B) Meditation C) Radiotherapy D) Chemotherapy E) Cryotherapy
A,C,D
What are the grades given to brain tumours based on their severity? A) 1-2 B) 3-4 C) 5-6 D) 7-8 E) 9-10
A,B
What are the types of brain tumours based on their origin? A) Primary B) Secondary C) Tertiary D) Quaternary E) Quinary
A,B
What are some lasting problems that might occur after brain tumour treatment? A) Seizures B) Walking difficulties C) Vision loss D) Speech problems E) Hair loss
A,B,D
What are some side effects that can develop months or years after brain tumour treatment? A) Cataracts B) Epilepsy C) Kidney failure D) Problems with thinking E) Liver disease
A,B,D

What are some recommendations for a healthy lifestyle to lower the risk of stroke after brain tumour treatment? A) Stopping smoking B) Following a healthy diet C) Regular exercise D) Avoiding contact sports E) Drinking plenty of water
A,B,C
What are some organizations that provide information and support for brain tumours? A) The Brain Tumour Charity B) Red Cross C) Brain Tumour Research D) Cancer Research UK E) Macmillan Cancer Support
A,C,E
What are some symptoms that might indicate a brain tumour and warrant a visit to the GP? A) Headaches B) Fits (seizures) C) Regularly feeling sick D) Memory problems E) Fever
A,B,C
What are some treatments used to relieve symptoms like headaches, seizures, and vomiting? A) Medicines B) Acupuncture C) Radiotherapy D) Chemotherapy E) Massage therapy
A,C,D

What is shoulder impingement? A) A condition where the shoulder bone is fractured B) A condition where a tendon in the shoulder rubs or catches on nearby tissue C) A condition where the shoulder muscle is torn D) A condition where the shoulder joint is dislocated E) A condition where the shoulder nerve is pinched
B,C

What is the rotator cuff tendon? A) The bone that supports the shoulder B) The nerve that controls shoulder movement C) The rubbery tissue that connects the muscles around the shoulder joint D) The ligament that stabilizes the shoulder E) The fluid-filled sac in the shoulder
C,D

What are the symptoms of shoulder impingement? A) Pain in the top and outer side of the shoulder B) Pain that's worse when you lift your arm C) Pain or aching at night D) Weakness in your arm E) Stiffness in the shoulder
A,B

What should you do if you have shoulder impingement? A) Avoid activities that involve repeatedly lifting your arm B) Do not stop moving your arm completely C) Gently hold an ice pack on your shoulder D) Take painkillers E) Use a sling to immobilize your arm
A,B
What treatments can be used for shoulder impingement? A) Shoulder exercises B) Steroid injections C) Surgery D) Heat therapy E) Massage therapy
A,B

What is a common cause of shoulder impingement? A) The tendon becoming swollen, thickened or torn B) The fluid-filled sac becoming irritated and inflamed C) The acromion being curved or hooked D) Bony growths on the acromion E) A viral infection
A,B
What type of surgery can be done for shoulder impingement? A) Subacromial decompression B) Shoulder replacement C) Rotator cuff repair D) Bone grafting E) Ligament reconstruction
A,C

What is the subacromial space? A) The space between the shoulder blade and the ribs B) The space at the top of the shoulder where the rotator cuff tendon passes through C) The space between the shoulder and the neck D) The space between the elbow and the wrist E) The space between the hip and the knee
A,B

What can you do to manage shoulder impingement at home? A) Avoid using a sling B) Use heat therapy C) Gently hold an ice pack on your shoulder D) Take anti-inflammatory painkillers E) Stop moving your arm completely
A,C

What should you do if your shoulder pain does not go away after a few weeks? A) See a GP B) Continue with home remedies C) Stop all physical activity D) Apply a heat pack E) Use a sling to immobilize your arm
A,B
What does thalassaemia affect in the blood? A) White blood cells B) Haemoglobin C) Platelets D) Glucose E) Cholesterol
B,C,
Which regions are primarily affected by thalassaemia? A) North America B) Northern Europe C) Mediterranean, south Asian, southeast Asian and Middle Eastern origin D) Australia E) South America
C,
What are the symptoms of anaemia caused by thalassaemia? A) High energy levels B) Severe tiredness, weakness, shortness of breath, palpitations, pale skin C) Increased appetite D) Fever E) Cough
B,
How is thalassaemia caused? A) Bacterial infection B) Faulty genes that affect the production of haemoglobin C) Viral infection D) Environmental factors E) Dietary deficiencies
B,
What are the main treatments for thalassaemia? A) Antibiotics B) Blood transfusions C) Chelation therapy D) Surgery E) Vitamin supplements
B,C,

What is a carrier of thalassaemia? A) Someone who has thalassaemia B) Someone who carries at least 1 of the faulty genes that causes thalassaemia C) Someone who has iron deficiency anaemia D) Someone with high blood pressure E) Someone with diabetes
B,
What is the only possible cure for thalassaemia? A) Antibiotics B) Stem cell or bone marrow transplant C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Physical therapy
B,
What health problems may a thalassaemia carrier experience? A) High blood pressure B) Mild anaemia C) Diabetes D) Heart disease E) Kidney failure
B,

What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)? A) A treatment center for thalassaemia B) A research organization that helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat thalassaemia C) A pharmaceutical company D) A hospital E) A charity
B,
What is the UK Thalassaemia Society (UKTS)? A) A treatment center for thalassaemia B) The main UK charity for people with thalassaemia C) A pharmaceutical company D) A hospital E) A research lab
B,
Which of the following is a medical reason for circumcision in men? A: Phimosis B: Allergies C: Hypertension D: Paraphimosis E: Bleeding
A,D,
What is phimosis? A: A type of skin cancer B: A tight foreskin that won't pull back C: A bacterial infection D: A condition of the heart E: A fungal infection
B,

What is paraphimosis? A: A condition where the foreskin won't retract B: A condition where the foreskin can't be returned to its original position C: A type of cancer D: A viral infection E: A condition of the skin
B,
What is one of the main risks of circumcision? A: Hair loss B: Bleeding C: Diabetes D: Headache E: Skin rash
B,
Which of the following is a treatment option for balanitis? A: Corticosteroid ointment B: Blood transfusion C: Chemotherapy D: Radiotherapy E: Surgery
A,
What type of anesthesia is commonly used for circumcision? A: General anesthetic B: Local anesthetic C: Spinal anesthetic D: Topical anesthetic E: No anesthesia
A,B,C,
How long does it usually take for the penis to heal after circumcision? A: 1 day B: 3 days C: 10 days D: 1 month E: 6 months
C,
What is a possible complication of paraphimosis? A: Headache B: Restricted blood flow to the penis C: Hair loss D: Diabetes E: Skin rash
B,
What is a possible alternative treatment for phimosis? A: Antibiotics B: Topical steroids C: Hair transplant D: Vitamin supplements E: Exercise
B,
Which of the following is a common practice that involves circumcision? A: Hindu rituals B: Christian rituals C: Jewish and Islamic communities D: Buddhist rituals E: Atheist practices
C,
What is the main symptom of cradle cap? A: Red bumps B: Greasy, scaly skin C: Rashes D: Blisters E: Hives
B
Where is cradle cap usually found? A: Arms B: Legs C: Scalp and face D: Back E: Stomach
C
How long does cradle cap usually last? A: 1-2 weeks B: 1-3 months C: 6-12 months D: 1-2 years E: Lifelong
C
What should you not use on a baby's scalp with cradle cap? A: Baby shampoo B: Peanut oil C: Emollient D: Water E: Olive oil
B,E
What is a recommended treatment for cradle cap? A: Massage with an emollient B: Use adult shampoo C: Apply olive oil D: Pick the crusts E: Leave it untreated
A
What can you ask a pharmacist about for cradle cap treatment? A: Peanut oil B: Unperfumed baby shampoos C: Barrier creams D: Adult soap E: Antibiotics
B,C
What should you do if your baby's cradle cap does not improve after treatment? A: Ignore it B: See a GP C: Use olive oil D: Wait another year E: Apply adult shampoo
B
What can bleeding or leaking fluid from cradle cap indicate? A: Normal healing B: Allergic reaction C: Infection D: Improvement E: Nothing serious
C
What should you not do when treating cradle cap? A: Use baby shampoo B: Pick the crusts C: Massage with an emollient D: Apply barrier creams E: See a GP
B
What can a pharmacist help with regarding cradle cap? A: Adult shampoo B: An emollient C: Skin creams D: Antibiotics E: Peanut oil
B,C
What is another name for bile duct cancer? A: Cholangiocarcinoma B: Hepatocarcinoma C: Pancreatocarcinoma D: Gastricarcinoma E: Colonocarcinoma
A
Which of the following are symptoms of bile duct cancer? A: Itching B: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes C: Pale stools D: Dark urine E: Shortness of breath
A,B,C,D
What does not cause bile duct cancer? A: Smoking B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis C: Liver fluke infection D: Drinking coffee E: Old age
D
Which tests can help diagnose bile duct cancer? A: Blood tests B: Ultrasound scan C: CT scan D: MRI scan E: Eye examination
A,B,C,D
What is the first step after noticing symptoms of bile duct cancer? A: Surgery B: Chemotherapy C: Tests and next steps D: Radiotherapy E: Alternative medicine
C
Which of the following is NOT a treatment option for bile duct cancer? A: Surgery B: Chemotherapy C: Radiotherapy D: Aromatherapy E: Clinical trials
D
Where can you get further support for bile duct cancer? A: Local gym B: NHS C: Supermarket D: Library E: Post office
B
Which of the following is a risk factor for bile duct cancer? A: Obesity B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis C: Diabetes D: High cholesterol E: Asthma
B
What is NOT a symptom of bile duct cancer? A: Fever B: Abdominal pain C: Weight gain D: Fatigue E: Loss of appetite
C
Which of the following is NOT a diagnostic tool for bile duct cancer? A: Endoscopy B: Biopsy C: X-ray D: PET scan E: Blood tests
C
What are the main symptoms of Crohn's disease? A) Diarrhoea B) Stomach aches and cramps C) Blood in your poo D) Fever E) Muscle pain
A,B,C

When should you see a GP regarding Crohn's disease? A) If you have blood in your poo B) If you have diarrhoea for more than 7 days C) If you have frequent stomach aches or cramps D) If you have lost weight for no reason E) If you have a sore throat
A,B,D

What are the main treatments for Crohn's disease? A) Medicines to reduce inflammation B) Surgery to remove a part of the digestive system C) Physical therapy D) Medicines to stop the inflammation coming back E) Herbal remedies
A,B,D
Which factors are thought to play a role in causing Crohn's disease? A) Your genes B) A problem with the immune system C) Smoking D) A previous stomach bug E) Consuming spicy food
A,B,C

What can disrupt school, work, and social life for someone with Crohn's disease? A) Unpredictable flare-ups B) Regular check-ups C) Strict dietary restrictions D) Constant need for surgery E) Sleep disturbances
A,B,D
Which health professionals might be involved in the care of someone with Crohn's disease? A) A GP B) A specialist nurse C) A specialist doctor D) A nutritionist E) A psychologist
A,B,C
What is the typical onset age for Crohn's disease symptoms? A) Childhood B) Early adulthood C) Middle age D) Late adulthood E) Infancy
A,B,C
What organizations can provide support for people with Crohn's disease? A) Crohn's & Colitis UK B) The Red Cross C) The National Health Service D) The World Health Organization E) Cancer Research UK
A,C,D
Which of the following is not a confirmed cause of Crohn's disease? A) A particular diet B) Smoking C) A previous stomach bug D) An abnormal balance of gut bacteria E) Your genes
A,C,D

What might happen during a flare-up of Crohn's disease? A) Symptoms may come back B) Symptoms may worsen C) Frequent need for hospitalization D) Need for strict dietary changes E) Symptoms may be constant
A,B,E

What are tendons? A) Tough cords of tissue that connect muscles to bones B) Fluid-filled sacs that cushion joints C) Small bones in the hand D) Cartilage that lines joints E) Muscles that move the fingers
A
Which group of tendons allows you to straighten your fingers and thumb? A) Extensor tendons B) Flexor tendons C) Radial tendons D) Ulnar tendons E) Palmar tendons
A
What is a common symptom if extensor tendons are damaged? A) Inability to bend fingers B) Inability to straighten fingers C) Numbness in fingers D) Tingling in fingers E) Weak grip
B

Which of the following can sometimes treat extensor tendon damage without surgery? A) Medication B) Physical therapy C) A rigid support called a splint D) Ultrasound therapy E) Chiropractic adjustment
C
Which activity can cause flexor tendon pulleys to rupture? A) Swimming B) Rock climbing C) Running D) Cycling E) Walking
B
What is a common cause of tendon damage? A) Cuts B) Falls C) Heart attacks D) Fevers E) Headaches
A
How long can it take for a repaired tendon to regain its previous strength? A) 1 week B) 2 weeks C) 1 month D) 3 months E) 6 months
D
What is used to protect tendons from overuse during recovery? A) A brace B) A hand splint C) A compression bandage D) A cast E) A sling
B
When can light activities be resumed after hand tendon repair surgery? A) 1 week B) 2 weeks C) 6-8 weeks D) 3 months E) 6 months
C
What is a common complication that can develop after tendon repair surgery? A) Allergic reaction B) Infection C) Blood clots D) Stroke E) Heart failure
B
Which parts of the body are most common for stretch marks? A) Tummy, breasts B) Chest, upper arms C) Legs, bottom D) Hips, back E) Neck, shoulders
A), B)
What are the common causes of stretch marks? A) Pregnancy B) Puberty C) Rapid weight loss D) Use of steroid creams E) Smoking
A), D)
Which treatments may help improve the appearance of stretch marks? A) Retinoid creams B) Hyaluronic acid C) Light or laser treatments D) Microdermabrasion E) Herbal supplements
A), C)

What are the symptoms of Cushing's syndrome related to stretch marks? A) More fat on the chest and tummy, but slim arms and legs B) A build-up of fat on the back of the neck and shoulders C) A red, puffy, rounded face D) Extreme tiredness E) Loss of appetite
A), B)

Which groups are more likely to get stretch marks? A) Pregnant women B) Those going through puberty C) Those who lose or gain weight quickly D) Those who are overweight E) Those who exercise regularly
A), C)
What are the colors that stretch marks can be? A) Pink B) Red C) Brown D) Black E) Yellow
A), B)
Which conditions can rarely cause stretch marks? A) Cushing's syndrome B) Diabetes C) High blood pressure D) Anemia E) Flu
A), C)
What are the characteristics of stretch marks? A) Lines or streaks across the skin B) Usually start off darker and fade over time C) Harmful to health D) Cause itching E) Cause pain
A), B)

Which factors may increase the likelihood of getting stretch marks? A) Being female B) Having a family member with stretch marks C) Using some kinds of steroid creams or tablets D) Eating a balanced diet E) Drinking plenty of water
A), B)
What are the recommendations for preventing stretch marks? A) Maintaining a healthy weight B) Using creams and lotions C) Avoiding sudden growth or weight gain D) Regular exercise E) Drinking alcohol
A), C)

What is an aortic valve replacement? A) A procedure to clean the heart B) A type of open heart surgery C) A medication to treat heart failure D) A non-invasive treatment E) A procedure to replace a faulty heart valve
B,E,
Why might an aortic valve need to be replaced? A) The valve has become narrowed B) The valve is leaky C) The valve has a hole D) The valve is too big E) The valve is too small
A,B,
What are the potential complications if aortic valve problems are left untreated? A) Heart failure B) Lung cancer C) Diabetes D) Stroke E) Kidney failure
A,D,

Under what conditions is an aortic valve replacement recommended? A) If you are at risk of serious complications B) If you are too weak for surgery C) If you have a cold D) If medicines are available E) If you are otherwise well enough to have surgery
A,E,

What happens during an aortic valve replacement? A) A large cut is made in your chest B) Your heart is stopped and a heart-lung machine is used C) The damaged valve is removed and replaced D) The procedure is done under local anaesthetic E) You are awake during the operation
A,B,C,
How long does it usually take to recover from an aortic valve replacement? A) A few hours B) A week C) 2 to 3 months D) A few days E) A few weeks
B,C,
What are some of the main risks of an aortic valve replacement? A) Wound infections B) Blood clots C) Strokes D) Temporarily irregular heartbeat E) Reduced kidney function
A,B,C,
What is the risk of dying from an aortic valve replacement? A) 2% B) 5% C) 10% D) 1% E) 0.5%
A,D,

What are some alternatives to an aortic valve replacement? A) Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) B) Aortic valve balloon valvuloplasty C) Sutureless aortic valve replacement D) Heart transplant E) Medications
A,B,C,
How is the aortic valve accessed during the procedure? A) Through a small cut in the arm B) Through a large cut in the chest C) Through the mouth D) Through the leg E) Through the stomach
B,E,

What are the main characteristics of night terrors? A) Scream, shout, thrash about B) Strong feelings of fear C) Mainly affect children D) Happen in the early part of the night E) Involve waking up and remembering the dream

Which of the following are common causes of night terrors and nightmares? A) Being very tired or unwell B) Watching a scary film C) Taking certain medicines D) Needing to pee during the night E) Eating spicy food before bed

What should you do during a night terror? A) Stay calm and wait for the person to calm down B) Try to wake the person C) Talk to the person D) Leave the room E) Do not try to stop them moving about unless there's a risk they could hurt themselves
A),E)

What are the differences between night terrors and nightmares? A) Night terrors mainly affect children B) Nightmares can affect both children and adults C) People remember night terrors D) Nightmares happen later in the night E) Night terrors last up to 15 minutes
What are some conditions that can cause night terrors and nightmares? A) Restless legs syndrome B) Sleep apnoea C) Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) D) Dementia E) Lactose intolerance

What should you do if your child has night terrors several times a night? A) Take them to the emergency room B) See a GP C) Give them sleeping pills D) Wake them up every hour E) Write a letter to their teacher
B)

How can you help someone having night terrors at the same time every night? A) Wake them up 15 minutes before the night terror every night for a week B) Give them a warm bath C) Play loud music D) Turn on bright lights E) Have them watch a scary movie
A)

What are some things you can try to help a child who has night terrors or nightmares? A) Try having a relaxing bedtime routine B) Keep a sleep diary C) Try to deal with things that might be causing stress or anxiety D) Give them caffeine before bed E) Watch TV with them

What is sleep paralysis? A) Being unable to move or speak as you wake up or fall asleep B) Having a nightmare about being paralyzed C) A symptom of night terrors D) A condition caused by eating too much E) A type of sleepwalking
A)

What are some treatments for nightmares in adults? A) Psychological treatment such as counselling B) Physical therapy C) Eating a big meal before bed D) Taking a hot shower E) Managing conditions that affect sleep better
A),E)
What does MRI stand for? A) Magnetic Resonance Imaging B) Medical Radiation Inspection C) Magnetic Radio Inspection D) Medical Radiation Imaging E) Magnetic Reaction Imaging
A,E,
An MRI scan uses which of the following to produce detailed images? A) X-rays B) Strong magnetic fields and radio waves C) Ultrasound waves D) Infrared light E) Gamma rays
B,D,
Which parts of the body can an MRI scan be used to examine? A) Brain and spinal cord B) Bones and joints C) Heart and blood vessels D) Eyes and ears E) Skin and hair
A,B,
During an MRI scan, what do you lie on? A) A flat bed B) A chair C) A hammock D) A stretcher E) A recliner
A,D,
What is the role of a radiographer during an MRI scan? A) Operates the scanner B) Manages the patient's medication C) Performs surgery D) Administers anesthesia E) Cleans the scanner
A,E,
What do you wear to protect your ears during an MRI scan? A) Earplugs B) Headphones C) Ear muffs D) Ear buds E) Ear protectors
A,B,
How long does an MRI scan typically last? A) 15 to 90 minutes B) 5 to 10 minutes C) 1 to 2 hours D) 30 minutes to 1 hour E) 2 to 3 hours
A,D,
What are protons in the body sensitive to? A) Magnetic fields B) Electric fields C) Gravitational fields D) Sound waves E) Light waves
A,E,
What is the most common discomfort associated with an MRI scan? A) Pain B) Nausea C) Claustrophobia D) Headache E) Fatigue
A,C,
What may prevent you from having an MRI scan? A) Metal implant B) Allergies C) High blood pressure D) Diabetes E) Asthma
A,E,
What is the most common type of stammering in early childhood? A) Developmental stammering B) Acquired stammering C) Psychological stammering D) Environmental stammering E) Emotional stammering
A
Which of the following can cause acquired or late-onset stammering? A) Diet B) Exercise C) Head injury D) Reading E) Listening to music
C

What is the main difference between developmental and acquired stammering? A) One is caused by genes, the other by environment B) One affects adults, the other children C) One is more severe than the other D) One is caused by head injury, the other by development issues E) One is rare, the other is common
B
What is the estimated percentage of young children who go through a phase of stammering? A) 1 in 12 B) 1 in 20 C) 1 in 50 D) 1 in 100 E) 1 in 200
A

Which organization provides information and support for people who stammer and parents of stammering children? A) The British Dyslexia Association B) The British Stammering Association C) The National Health Service D) The Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists E) The Mental Health Foundation
B
What is the estimated percentage of adults affected by stammering? A) 1 in 50 B) 1 in 100 C) 1 in 200 D) 1 in 500 E) 1 in 1000
A
What is one of the main causes of developmental stammering? A) Poor parenting B) Genetic factors C) Lack of exercise D) Environmental pollution E) Poor diet
B

What can you do if you are an adult who stammers and it's affecting your social and work life? A) Seek advice from a nutritionist B) Join a gym C) Consult a GP to refer you to a speech and language therapist D) Start a new hobby E) Take a vacation
C

What is the main role of a speech and language therapist (SLT) in treating stammering? A) Prescribing medication B) Providing dietary advice C) Offering exercise routines D) Helping to create an environment where the child feels relaxed and confident about talking E) Providing financial advice
D
What is the estimated ratio of men to women who stammer? A) 1:1 B) 2:1 C) 3:1 D) 3:4 E) 4:1
D
Which part of the foot does Morton's neuroma usually affect? A) The heel B) The arch C) Between the 3rd and 4th toes D) The big toe E) The ankle
C
What is the main symptom of Morton's neuroma? A) Swelling B) Shooting, stabbing, or burning pain C) Blisters D) Bruising E) Redness
B
What can make the symptoms of Morton's neuroma worse? A) Resting B) Wearing loose shoes C) Wearing tight or high-heeled shoes D) Avoiding impact activities E) Massaging the foot
C
What is a recommended self-care treatment for Morton's neuroma? A) Applying heat B) Wearing tight shoes C) Resting and raising the foot D) Soaking in hot water E) Using a heating pad
C
What type of medication can help ease the pain of Morton's neuroma? A) Antibiotics B) Ibuprofen or paracetamol C) Antihistamines D) Steroids E) Antacids
B
When should you see a GP for Morton's neuroma? A) If the pain is severe B) If the pain is mild C) If the pain improves with self-treatment D) If the pain is moderate E) If the pain comes and goes
A
What is a potential cause of Morton's neuroma? A) Wearing wide shoes B) Doing a lot of swimming C) Wearing tight, pointy or high-heeled shoes D) Eating spicy food E) Drinking alcohol
C

What can a foot specialist do to treat Morton's neuroma? A) Prescribe antibiotics B) Provide specially made soft pads or insoles C) Advise to wear high heels D) Recommend drinking more water E) Prescribe antihistamines
B

What is the definition of severe pain according to the NHS guidelines for Morton's neuroma? A) Pain that is annoying but does not stop daily activities B) Pain that is always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk C) Pain that comes and goes D) Pain that makes it hard to concentrate or sleep E) Pain that is very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress
B
What other foot problems can be linked to Morton's neuroma? A) Ingrown toenails B) Athlete's foot C) Flat feet D) Plantar warts E) Fungal infections
C
Which of the following is the primary function of a pacemaker? A: To monitor blood pressure B: To keep the heart beating regularly C: To filter blood D: To deliver medication E: To reduce cholesterol
B,D,
What is the typical weight of a pacemaker? A: 10 to 20g B: 20 to 50g C: 50 to 70g D: 70 to 90g E: 90 to 110g
B,D,
Which type of anaesthesia is usually used during pacemaker implantation? A: General anaesthesia B: Local anaesthesia C: Spinal anaesthesia D: Epidural anaesthesia E: Intravenous sedation
B,D,

What is the main advantage of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD)? A: It delivers a small electrical shock B: It speeds up the heart rate C: It regulates blood sugar levels D: It reboots the heart E: It monitors blood oxygen levels
D,E,
Which of the following is a common heart condition that a pacemaker can help with? A: Bradycardia B: Tachycardia C: Heart block D: Cardiac arrest E: Hypertension
A,C,
How long does the pacemaker implantation procedure usually take? A: 15 minutes B: 30 minutes C: 1 hour D: 2 hours E: 4 hours
C,E,
What is the recommended distance to keep between an induction hob and a pacemaker? A: 15cm B: 30cm C: 60cm D: 90cm E: 120cm
C,E,

Which of the following is a common safety concern with pacemakers? A: Battery overheating B: Pacemaker losing ability to control heartbeat C: Allergic reaction to pacemaker material D: Pacemaker causing high blood pressure E: Pacemaker causing diabetes
B,D,
What is the primary treatment for atrial fibrillation besides a pacemaker? A: Surgery B: Medication C: Catheter ablation D: Radiation therapy E: Chemotherapy
B,C,

What is the new technology being developed for pacemakers? A: Larger pacemakers B: Pacemakers with pacing leads C: Smaller pacemakers about the size of a pill D: Pacemakers with wireless technology E: Pacemakers that can be implanted directly into the heart
C,E,
Which conditions can be treated with lumbar decompression surgery? A: Spinal stenosis B: Slipped disc C: Sciatica D: Metastatic spinal cord compression E: Ankle fracture
A,B,C,D
What procedures might be performed during lumbar decompression surgery? A: Laminectomy B: Discectomy C: Spinal fusion D: Knee replacement E: Hernia repair
A,B,C
Under what type of anesthesia is lumbar decompression surgery usually carried out? A: General anesthetic B: Local anesthetic C: Epidural anesthetic D: Conscious sedation E: No anesthesia
A
How long does lumbar decompression surgery usually take? A: Less than 30 minutes B: About an hour C: Several days D: A few minutes E: More than a week
B
How long does it typically take to recover and leave the hospital after lumbar decompression surgery? A: A few hours B: 1 to 4 days C: A few weeks D: A few months E: Over a year
B
What activities should be avoided for about 6 weeks after lumbar decompression surgery? A: Walking B: Lifting heavy objects C: Sitting D: Sleeping E: Driving for long periods
B,E
What are some potential complications of lumbar decompression surgery? A: Infection B: Blood clot (DVT) C: Pulmonary embolism D: Damage to the spinal nerves or cord E: Hair loss
A,B,C,D
What factors can make lumbar decompression surgery safer? A: Smoking B: Poor general fitness C: Losing weight if needed D: High blood pressure E: Good general fitness
C,E
What components make up the spine? A: Vertebrae B: Discs C: Spinal canal D: Lungs E: Liver
A,B,C
What does the spinal canal contain and protect? A: Spinal cord B: Nerves C: Blood vessels D: Liver E: Spleen
A,B
What is the estimated incidence of Turner syndrome in baby girls? A) 1 in 100 B) 1 in 2,000 C) 1 in 10,000 D) 1 in 1,000 E) 1 in 5,000
How many X sex chromosomes does a girl with Turner syndrome typically have? A) 2 B) 0 C) 1 D) 3 E) 4
When does the chromosome variation in Turner syndrome occur? A) After birth B) During childhood C) When the baby is conceived D) During adolescence E) During early adulthood
When the baby is conceived
What is typically underdeveloped in females with Turner syndrome? A) Brain B) Lungs C) Ovaries D) Liver E) Spleen
Ovaries

Turner syndrome is often diagnosed when a girl fails to show sexual development associated with puberty, usually between what ages? A) 3-7 years B) 8-14 years C) 15-20 years D) 20-25 years E) 25-30 years
8-14 years
What is the main symptom of Turner syndrome related to height? A) Above average height B) Average height C) Shorter than average D) Tallest in class E) Normal height
Shorter than average
What is the impact of Turner syndrome on monthly periods? A) Excessive bleeding B) Irregular periods C) Lack of periods D) Heavy periods E) No impact
Lack of periods
How is life expectancy affected in individuals with Turner syndrome? A) Slightly increased B) Slightly reduced C) No difference D) Significantly increased E) Significantly reduced
Slightly reduced

What service helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat Turner syndrome? A) National Health Service B) National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service C) World Health Organization D) National Institute of Health E) Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service
What can improve life expectancy for individuals with Turner syndrome? A) Regular exercise B) Regular health checks C) Special diet D) Medication E) Surgery
Regular health checks
Which of the following are symptoms of a brain abscess? A) Headache B) Stiff neck C) Blurred vision D) Fatigue E) Paralysis
A,B,E
What are the three main causes of a brain abscess? A) Ear infection B) Head injury C) Diabetes D) Blood clot E) Sinusitis
A,B,E
Which of the following should be treated as a medical emergency? A) Slurred speech B) Muscle weakness C) Seizures D) Fever E) Cough
A,B,C
How can a brain abscess be diagnosed? A) Blood tests B) CT scan C) X-ray D) MRI scan E) Ultrasound
A,B,D
What are the treatments for a brain abscess? A) Antibiotics B) Surgery C) Radiation therapy D) Chemotherapy E) Antifungals
A,B,E
Which of the following are complications of a brain abscess? A) Epilepsy B) Meningitis C) Asthma D) Heart failure E) Brain damage
A,B,E
What should you do if you experience symptoms of a worsening infection? A) Contact your GP B) Call NHS 111 C) Take over-the-counter medication D) Wait it out E) Go to the pharmacy
A,B
Which of these can spread directly into the brain and cause an abscess? A) Ear infection B) Appendicitis C) Food poisoning D) Sinusitis E) Dental abscess
A,D,E
When should you seek immediate medical advice for an abscess? A) If you have a headache B) If you have a fever C) If you have slurred speech D) If you have muscle weakness E) If you have a cough
C,D
What can a brain abscess cause if left untreated? A) Permanent brain damage B) Death C) Flu D) Allergic reaction E) High blood pressure
A,B

What is hirsutism? A) A skin condition characterized by excessive sweating B) Thick, dark hair growth on various body parts in women C) A rare genetic disorder D) A type of hormonal imbalance E) A viral infection
B)
Which hormones are linked to hirsutism? A) Estrogens B) Cortisol C) Androgens D) Insulin E) Melatonin
C)
What is the most common cause of hirsutism? A) PCOS B) Cushing's syndrome C) Acromegaly D) Anabolic steroids E) Genetic mutations
A)
What is a rare cause of hirsutism? A) Menopause B) PCOS C) Anabolic steroids D) Cushing's syndrome E) Diabetes
D)

What type of hair growth is not considered hirsutism? A) Thick, dark hair on the chest B) Lighter, finer hair on the face C) Dark hair on the lower back D) Thick hair on the thighs E) Dark hair on the buttocks
B)
What should you do if you have symptoms of hirsutism? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Apply a topical cream D) Change your diet E) Exercise more
B)
What might a GP do to diagnose hirsutism? A) Perform a skin biopsy B) Check your blood sugar levels C) Measure your hormone levels with a blood test D) Conduct an MRI E) Check for allergies
C)
What is one of the treatments for hirsutism? A) Drinking more water B) Taking a contraceptive pill C) Increasing vitamin intake D) Using a special shampoo E) Applying a topical steroid
B)
Which prescription cream can slow hair growth on your face? A) Hydrocortisone cream B) Eflornithine cream C) Benzoyl peroxide cream D) Retinol cream E) Clotrimazole cream
B)
What is a longer-lasting hair removal treatment for hirsutism? A) Shaving B) Waxing C) Electrolysis D) Plucking E) Bleaching
C)
What is the main symptom of acanthosis nigricans? A) Redness and swelling B) Patches of skin that are darker and thicker than usual C) Intense itching D) Open sores E) Blistering
B)
Where do the patches of acanthosis nigricans commonly appear? A) On the face B) On the hands C) In skin folds, such as the armpits, neck or groin D) On the feet E) On the scalp
C)
What is the most common cause of acanthosis nigricans? A) Type 1 diabetes B) Allergic reactions C) Obesity D) Sun exposure E) Infectious diseases
C)
What should you do if you have new dark patches on your skin? A) Ignore them B) Apply creams C) See a GP D) Drink more water E) Take over-the-counter medication
C)
What kind of specialist may be able to suggest treatments to improve the appearance of acanthosis nigricans patches? A) Cardiologist B) Dermatologist C) Optometrist D) Dentist E) Podiatrist
B)
Which type of cancer can rarely be associated with acanthosis nigricans? A) Lung cancer B) Brain cancer C) Skin cancer D) Stomach cancer E) Bone cancer
D)
What is one of the hormone-related conditions that can cause acanthosis nigricans? A) Polycystic ovary syndrome B) Asthma C) Hypertension D) Arthritis E) Migraine
A)
How do the patches of acanthosis nigricans typically feel? A) Rough B) Wet C) Velvet-like D) Scaly E) Burning
C)
What is one of the rare causes of acanthosis nigricans? A) Faulty gene inherited from your parents B) Common cold C) Flu D) Allergies E) Food poisoning
A)
What is one of the treatments a GP might recommend for acanthosis nigricans? A) Surgery B) Medicine to balance your hormones C) Physical therapy D) Chemotherapy E) Radiation therapy
B)
What is the medical term for the lining of the womb? A) Endometrium B) Ovary C) Fallopian tube D) Cervix E) Uterine wall
Which of the following is a common location for womb cancer to start? A) Ovaries B) Endometrium C) Fallopian tubes D) Bladder E) Liver
Womb cancer is also known as what? A) Endometrial cancer B) Ovarian cancer C) Cervical cancer D) Breast cancer E) Lung cancer
Which group is most commonly affected by womb cancer? A) Women who've been through menopause B) Men C) Young children D) Teenagers E) Elderly men
What is the function of the womb during pregnancy? A) It produces hormones B) It grows a baby C) It transports eggs D) It filters blood E) It stores fat
How can the seriousness of womb cancer be determined? A) By its size B) By whether it has spread C) By general health D) By age E) By blood type
Why is it important to check symptoms of womb cancer early? A) It makes it easier to treat B) It reduces hospital visits C) It prevents other illnesses D) It increases lifespan E) It saves money
What is another name for the womb? A) Uterus B) Endometrium C) Ovary D) Cervix E) Fallopian tube
Who can get womb cancer? A) Anyone with a womb B) Only women C) Only men D) Only children E) Only adults
When was the information on womb cancer last reviewed by the NHS? A) October 2021 B) October 2024 C) October 2020 D) October 2022 E) October 2023

What is hydronephrosis? A) A condition where the lungs become stretched and swollen B) A condition where the kidneys become stretched and swollen C) A condition where the liver becomes stretched and swollen D) A condition where the stomach becomes stretched and swollen E) A condition where the heart becomes stretched and swollen
B
What can be spotted in unborn babies during routine pregnancy ultrasound scans? A) Kidney stones B) Heart disease C) Hydronephrosis D) Liver failure E) Brain tumor
C
What can increase your chances of getting urinary tract infections (UTIs)? A) Hydronephrosis B) Appendicitis C) Diabetes D) Asthma E) Arthritis
A
What can happen in severe cases of hydronephrosis that are left untreated? A) Stomach ulcers B) Kidney failure C) Lung cancer D) Heart attack E) Stroke
B
What is antenatal hydronephrosis (ANH) often diagnosed with? A) MRI B) X-ray C) Ultrasound scan D) CT scan E) Blood test
C
What symptoms may indicate hydronephrosis in children and adults? A) Fever B) Back or side pain C) Symptoms of a UTI D) Blood in urine E) Weak urine stream
B,C,D,E
What is a common cause of hydronephrosis in adults? A) Kidney stones B) Pregnancy C) Enlarged prostate gland D) Narrowing of the ureters E) Some types of cancer
A,B,C,D,E
What is often the first stage of treatment for hydronephrosis in adults? A) Surgery B) Draining the urine using a catheter C) Medication D) Physical therapy E) Laser therapy
B
How might kidney stones be treated in cases of hydronephrosis? A) Using sound waves to break them up B) Physical therapy C) Dietary changes D) Meditation E) Psychotherapy
A
What might be used to treat cancer causing hydronephrosis? A) Chemotherapy B) Radiotherapy C) Surgery D) Acupuncture E) Massage therapy
A,B,C
What is a stroke? A) When blood stops flowing to a part of your brain B) A sudden pain in the stomach C) A heart attack D) A severe headache E) A broken bone
A
What can a stroke affect? A) Speech B) Movement C) Both speech and movement D) Vision only E) Hearing only
C
How long can it take to recover from a stroke? A) A few minutes B) A few hours C) A long time D) A few days E) A few weeks
C
Why does a stroke need urgent medical help? A) It can be life-threatening B) It can cause a rash C) It can cause a fever D) It can cause nausea E) It can cause dizziness
A
Where should a person seek help if they have a stroke? A) At home B) At a pharmacy C) At a shopping mall D) In hospital E) At a friend's house
D

What does a stroke involve? A) Blood stops flowing to a part of your brain B) Blood is flowing too fast C) Blood is clotting in the veins D) Blood is leaking from the lungs E) Blood is pooling in the legs
A
What can be the result of a stroke? A) It can affect speech B) It can affect movement C) It can be life-threatening D) All of the above E) None of the above
D
What is not a symptom of a stroke? A) Sudden numbness B) Difficulty speaking C) Blurred vision D) Fever E) Headache
D
What is the primary reason for seeking immediate medical attention for a stroke? A) To prevent a rash B) To prevent fever C) It can be life-threatening D) To prevent nausea E) To prevent dizziness
C
What is the correct place to seek treatment for a stroke? A) At a pharmacy B) At a shopping mall C) At a friend's house D) In hospital E) At home
D

Which of the following are symptoms of vascular dementia? A) Slowness of thought B) Difficulty with planning and understanding C) Problems with concentration D) Changes to your mood, personality or behaviour E) Increased appetite
A,B,C,D
What are some of the conditions related to vascular dementia? A) Strokes B) High blood pressure C) Diabetes D) Liver disease E) Transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs)
A,B,C,E
Which tests are used to diagnose vascular dementia? A) MRI scan B) CT scan C) Blood test D) Assessment of symptoms E) Assessment of mental abilities
A,B,D,E

What treatments can help slow down vascular dementia? A) Eating a healthy, balanced diet B) Losing weight if overweight C) Stopping smoking D) Taking medicines to lower cholesterol E) Increasing salt intake
A,B,C,D
What are some of the underlying causes of vascular dementia? A) Narrowing and blockage of small blood vessels B) A single stroke C) Multiple mini strokes (TIAs) D) Brain tumors E) High blood pressure
A,B,C,E
Which of the following lifestyle factors are linked to vascular dementia? A) Smoking B) Being overweight C) Regular exercise D) High sugar intake E) High blood pressure
A,B,E
Which professionals or services can provide support for people with vascular dementia? A) NHS B) Social services C) Voluntary organizations D) Dentists E) Nursing homes
A,B,C,E

What are some of the ways to reduce the impact of existing problems in vascular dementia? A) Physiotherapy B) Occupational therapy C) Dementia activities D) Increasing caffeine intake E) Psychological therapies
A,B,C,E
What are the typical progressions of vascular dementia? A) Worsening over time B) Sudden steps of decline C) Periods with no change D) Gradual improvement E) Immediate recovery
A,B,C
What kind of help might be needed for someone with vascular dementia? A) Home-based help B) Care in a nursing home C) Regular physical therapy D) Increased social media use E) Seasonal vaccinations
A,B,C
What are the main symptoms of chickenpox? A) Fever B) Flu-like symptoms C) Itchy, spotty rash D) Loss of appetite E) Sneezing
A,C,D
How long does it usually take for chickenpox to resolve without seeing a GP? A) 1 week B) 1 to 2 weeks C) 3 weeks D) 1 month E) 2 months
A,B,C
Where can chickenpox spots appear on the body? A) Inside the mouth B) Around the genitals C) On the face D) Around the eyes E) On the feet
A,B,C

What are the characteristics of chickenpox spots in stage 1? A) They can be painful B) They can spread or stay in a small area C) They can be red, pink, darker or the same colour as the surrounding skin D) They can be harder to see on brown and black skin E) They can be larger than 1cm
A,B,C
What happens to the spots in stage 2 of chickenpox? A) They fill with fluid and become blisters B) They become scabs C) They are very itchy D) They may burst E) They become flat
A,C,D

What happens in stage 3 of chickenpox? A) The spots form a scab B) Some scabs are flaky while others leak fluid C) The spots become blisters D) The spots disappear completely E) The spots become larger
A,B,C
What are the other symptoms that may appear before or after the chickenpox rash? A) High temperature B) Aches and pains C) Loss of appetite D) Coughing E) Difficulty breathing
A,B,C

How long should you stay away from school or work if you have chickenpox? A) Until all the spots have formed a scab B) 1 week after the spots appeared C) 3 days after the spots appeared D) Until the spots disappear completely E) 2 weeks after the spots appeared
A,B,C
What should you do if you're not sure it's chickenpox? A) Speak to a GP B) Take ibuprofen C) Go near newborn babies D) Scratch the spots E) Bathe in cool water
A,D,E

What should you do if you have chickenpox and are concerned about your child? A) Speak to a GP B) Give aspirin to children under 16 C) Use cooling creams or gels D) Go near pregnant individuals E) Cut your child's fingernails
A,C,E
What is Hirschsprung's disease? A) A rare condition that causes poo to become stuck in the bowels B) A condition that affects the kidneys C) A skin condition D) A lung disease E) A heart condition
A
What is the primary symptom of Hirschsprung's disease in babies? A) Difficulty breathing B) Failing to pass meconium within 48 hours C) Seizures D) Fever E) Cough
B
What is one of the signs of Hirschsprung's disease in older infants and children? A) A swollen belly B) Blurred vision C) Ear pain D) Rash E) Dizziness
A
How is Hirschsprung's disease diagnosed? A) Blood test B) X-ray C) Ultrasound D) MRI E) ECG
B

What is the primary cause of Hirschsprung's disease? A) Ganglion cells missing from a section at the end of the bowel B) Bacterial infection C) Viral infection D) Allergic reaction E) Genetic mutation affecting the heart
A
What is the most common treatment for Hirschsprung's disease? A) Physical therapy B) Medication only C) Surgery D) Dietary changes E) Chemotherapy
C

What is the 'pull-through' operation in Hirschsprung's disease? A) A procedure to remove the affected section of bowel and join the healthy sections B) A procedure to insert a stent C) A procedure to remove the appendix D) A procedure to repair a hernia E) A procedure to replace a valve
A
What is one of the risks of surgery for Hirschsprung's disease? A) Bleeding during or after the operation B) Loss of hearing C) Vision loss D) Heart failure E) Liver failure
A
What is a common issue children may face after surgery for Hirschsprung's disease? A) Persistent constipation B) High blood pressure C) Asthma D) Diabetes E) Arthritis
A

When should you seek immediate medical attention for a child with symptoms of Hirschsprung's disease? A) If they have a high temperature of 38C or more B) If they have a headache C) If they have a runny nose D) If they have a sore throat E) If they have muscle pain
A
What are topical corticosteroids primarily used for? A) To increase muscle mass B) To reduce inflammation and irritation C) To treat diabetes D) To improve vision E) To cure acne
B)
Which of the following is a very potent topical corticosteroid? A) Clobetasone B) Hydrocortisone C) Clobetasol D) Betamethasone E) Fluticasone
C)
What condition is topical corticosteroids commonly used to treat? A) Rosacea B) Psoriasis C) Asthma D) High blood pressure E) Anemia
B)
How many different strengths (potencies) of topical corticosteroids are available? A) 2 B) 3 C) 4 D) 5 E) 6
C)
Which part of the body requires 2.5 FTUs of topical corticosteroids for a single dose in adults? A) Genitals B) Face and neck C) Hands D) Scalp E) Chest
B)
What is the most common side effect of topical corticosteroids? A) Headache B) Nausea C) Burning or stinging sensation D) Dizziness E) Fever
C)
Which condition should not be treated with topical corticosteroids unless advised by a doctor? A) Eczema B) Psoriasis C) Infected skin D) Dermatitis E) Allergies
C)
What is the recommended time interval between using topical corticosteroids and emollients? A) 5-10 minutes B) 10-15 minutes C) 15-20 minutes D) 20-30 minutes E) 30-40 minutes
D)
Which of the following is NOT a form of topical corticosteroids? A) Creams B) Ointments C) Injections D) Lotions E) Mousses
C)

What is a fingertip unit (FTU) of topical corticosteroids? A) The amount needed to cover the entire hand B) The amount needed to cover the entire arm C) The amount needed to squeeze a line from the tip of an adult finger to the first crease of the finger D) The amount needed to cover the entire leg E) The amount needed to cover the entire back
C)

What is radiotherapy used for? A) To cure the cancer completely B) To make other treatments more effective C) To reduce the risk of the cancer coming back after surgery D) To relieve symptoms if a cure is not possible E) To increase muscle mass
A,B,C,D

Which of the following are types of radiotherapy? A) External radiotherapy B) Radiotherapy implants (brachytherapy) C) Radiotherapy injections, capsules or drinks (radioisotope therapy) D) Intrabeam radiotherapy E) Laser therapy
A,B,C,D
What are some common side effects of radiotherapy? A) Sore skin B) Feeling tired C) Hair loss D) Feeling sick E) Increased appetite
A,B,C,D

What happens after external radiotherapy? A) You usually go home soon after B) You need to stay in hospital for a few days C) You become radioactive D) You need to avoid close contact with other people E) You need to drink a lot of water
A

What might happen if you have radiotherapy implants or injections? A) You might need to stay in hospital for a few days B) You might need to avoid close contact with other people C) The radiation stays in your body for a few days D) You might need to avoid close contact with children and pregnant women E) You might need to wear a special suit
A,B,C,D
Which of the following is not a stage when radiotherapy is used? A) Early stages of cancer B) After it has started to spread C) Before surgery D) After surgery E) Only after chemotherapy
E

What is neo-adjuvant radiotherapy? A) Radiotherapy used before surgery B) Radiotherapy used after surgery C) Radiotherapy used to cure the cancer completely D) Radiotherapy used to relieve symptoms E) Radiotherapy used to increase blood flow
A

What is adjuvant radiotherapy? A) Radiotherapy used before surgery B) Radiotherapy used after surgery C) Radiotherapy used to cure the cancer completely D) Radiotherapy used to relieve symptoms E) Radiotherapy used to improve vision
B

What is palliative radiotherapy? A) Radiotherapy used to cure the cancer completely B) Radiotherapy used to make other treatments more effective C) Radiotherapy used to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back after surgery D) Radiotherapy used to relieve symptoms if a cure is not possible E) Radiotherapy used to improve hearing
D

What is intrabeam radiotherapy? A) Radiotherapy delivered directly at the tumour during breast cancer surgery B) Radiotherapy used to cure the cancer completely C) Radiotherapy used to make other treatments more effective D) Radiotherapy used to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back after surgery E) Radiotherapy used to improve lung function
A
Which are symptoms of dry eyes? A) Itchy B) Gritty C) Swollen D) Yellowish E) Blurry
A,B,E

What can increase the likelihood of getting dry eyes? A) Wearing contact lenses B) Drinking coffee C) Looking at computer screens D) Being under the age of 50 E) Spending time in air-conditioned environments
A,C,E
What are some conditions associated with dry eyes? A) Blepharitis B) Flu C) Sjögren's syndrome D) Diabetes E) Lupus
A,C,E
What are some self-care methods for treating dry eyes? A) Cleaning eyelids every day B) Taking breaks from computer screens C) Wearing sunglasses D) Using a humidifier E) Stopping prescribed medicine
A,B,D
What should you avoid doing if you have dry eyes? A) Smoking B) Drinking alcohol C) Spending time in smoky places D) Stopping prescribed medicine without advice E) Using contact lenses
A,B,C
Where can you seek help for dry eyes? A) A pharmacist B) A dentist C) An optician or GP D) A physiotherapist E) An eye specialist
A,C,E

When should you seek urgent medical help for dry eyes? A) If your eye is painful and red B) If you have a red eye and wear contact lenses C) If you have a red eye, severe headache, and feel sick D) If you have a mild headache E) If you have a slight change in vision
A,B,C
What immediate action should you take if you have changes to your sight? A) Drive to A&E B) Call 999 or go to A&E C) Wait for symptoms to pass D) Take painkillers E) Call a friend
B
What can dry eyes be caused by? A) Not making enough tears B) Tears drying up quickly C) Excessive blinking D) Too much sleep E) Allergies
A,B
What should you do if dry eyes persist after home treatments? A) Stop all treatments B) Wait for a few more weeks C) See an optician or GP D) Change your diet E) Use stronger eye drops
C
What are the common causes of broken or bruised ribs? A) A severe cough B) A fall C) A blow to the chest D) Fatigue E) A minor scratch
A,B,C
Which of the following are symptoms of broken or bruised ribs? A) Strong pain in the chest area B) Swelling or tenderness around the affected ribs C) Feeling or hearing a crack D) Headache E) Nausea
A,B,C

What should you do to treat broken or bruised ribs yourself? A) Use painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen gel B) Hold an ice pack to the affected ribs C) Breathe normally and cough when needed D) Sleep more upright for the first few nights E) Drink plenty of alcohol
A,B,C,D

What should you avoid doing if you have broken or bruised ribs? A) Lie down or stay still for a long time B) Strain yourself or lift heavy objects C) Play sports or do any exercise that makes your pain worse D) Smoke E) Eat a lot of junk food
A,B,C,D

When should you seek urgent GP advice for a broken or bruised rib? A) If your pain has not improved within a few weeks B) If you're coughing up yellow or green mucus C) If you have a very high temperature or feel hot and shivery D) If you have a mild headache E) If you feel slightly tired
A,B,C

When should you call 999 or go to A&E for a broken or bruised rib? A) If your injury was caused by a serious accident B) If you have shortness of breath that's getting worse C) If the chest pain is getting worse D) If you have pain in your tummy or shoulder E) If you have a minor cut
A,B,C,D

What can you do to help ease pain from broken or bruised ribs? A) Hold a pillow against your chest if you need to cough B) Walk around and move your shoulders C) Regularly take slow, deep breaths D) Try to sleep more upright for the first few nights E) Watch TV for long hours
A,B,C,D

What should you not do if you have broken or bruised ribs? A) Lie down or stay still for a long time B) Strain yourself or lift heavy objects C) Play sports or do any exercise that makes your pain worse D) Smoke E) Take a hot bath
A,B,C,D

What are some actions you can take to help heal broken or bruised ribs? A) Use painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen gel B) Hold an ice pack to the affected ribs C) Breathe normally and cough when needed D) Sleep more upright for the first few nights E) Eat a lot of spicy food
A,B,C,D

What should you do if you have a broken or bruised rib and your pain has not improved within a few weeks? A) Ask for an urgent GP appointment B) Get help from NHS 111 C) Take a nap D) Go for a run E) Drink more water
A,B
What does hypnotherapy use to try to treat conditions or change habits? A) Medication B) Surgery C) Hypnosis D) Electroshock therapy E) Massage
C

What is the first step in a hypnotherapy session? A) Leading into a deeply relaxed state B) Discussing goals and methods C) Suggesting not to carry out a habit D) Bringing out of the trance-like state E) Taking medication
B

What does a hypnotherapist do after discussing goals and methods? A) Lead you into a deeply relaxed state B) Use shock therapy C) Prescribe medication D) Perform physical therapy E) Conduct a general check-up
A
How do you feel after being brought out of the hypnotic state? A) Tired B) Confused C) Refreshed and relaxed D) Hungry E) Anxious
C
What should you do if you have psychosis or certain types of personality disorder? A) Use hypnotherapy B) Avoid hypnotherapy C) Increase medication D) Consult a GP E) Self-medicate
B,D
Is hypnotherapy usually available on the NHS? A) Yes B) No C) Only for emergencies D) Only for children E) Only for adults
B
Who do you ask to find out if you can see a hypnotherapist on the NHS in your area? A) A GP B) Your local integrated care board (ICB) C) A pharmacist D) A dentist E) A nutritionist
A,B

What should you do when looking for a private hypnotherapist? A) Choose someone with a healthcare background B) Choose someone with little training C) Choose someone who is not a health professional D) Choose someone registered with an accredited organization E) Choose someone based on cost alone
A,D
What is the cost range of a private hypnotherapy session? A) £10-£20 B) £20-£30 C) £30-£40 D) £40-£50 E) £50 upwards
E
When using hypnotherapy, are you fully in control? A) Yes B) No C) Only if the therapist allows it D) Only if you are medicated E) Only if you are hypnotized
A
What are warts and verrucas? A) Small lumps on the skin that most people have B) Large tumors on the skin C) Dark spots on the skin D) Bumps that are always painful E) Hard bumps under the skin
A,E
Where can warts appear on the body? A) On the palms B) On the knuckles C) On the elbows D) On the fingers E) On the toes
A,B
What color are warts usually? A) Red B) Blue C) Skin colored D) Black E) Yellow
C,E
What are the characteristics of verrucas? A) They have tiny black dots B) They are always on the hands C) They are painless D) They are found on the feet E) They are always large
A,D
What are plane warts? A) Round and yellow B) Dark and flat C) Small and painful D) Large and itchy E) Round, flat and can be yellow
A,E
Where are mosaic warts common? A) On the face B) On the feet C) On the hands D) On the back E) On the neck
B,C
What can warts and verrucas be treated with? A) Creams B) Plasters C) Sprays D) Injections E) Pills
A,B
How long can treatments for warts and verrucas take? A) 1 week B) 3 months C) 1 year D) 2 days E) 6 months
B,E
Who can you see for advice on treating warts and verrucas? A) A pharmacist B) A dentist C) A nurse D) A teacher E) A podiatrist
A,E
How can you stop warts and verrucas from spreading? A) Wash your hands B) Share towels C) Walk barefoot in public D) Cover warts with a plaster E) Scratch the warts
A,D
What time of the night does sleepwalking typically occur? A) Early morning B) Late morning C) Early part of the night D) Afternoon E) Evening
C)
What is the frequency of sleepwalking in children? A) 1 in 2 children B) 1 in 3 children C) 1 in 5 children D) 1 in 10 children E) 1 in 20 children
C)
What are some triggers for sleepwalking? A) Drinking water B) Exercising C) Not getting enough sleep D) Eating vegetables E) Watching TV
C)
What medications can worsen sleepwalking? A) Vitamins B) Antibiotics C) Certain types of medicine D) Painkillers E) Vitamin D
C)
What can happen during a sleepwalking episode? A) Sleeping more deeply B) Waking up suddenly C) Carrying out complex activities D) Falling asleep instantly E) Talking in sleep
C)
What should you do if you find someone sleepwalking? A) Shout at them B) Physically restrain them C) Guide them back to bed D) Leave them alone E) Wake them up abruptly
C)
When should you seek medical advice for sleepwalking? A) If it happens once B) If it happens frequently C) If it happens during the day D) If it happens while awake E) If it happens to adults only
B)
What is a common treatment for sleepwalking? A) Exercising before bed B) Drinking coffee C) Having a regular sleep routine D) Eating a heavy meal E) Watching TV
C)
What medicines are sometimes used to treat frequent sleepwalking? A) Painkillers B) Antibiotics C) Benzodiazepines D) Vitamins E) Cough syrup
C)
What therapies may be helpful for sleepwalking? A) Physical therapy B) Occupational therapy C) Cognitive behavioural therapy D) Speech therapy E) Music therapy
C)
What are the common symptoms of cervical spondylosis? A) Neck and shoulder pain or stiffness B) Headaches starting at the back of the neck C) Constant fever D) Chest pain E) Sudden weight loss
A,B,
What can you do to ease symptoms of cervical spondylosis? A) Try gentle neck exercises B) Improve your posture C) Take painkillers D) Avoid all physical activity E) Consume excessive alcohol
A,B,C,

When should you seek urgent medical attention for cervical spondylosis? A) Pain that's getting much worse B) Heaviness or weakness in your arms or legs C) Pins and needles in an arm D) Neck pain that is worse when you move E) Slight discomfort in the neck
A,B,D,

What are the signs that you should call 999 for cervical spondylosis? A) New problems walking B) Loss of bladder or bowel control C) Sudden lack of co-ordination D) Mild headache E) Temporary vision loss
A,B,C,
What might a GP do during an appointment for cervical spondylosis? A) Examine your neck and shoulder B) Test your reflexes C) Watch you walk D) Order blood tests E) Perform surgery
A,B,C,

What treatments might a GP recommend for cervical spondylosis? A) More exercises B) Prescribe a muscle relaxant C) Surgery if a nerve is being pinched D) Complete bed rest E) Alternative therapies like acupuncture
A,B,C,
What might a GP recommend if your symptoms do not improve in a few weeks? A) Physiotherapy B) A course of antibiotics C) A strict diet D) Surgery for all cases E) Complete isolation
A,
What are some causes of cervical spondylosis? A) Ageing B) Previous neck injury C) Family history of the condition D) Excessive exercise E) Poor diet
A,B,C,
What can a pharmacist do for cervical spondylosis? A) Recommend stronger painkillers B) Perform surgery C) Diagnose the condition D) Prescribe antibiotics E) Provide counseling services
A,

What are some urgent symptoms that require immediate medical attention for cervical spondylosis? A) Pain between your shoulder blades B) A stiff neck C) Poor balance D) Sudden weight gain E) Mild skin rash
A,B,C,
Which of the following are symptoms of pulmonary hypertension? A) Shortness of breath B) Tiredness C) Headache D) Chest pain (angina) E) Swelling in the legs
A,B,D

What are some possible causes of pulmonary hypertension? A) Conditions affecting the left side of the heart B) Lung diseases C) Blood clots D) High cholesterol E) Various conditions affecting the pulmonary arteries
A,B,E
Which tests might be used to diagnose pulmonary hypertension? A) Echocardiogram B) Right heart catheterisation C) Blood test D) X-ray E) MRI
A,B,E
What are some treatments for pulmonary hypertension? A) Anticoagulant medicines B) Diuretics C) Exercise D) Home oxygen therapy E) Medicines to widen blood vessels
A,B,E
What are some advanced symptoms of pulmonary hypertension? A) Racing heartbeat B) Fever C) Swelling in the ankles D) Feeling faint E) Chest pain
A,C,D
What are some complications of pulmonary hypertension? A) Heart failure B) Liver failure C) Kidney failure D) Stroke E) Swelling in the legs
A,D,E

What can the right side of the heart do if it has to work harder due to pulmonary hypertension? A) Gradually become stronger B) Gradually become weaker C) Increase in size D) Decrease in size E) Stop functioning
B,C,E
What should you do if you experience sudden chest pain that does not stop after a few minutes? A) Call a doctor B) Take painkillers C) Call 999 or go to A&E D) Wait and see E) Take a nap
A,C,D
What factors can affect the outlook for pulmonary hypertension? A) How quickly it's diagnosed B) How advanced the symptoms are C) Whether you have another underlying health condition D) Age E) Gender
A,B,C

What can be a sign of another condition such as a blood clot in your lungs or a serious heart problem? A) Chest pain B) Heart palpitations with chest pain C) Shortness of breath D) Feeling faint E) Tiredness
A,B,C
What is the most common symptom of roseola before a rash appears? A) Itchy skin B) Sudden high temperature C) Abdominal pain D) Diarrhea E) Vomiting
B
How long do the initial symptoms of roseola usually last before the rash appears? A) 1-2 days B) 3-5 days C) 5-7 days D) 7-10 days E) More than 10 days
B
What does the rash in roseola typically look like? A) Small red spots B) Pinkish-red spots, patches or bumps C) Large purple blotches D) Yellowish spots E) White patches
B
Where does the rash in roseola usually start? A) On the face B) On the chest, tummy and back C) On the legs D) On the arms E) On the feet
B
How long does the rash in roseola typically last? A) Less than 1 day B) 1-2 days C) 2-3 days D) 3-4 days E) More than 4 days
B

What should you do if your child has a high temperature due to roseola? A) Cover them in warm clothes B) Give them aspirin C) Give them children's paracetamol D) Take them to the hospital immediately E) Keep them in a hot room
C

When is roseola thought to be most contagious? A) When the rash appears B) When the child has a high temperature C) After the rash disappears D) Before any symptoms appear E) When the child has cold-like symptoms
B
What should you do if your child under 3 months old has a temperature of 38C or higher? A) Wait and observe B) Give them aspirin C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Keep them at home E) Do nothing
C

What is a serious sign that requires immediate action if a baby or young child has it? A) A mild cough B) A rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it C) A slight fever D) Slight dehydration E) Mild rash
B

What is a recommended action if a child has a high temperature that does not come down with paracetamol or ibuprofen? A) Give them more blankets B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Wait for it to pass D) Take them to the gym E) Give them aspirin
B
What is the main symptom of myositis? A) High fever B) Muscle weakness C) Severe headache D) Abdominal pain E) Blurred vision
B

What are the common types of myositis? A) Osteomyositis and Fibromyositis B) Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis C) Myelomyositis and Neuromyositis D) Cardiomyositis and Gastroenteromyositis E) Retromyositis and Endomyositis
B
Which of the following is a symptom of myositis? A) Severe itching B) Patchy, red rash C) Swollen glands D) Loss of smell E) Double vision
B
What does a GP do if they think you have myositis? A) Perform an X-ray B) Do a blood test C) Prescribe antibiotics D) Schedule an ultrasound E) Refer to a nutritionist
B
What kind of tests might a specialist perform for myositis? A) Lumbar puncture B) Blood tests C) MRI scan D) EMG scan E) Biopsy
B,C,D,E
What is the possible cause of myositis? A) Bacterial infection B) Viral infection C) Autoimmune condition D) Trauma E) Hormonal imbalance
C
What is included in the treatment for myositis? A) Surgery B) Steroids C) Physiotherapy D) Antibiotics E) Chemotherapy
B,C

What therapy may be offered if you have difficulties swallowing or communicating due to myositis? A) Physical therapy B) Speech and language therapy C) Occupational therapy D) Massage therapy E) Chiropractic therapy
B

Which of the following is a symptom of myositis that can affect daily activities? A) Difficulty breathing B) Difficulty getting up from a chair C) Difficulty seeing D) Difficulty hearing E) Difficulty chewing
B
What additional treatment might be offered if myositis gets worse? A) Radiation therapy B) Immunoglobulin therapy C) Acupuncture D) Hormone therapy E) Dialysis
B
What is the recommended treatment for itchy skin? A) Scratching B) Using a damp towel C) Using perfumed soaps D) Taking hot showers E) Wearing synthetic fabrics
B)

What should you avoid when you have itchy skin? A) Patting the skin B) Using unperfumed moisturizer C) Wearing loose cotton clothing D) Spending a long time in the bath E) Using a laundry liquid for sensitive skin
D)
What can a pharmacist recommend for itchy skin? A) Hot compresses B) Antihistamines C) Strong perfumes D) Tight clothing E) Scratching the skin
B)

When should you see a GP for itchy skin? A) If it improves with self care B) If it is mild and infrequent C) If it is all over your body D) If it is caused by a known allergy E) If it is not bothering you
C)
What might a GP prescribe for itchy skin? A) Hot baths B) Creams, lotions or tablets C) Scratching D) Perfumed soaps E) Synthetic clothing
B)
What is a possible cause of itchy skin? A) Excessive exercise B) Caffeine consumption C) Common skin conditions D) Staying indoors E) Eating sugary foods
C)
What is a less common but serious condition that can cause itchy skin? A) Common cold B) Flu C) Thyroid, liver or kidney problems D) Headaches E) Muscle aches
C)
What should you do if you have itchy skin during pregnancy? A) Ignore it B) Consult a GP or midwife C) Scratch more D) Use hot water to soothe E) Wear tight clothing
B)
What skin condition can cause itchy skin? A) Bruises B) Eczema C) Sunburn D) Frostbite E) Stretch marks
B)
What is the recommended way to handle itchy skin? A) Scratching it B) Patting or tapping the skin C) Rubbing it with a wool cloth D) Using perfumed deodorants E) Wearing synthetic fabrics
B)
What is the main symptom of pericarditis? A) Shortness of breath B) Chest pain C) Headache D) Nausea E) Dizziness
B)
How does the chest pain of pericarditis usually feel? A) Dull and aching B) Sharp or stabbing C) Burning D) Pins and needles E) Throbbing
B)

What should you do if you have chest pain that gets worse when you take a deep breath in? A) Ignore it B) Take over-the-counter medication C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Call an ambulance E) Go to sleep
C)
What is the most common cause of pericarditis? A) Bacterial infection B) Viral infection C) Fungal infection D) Trauma E) Allergic reaction
B)
What is the fluid-filled sac around the heart called? A) Pericardium B) Endocardium C) Epicardium D) Myocardium E) Pleura
A)
What kind of painkillers are often given to treat pericarditis? A) Acetaminophen B) Anti-inflammatory painkillers C) Opioids D) Muscle relaxants E) Antihistamines
B)
What should you do if you have sudden chest pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck, or jaw? A) Call 999 B) Wait and see C) Take a nap D) Drink water E) Exercise
A)
What test can a GP use to confirm pericarditis? A) Blood tests B) Chest X-ray C) Electrocardiogram (ECG) D) Echocardiogram E) All of the above
E)
What medication can be prescribed if anti-inflammatory painkillers do not work for pericarditis? A) Colchicine B) Antidepressants C) Diuretics D) Antacids E) Beta-blockers
A)

What should you do if you have chest pain that gets worse when you lie down on your left side? A) Ignore it B) Take a hot shower C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Listen to music E) Go for a walk
C)
What is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)? A) A lung infection B) A condition where lungs become scarred C) A type of asthma D) A genetic disorder E) A heart condition
B
What are the symptoms of IPF? A) High fever B) Shortness of breath C) Persistent dry cough D) Loss of appetite and weight loss E) Nausea
B,C,D
What tests can be performed to diagnose IPF? A) Eye exam B) Breathing (lung function) tests C) Blood tests D) Chest X-ray E) Lung biopsy
B,C,D,E
What factors have been linked to IPF? A) Exposure to certain types of dust B) Viral infections C) Family history of IPF D) Acid reflux E) High cholesterol
A,B,C,D
What treatments can help relieve the symptoms of IPF? A) Self care measures B) Medicines to reduce scarring C) Breathing oxygen through a mask D) Pulmonary rehabilitation E) Antibiotics
A,B,C,D
What is the outlook for people with IPF? A) It gets worse over time B) It can be completely cured C) It has no impact on daily activities D) It is always fatal within a year E) It can be reversed
A
What additional problems can develop in people with IPF? A) Chest infections B) Pulmonary hypertension C) Heart failure D) Diabetes E) Arthritis
A,B,C
What is the NCARDRS? A) A national charity for IPF B) A national registry for rare diseases C) A medical journal D) A treatment center E) A support group
B
What age group is most commonly affected by IPF? A) Children under 10 B) Adults around 70 to 75 years old C) Teenagers D) People in their 20s E) People in their 40s
B
What are some self-care measures recommended for IPF? A) Stopping smoking B) Eating healthily C) Exercising regularly D) Taking vitamins E) Avoiding all physical activity
A,B,C
What does physiotherapy help to restore? A) Muscle mass B) Movement and function C) Hair growth D) Digestive functions E) Mental clarity
B
When is physiotherapy used? A) To improve vision B) To restore movement and function C) To enhance memory D) To reduce sleep disorders E) To improve physical activity
B,E
Which of the following conditions can physiotherapy help with? A) Skin rashes B) Back pain C) Neck pain D) Tooth decay E) Multiple sclerosis (MS)
B,C,E
What are the main approaches used by physiotherapists? A) Education and advice B) Surgery C) Medication D) Movement, tailored exercise and physical activity advice E) Manual therapy
A,D,E
Where do physiotherapists often work? A) Banks B) Hospitals C) Community health centres or clinics D) Sports teams, clubs, charities and workplaces E) Supermarkets
B,C,D

What is the holistic approach that physiotherapists take? A) Focusing on individual body parts B) Considering the body as a whole C) Using only medication D) Ignoring patient input E) Relying solely on technology
B
Which of the following techniques may be used by physiotherapists? A) Acupuncture B) Hydrotherapy or aquatic therapy C) Blood tests D) X-rays E) Manual therapy
A,B,E
