What conditions affecting the heart and circulation can physiotherapy help with? A) Rehabilitation after a heart attack B) High cholesterol C) Hypertension D) Heart failure E) Arrhythmia
A

How can you access physiotherapy through the NHS? A) Always requires a GP referral B) Self-referral in some areas C) Only through private insurance D) Only through emergency services E) Only through specialist clinics
B

Which of the following conditions affecting the lungs and breathing can physiotherapy help with? A) Asthma B) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) C) Cystic fibrosis D) Pneumonia E) Common cold
B,C
What is another name for discoid eczema? A) Psoriasis B) Nummular dermatitis C) Seborrheic dermatitis D) Ringworm E) Impetigo
B)
Which part of the body is not usually affected by discoid eczema? A) Arms B) Legs C) Face D) Abdomen E) Back
C)
What is the first sign of discoid eczema? A) Large blisters B) A group of small spots or bumps C) Severe itching D) Skin discoloration E) Peeling skin
B)
What type of eczema is caused by coming into contact with a particular substance? A) Atopic eczema B) Discoid eczema C) Contact dermatitis D) Seborrheic dermatitis E) Psoriasis
C)
Which condition often runs in families and is linked to asthma and hay fever? A) Discoid eczema B) Contact dermatitis C) Atopic eczema D) Varicose eczema E) Ringworm
C)
What should you do if you think your discoid eczema is infected? A) Apply more moisturizer B) See a pharmacist or GP C) Take over-the-counter painkillers D) Avoid sunlight E) Use a steroid cream
B)
Which environmental condition can make discoid eczema worse? A) Humid environments B) Sunny environments C) Dry environments D) Cold climates E) Warm climates
D)
What type of treatment can relieve severe symptoms of discoid eczema? A) Antibiotics B) Topical corticosteroids C) Antifungal creams D) Painkillers E) Vitamin supplements
B)
What is the main cause of discoid eczema? A) Bacterial infection B) Unknown, possibly dry skin C) Allergic reaction D) Viral infection E) Genetic predisposition
B)

What can you do to help manage discoid eczema? A) Use harsh soaps B) Avoid irritating chemicals in soaps and detergents C) Scratch the affected areas frequently D) Apply perfumed lotions E) Expose the skin to extreme temperatures
B)
What is the medical term for an overactive thyroid? A) Hypothyroidism B) Thyrotoxicosis C) Thyroiditis D) Hyperthyroidism E) Goitre
B,D,
Which of the following are symptoms of an overactive thyroid? A) Weight gain B) Sensitivity to heat C) Difficulty sleeping D) Constipation E) Swelling in your neck
B,C,E,
What are the main treatments for an overactive thyroid? A) Medicine B) Surgery C) Radiotherapy D) Diet therapy E) Exercise therapy
A,B,C,
What is the most common cause of an overactive thyroid? A) Graves' disease B) Lumps on the thyroid C) Amiodarone D) Iodine deficiency E) Stress
A,B,C,
What are some of the potential further problems associated with an untreated overactive thyroid? A) Eye problems B) Pregnancy complications C) Thyroid storm D) Liver failure E) Kidney stones
A,B,C,

What is the thyroid gland? A) A small butterfly-shaped gland B) A large gland in the chest C) A gland that produces insulin D) A gland that controls blood pressure E) A gland that produces hormones affecting heart rate and body temperature
A,E,
Which of the following are not symptoms of an overactive thyroid? A) Nervousness B) Cold intolerance C) Weight loss D) Twitching E) Increased appetite
B,E,
What is the first step in diagnosing an overactive thyroid? A) MRI scan B) Blood test C) X-ray D) Ultrasound E) Endoscopy
B,
Who is more commonly affected by an overactive thyroid? A) Men B) Women C) Children D) Elderly E) Pregnant women
B,
What are some of the potential complications of an overactive thyroid during pregnancy? A) Pre-eclampsia B) Gestational diabetes C) Increased fetal weight D) Premature birth E) Miscarriage
A,D,E,
What are the main types of urinary incontinence? A) Stress incontinence B) Overflow incontinence C) Urge incontinence D) Total incontinence E) Bladder incontinence
A,C
What is the primary cause of stress incontinence? A) Weak pelvic floor muscles B) Overactive detrusor muscles C) Bladder obstruction D) Excessive fluid intake E) Spinal injury
A,C
Which lifestyle changes can help manage urinary incontinence? A) Losing weight B) Increasing caffeine intake C) Pelvic floor exercises D) Drinking more alcohol E) Bladder training
A,E
What factors can increase the chances of urinary incontinence? A) Pregnancy and vaginal birth B) Obesity C) Family history D) Increasing age E) Low calcium intake
A,B
Which surgical treatment is used for stress incontinence? A) Sling procedure B) Bladder enlargement C) Implanting a nerve stimulator D) Pelvic floor exercises E) Absorbent pads
A,C
What can cause overflow incontinence? A) Weak pelvic floor muscles B) Bladder obstruction C) Overactive detrusor muscles D) Excessive alcohol consumption E) Fistula
B,E
Which products can be used to manage urinary incontinence? A) Absorbent pads B) Handheld urinals C) Caffeine supplements D) Alcoholic beverages E) Detrusor muscle relaxants
A,B
What is the recommended weekly limit for alcohol consumption? A) 7 units B) 14 units C) 21 units D) 28 units E) 35 units
B,D
What can help prevent urinary incontinence during pregnancy? A) Pelvic floor exercises B) Increasing caffeine intake C) Excessive fluid intake D) Bladder training E) Maintaining a healthy weight
A,E
Which medical professional should you see if you have urinary incontinence? A) Dentist B) GP C) Optometrist D) Pharmacist E) Physiotherapist
B,D
What does the term 'obese' describe? A) A person with a healthy weight B) A person with excess body fat C) A person with a high BMI D) A person with a low BMI E) A person with a normal BMI
What percentage of adults in the UK are living with obesity? A) 1 in 5 B) 1 in 4 C) 1 in 3 D) 1 in 2 E) 1 in 6
What is the most widely used method to check if you're a healthy weight? A) Waist to height ratio B) Body mass index (BMI) C) Weight scale D) Body fat percentage E) Blood test
What is the BMI range for being in the overweight range for most adults? A) 18.5 to 24.9 B) 25 to 29.9 C) 30 to 39.9 D) 40 or above E) 23 to 27.4
What are some health risks associated with living with obesity? A) Type 2 diabetes B) Stroke C) Breast cancer D) Asthma E) Bowel cancer
What are some causes of obesity? A) Extra calories from foods high in fat and sugar B) Genetics C) Underactive thyroid gland D) Some medicines E) Lack of physical activity
What are some recommended treatments for obesity? A) Eating a healthy reduced-calorie diet B) Exercise regularly C) Weight loss surgery D) Medicine like orlistat E) Psychotherapy
What are some day-to-day problems related to obesity? A) Breathlessness B) Increased sweating C) Low confidence and self-esteem D) Joint and back pain E) Feeling very tired
What are some serious health conditions associated with obesity? A) High blood pressure B) High cholesterol C) Gallstones D) Liver disease E) Kidney disease

What is the recommended amount of physical activity for treating obesity? A) 150 to 300 minutes a week B) 100 to 200 minutes a week C) 50 to 100 minutes a week D) 200 to 300 minutes a week E) 300 to 400 minutes a week
What are the main blood vessels that supply blood to the neck, face, and brain? A) Aortic arteries B) Carotid arteries C) Femoral arteries D) Renal arteries E) Pulmonary arteries
B)

What is the procedure called that removes a build-up of fatty deposits (plaque) from the carotid arteries? A) Carotid angioplasty B) Carotid endarterectomy C) Carotid stenting D) Carotid bypass E) Carotid laser therapy
B)
What can result from a narrowed carotid artery if left untreated? A) Heart attack B) Stroke C) Transient ischaemic attack (TIA) D) Kidney failure E) Liver disease
B),C)

What symptoms should you seek immediate medical advice for to reduce the risk of a stroke? A) Chest pain B) Numbness or weakness in your face, arm, or leg C) Abdominal pain D) Speech problems E) Loss of vision in one eye
What type of anaesthesia can be used during a carotid endarterectomy? A) Spinal anaesthesia B) General anaesthesia C) Local anaesthesia D) Epidural anaesthesia E) Intravenous sedation
B),C)
What is the usual recovery time for most people after a carotid endarterectomy? A) 24 hours B) 48 hours C) 72 hours D) 1 week E) 2 weeks
B)
What are the most common problems experienced after a carotid endarterectomy? A) Temporary numbness or discomfort in the neck B) Severe headaches C) Loss of appetite D) High fever E) Muscle spasms
A)
What is the risk of serious complications like stroke or death after a carotid endarterectomy? A) 1% B) 2-3% C) 5% D) 10% E) 20%
B)
What is an alternative procedure to carotid endarterectomy? A) Coronary artery bypass B) Carotid artery stent placement C) Angioplasty D) Valve replacement E) Heart transplant
B)

What is the first line of treatment recommended for most people with narrowed carotid arteries? A) Carotid artery stent placement B) Carotid endarterectomy C) Medication only D) Lifestyle changes E) Physical therapy
B)

What is Down's syndrome? A: A genetic disorder caused by an extra chromosome. B: A disease caused by poor nutrition. C: A result of a viral infection. D: A mental health condition. E: A skin condition.
A

How does one usually get Down's syndrome? A: Through a change in the sperm or egg before birth. B: By eating contaminated food. C: Through exposure to radiation. D: By inheriting it from parents. E: Through a change in the environment.
A

What does having a learning disability mean for someone with Down's syndrome? A: They will have a range of abilities and may need varying levels of care. B: They will never be able to live independently. C: They will always need constant medical attention. D: They will have no personalities or likes and dislikes. E: They will have a short lifespan.
A

Can people with Down's syndrome have their own personalities? A: Yes, they have their own personalities. B: No, they all behave the same. C: They have no emotions. D: They are always happy. E: They cannot express themselves.
A

Does Down's syndrome usually run in families? A: No, it does not usually run in families. B: Yes, it is always inherited. C: Sometimes it runs in families. D: It depends on the ethnicity. E: It is only inherited through the mother's side.
A
What increases the chance of having a baby with Down's syndrome? A: The mother's age. B: The father's occupation. C: The mother's diet. D: The father's age. E: The mother's exercise routine.
A
Who can you speak to if you want to find out more about having a baby with Down's syndrome? A: A genetic counsellor. B: A dietitian. C: A physiotherapist. D: A dentist. E: A pharmacist.
A

When will you be offered a screening test for Down's syndrome if you're pregnant? A: Between weeks 10 and 14 of pregnancy. B: After the baby is born. C: Only if you request it. D: Before conception. E: During the first month of pregnancy.
A

What does the screening test for Down's syndrome involve? A: An ultrasound scan with a blood test. B: A series of X-rays. C: A psychological evaluation. D: A physical fitness test. E: A blood test only.
A

Is it mandatory to have screening tests for Down's syndrome? A: No, it's your choice. B: Yes, it is mandatory by law. C: Only if you have a family history. D: Only if the doctor recommends it. E: Only if you are over a certain age.
A
What are the early symptoms of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: Depression B: Memory loss C: Confusion D: Personality changes E: Dizziness
A,D,
What is the main cause of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: Genetic predisposition B: Repeated head injuries C: Viral infection D: Exposure to chemicals E: Poor nutrition
B,

When do symptoms of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) usually start? A: Immediately after head injury B: Around 10 years after repeated head injuries C: After 20 years D: Within a month E: After 5 years
B,
What kind of support can be provided to manage symptoms of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: Physiotherapy B: Herbal remedies C: Dietary supplements D: Occupational therapy E: Light therapy
A,D,

Who is most at risk of developing chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: People with a family history of dementia B: People who regularly played contact sports C: People who have had blast injuries D: People who often have migraines E: People with a high BMI
B,C,

What might a GP do during an appointment for suspected chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: Conduct a full body scan B: Ask about past head injuries C: Perform blood or urine tests D: Prescribe strong painkillers E: Refer to a memory assessment service
B,C,E

What are some of the advanced symptoms of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: Short-term memory loss B: Heightened sense of taste C: Confusion D: Increased appetite E: Difficulties with planning and organisation
A,C,E

How can the risk of developing chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) be lowered? A: Eating a balanced diet B: Avoiding repeated head injuries C: Regular exercise D: Taking vitamin supplements E: Wearing protective equipment during sports
B,E,

Why might a person be referred to a specialist for chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: To get a formal diagnosis B: To undergo surgery C: For speech and language therapy D: To receive a care plan E: For genetic testing
C,D,

What is the prognosis for chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)? A: It can be cured with medication B: It slowly gets worse over time C: It can be reversed with therapy D: It is always fatal E: It does not affect cognitive abilities
B,

What is the definition of menopause? A) A condition diagnosed in women over 45 who have not had a period for more than a year. B) A condition diagnosed in women over 50 who have not had a period for more than two years. C) A condition diagnosed in women over 45 who have not had a period for more than a year. D) A condition diagnosed in women over 35 who have not had a period for more than a year. E) A condition diagnosed in women over 40 who have not had a period for more than a year.
A,C

What should you do if you experience postmenopausal bleeding? A) See a GP even if it's only happened once. B) Ignore it if it's a small amount of blood. C) See a GP even if there's only a small amount of blood, spotting, or pink or brown discharge. D) Wait for it to go away on its own. E) See a GP even if you're not sure if it's blood.
A,C,E

What tests might you be offered at a hospital or clinic appointment for postmenopausal bleeding? A) A blood test. B) A vaginal ultrasound scan. C) An examination of your pelvis and vagina. D) A hysteroscopy. E) A specialist pressing on your tummy and inside your vagina.
B,C,D,E

What are the most common causes of postmenopausal bleeding? A) Inflammation and thinning of the vaginal lining (atrophic vaginitis). B) Cervical or womb polyps. C) A thickened womb lining (endometrial hyperplasia). D) High cholesterol levels. E) Low blood pressure.
A,B,C

What treatment might be offered for cervical polyps causing postmenopausal bleeding? A) Oestrogen cream. B) Removal of the polyps by a specialist. C) Hormone medicine. D) Radiotherapy. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
B

What treatment might be offered for vaginal or endometrial atrophy causing postmenopausal bleeding? A) Oestrogen cream or pessaries. B) Removal of the polyps by a specialist. C) Hormone medicine. D) Radiotherapy. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
A

What treatment might be offered for endometrial hyperplasia causing postmenopausal bleeding? A) No treatment. B) Hormone medicine (tablets or an intrauterine system, IUS). C) Total hysterectomy. D) Radiotherapy. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
A,B,C

What treatment might be offered if postmenopausal bleeding is a side effect of HRT? A) Changing or stopping HRT treatment. B) Oestrogen cream. C) Hormone medicine. D) Radiotherapy. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
A

What treatment might be offered for womb cancer that causes postmenopausal bleeding? A) Total hysterectomy. B) Oestrogen cream. C) Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy. D) Removal of the polyps by a specialist. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
A,C,E

What treatment might be offered for ovarian cancer that causes postmenopausal bleeding? A) Surgery to remove your ovaries, and sometimes your womb (total hysterectomy). B) Oestrogen cream. C) Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy. D) Removal of the polyps by a specialist. E) Surgery to remove your ovaries.
A,C,E
What are the symptoms of astigmatism? A) Blurred vision B) Headaches C) Eye strain D) Double vision E) Dry eyes
A,B,C
What causes lazy eye in relation to astigmatism? A) Astigmatism in both eyes B) Astigmatism in 1 eye C) Not wearing glasses D) Excessive screen time E) Poor diet
A,B,C
Which conditions often occur alongside astigmatism? A) Short-sightedness B) Long-sightedness C) Color blindness D) Cataracts E) Glaucoma
A,B,C

What are the pros of using glasses for astigmatism? A) Cheapest option B) May be available free or discounted on the NHS C) Can be lost or broken D) Always permanent E) No side effects

A,B,C
What is the main test to check for low sperm count? A) Blood test B) Semen analysis test C) MRI D) X-ray E) PET scan

What is one of the treatments for low sperm count? A) IVF B) ICSI C) Using donor sperm D) Surgery E) Acupuncture

What are the symptoms of mesothelioma in the lining of the lungs? A) Chest pain B) Shortness of breath C) Abdominal pain D) Fever E) Swollen fingertips

What are the initial symptoms of meningitis? A) High temperature B) Headache C) Rash D) Stiff neck E) Diarrhea

A,B,C,D

A,B,C,D

What is the age group often affected by long-sightedness? A) Under 20 years B) 20-40 years C) Over 40 years D) Over 60 years E) All ages
C,E
What is cancer? A) A condition where cells grow and reproduce uncontrollably B) A virus that affects the skin C) A mental health disorder D) A bacterial infection E) A type of allergy
A

A
What are the 4 most common types of cancer in the UK? A) Breast cancer B) Lung cancer C) Prostate cancer D) Bowel cancer E) Skin cancer
A,B,C,D

How many different types of cancer are there? A) Less than 50 B) More than 200 C) Exactly 100 D) Around 150 E) Less than 10
B

A

E

What are some symptoms of a herpes simplex eye infection? A) Eye pain B) A red eye C) A swollen ankle D) Blisters on your eyelid E) Sensitivity to light

What are some signs that your child may have problems with their vision? A) Narrowing or squinting their eyes B) Closing 1 eye C) Turning their head in unusual ways D) Looking at you sideways E) Blinking rapidly

What should you do if you still have double vision in the eye that is not covered? A) Ignore it B) It’s probably only affecting that eye C) It’s probably affecting both eyes D) Take painkillers E) Drink plenty of water

What is the main symptom of glue ear? A: Tinnitus B: Temporary hearing loss C: Earache D: Dizziness E: Fever
B
How long does glue ear usually last? A: 1 week B: 1 month C: 3 months D: 6 months E: 1 year
C

B
What should you do if you suspect glue ear? A: Wait it out B: See a GP C: Try home remedies D: Ignore it E: Go to the emergency room
B

A

A
What are the main hospital treatments for glue ear? A: Ear drops B: Hearing aids C: Grommets D: Antibiotics E: Painkillers

What is an adenoidectomy in relation to glue ear? A: Removal of earwax B: Removal of adenoids C: Removal of tonsils D: Removal of eardrum E: Removal of nasal polyps

Why might a doctor ask for a poo sample? A) To check for a headache B) To test for blood in your poo C) To monitor sleep patterns D) To diagnose a skin rash E) To assess constipation
B,E,

What should you do before collecting your poo sample if you need to pee? A) Pee in a separate container B) Pee after collecting the sample C) Pee before collecting the sample D) Skip peeing altogether E) Pee directly into the sample container
A,C,
What type of container is usually provided for a poo sample? A) A large metal bowl B) A small plastic container C) A glass jar D) A cardboard box E) A fabric pouch
B,E,
What should you do to catch the poo in the toilet? A) Use a towel B) Use a clean disposable container C) Place newspaper over the rim D) Use cling film E) Use a sponge
B,C,
What should you use to put the poo in the container? A) A metal spoon B) A disposable spoon C) Your fingers D) A fork E) A plastic spoon
B,E,
What should you do with the rest of the poo after collecting the sample? A) Save it for later B) Flush it down the toilet C) Store it in the fridge D) Throw it in the garden E) Put it in a sealed bag
B,E,
What should you do with the items used to collect the poo sample? A) Reuse them B) Put them in a plastic bag and tie it up C) Throw them directly in the bin D) Burn them E) Flush them down the toilet

How should you return your poo sample? A) Keep it for a week B) Hand it in or post it as soon as possible C) Freeze it D) Mix it with water E) Return it in a non-prepaid envelope
B,E,
What should you do if you cannot return the poo sample within 24 hours? A) Throw it away B) Talk to your doctor C) Store it in the freezer D) Leave it outside E) Mix it with other samples

What can a poo sample help diagnose? A) Flu B) Diarrhoea C) Diabetes D) Crohn's disease E) Headache
B,D,
What are the symptoms of peritonitis? A) Tummy pain B) A very high temperature C) A rapid heartbeat D) Increased appetite E) A swollen tummy
A,B,C

A,B,C

What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)? A) A service to register information about rare diseases B) A service for heart conditions C) A service for lung diseases D) A service for kidney diseases E) A service for skin diseases
A
What should you do if your skin is itchy? A: Scratch it vigorously B: Pat or tap your skin C: Take a hot bath D: Use perfumed moisturisers E: Wear tight clothes

What should you do if you think you or someone else has been bitten by a snake? A) Drive to A&E B) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately C) Wait for the symptoms to develop D) Try to suck the venom out E) Take ibuprofen for pain
B,D

What should you do while waiting for medical help after a snake bite? A) Go near the snake B) Stay calm C) Tie something tightly around the bite D) Take paracetamol for pain E) Try to catch or kill the snake
B,D

What should you not do after a snake bite? A) Take aspirin or ibuprofen B) Lie in the recovery position C) Remember the colour and pattern of the snake D) Drive to A&E E) Take off any jewellery near the bite
A,D

What happens at the hospital after a snake bite? A) You will be given a medicine to fight the venom B) You will need to stay in hospital for at least 24 hours C) The bite will be cleaned and bandaged D) You will be given an injection to help protect you from tetanus E) You will be discharged immediately
B,C
Which of the following snakes are found in the wild in the UK? A) Adder B) Cobra C) Grass snake D) Smooth snake E) Python
A,C
What colour is the adder snake typically? A) Green B) Grey or reddish-brown C) Black D) Blue E) White
B,D
What pattern does the adder snake have? A) Dark zig-zag shaped stripe down their back B) Yellow and black bands around their neck C) Dark spots down their sides D) Stripes E) No pattern
A,C
What colour is the grass snake typically? A) Green B) Grey or brown C) Black D) Blue E) White
A,B
What pattern does the grass snake have? A) Dark zig-zag shaped stripe down their back B) Yellow and black bands around their neck C) Dark spots down their sides D) Stripes E) No pattern
B,C
What colour is the smooth snake typically? A) Green B) Grey or brown C) Black D) Blue E) White
B,C
At what age do symptoms of Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) usually start? A) 20-30 years B) 30-40 years C) 40-50 years D) 50-60 years E) 60-70 years
D)
Which part of the body is affected by MSA, causing balance and movement issues? A) Liver B) Lungs C) Brain D) Heart E) Kidneys
C)
What is the medical term for the inability to get and maintain an erection? A) Erectile dysfunction B) Impotence C) Sexual dysfunction D) Libido loss E) Infertility
A)
What is the condition called when a person feels lightheaded, dizzy, and faint after standing up? A) Vertigo B) Postural hypotension C) Syncope D) Hypoglycemia E) Anemia
B)
Which part of the brain is damaged in MSA, causing problems with coordination, balance, and speech? A) Frontal lobe B) Temporal lobe C) Cerebellum D) Occipital lobe E) Parietal lobe
C)
What is the term for the slowness of movement and feeling stiff in MSA? A) Bradykinesia B) Hyperkinesia C) Dyskinesia D) Akinesia E) Hypokinesia
A)
Which medicine is used to relieve symptoms in Parkinson's disease but is not very effective for people with MSA? A) Levodopa B) Dopamine C) Serotonin D) Acetylcholine E) Norepinephrine
A)
What is the protein that builds up abnormally in the brain cells of a person with MSA? A) Alpha-synuclein B) Beta-amyloid C) Tau protein D) Prion protein E) Huntingtin protein
A)
Which test is often needed to detect any loss of brain cells in MSA? A) CT scan B) MRI scan C) PET scan D) X-ray E) Ultrasound
B)
What is the average lifespan of a person with MSA after their symptoms start? A) 1-3 years B) 3-5 years C) 6-9 years D) 10-12 years E) 15-20 years
C)

What is the purpose of a potassium test? A) To measure the amount of potassium in blood serum B) To check for anemia C) To diagnose skin conditions D) To assess lung function E) To monitor blood sugar levels
A
Potassium helps with which of the following processes? A) Bone growth B) Muscle and nerve communication C) Hair growth D) Liver function E) Eye health
B
Which organ's disease is the most common cause of high potassium levels? A) Liver B) Heart C) Kidney D) Lungs E) Brain
C
A doctor might recommend a potassium test if you have which of the following conditions? A) Asthma B) High blood pressure (hypertension) C) Arthritis D) Depression E) Sinusitis
B
Low potassium levels may indicate which of the following heart conditions? A) Heart attack B) Coronary artery disease C) Irregular heartbeat D) Heart murmur E) Congestive heart failure
C
A serious complication of diabetes that may require a potassium test is? A) Diabetic retinopathy B) Diabetic ketoacidosis C) Diabetic neuropathy D) Diabetic foot ulcers E) Diabetic gastroparesis
B
Which of the following can be a good source of dietary potassium? A) Rice B) Bananas C) Soda D) Candy E) Ice cream
B
If you have high potassium levels, what may happen to your heart muscle activity? A) It may increase B) It may become irregular C) It may be reduced D) It may stop E) It may beat faster
C
Potassium levels may be low through which of the following factors? A) High protein diet B) Excessive exercise C) Poor diet D) High fiber diet E) Sleep deprivation
C

Which of the following is NOT a reason for a doctor to recommend a potassium test? A) To monitor kidney disease B) If you have heart-related problems C) If you take certain medicines D) If you have diabetes E) To check for appendicitis
E

What is an anal fistula? A) A small tunnel between the bowel and the skin near the anus B) A growth on the skin near the anus C) A type of skin rash D) A cyst inside the anus E) A swollen vein near the anus
A)
What causes an anal fistula? A) Infection near the anus B) Poor hygiene C) Consumption of spicy food D) Excessive exercise E) Crohn's disease
A),E)

What symptoms might indicate an anal fistula? A) Skin irritation around the anus B) Constant, throbbing pain C) Smelly discharge near the anus D) Swelling and redness around the anus E) Difficulty breathing

When should you seek medical advice for an anal fistula? A) When you have persistent symptoms B) When you have a fever C) When you have a headache D) When you have a cold E) When you have difficulty controlling bowel movements
A),E)
What tests might be used to diagnose an anal fistula? A) Rectal examination B) Proctoscopy C) Ultrasound scan D) Blood test E) X-ray
What less common causes of anal fistulas include? A) Crohn's disease B) Poor nutrition C) High blood pressure D) Diverticulitis E) Tuberculosis
What are the main surgical options for treating an anal fistula? A) Fistulotomy B) Seton procedures C) Antibiotics D) Physical therapy E) Dietary changes
A),B)
What might a GP do to initially assess an anal fistula? A) Examine the skin around the anus B) Perform a rectal examination C) Prescribe antibiotics D) Recommend exercise E) Order an ultrasound scan
A),B)

What might happen if an anal fistula is left untreated? A) It will heal on its own B) It will cause severe pain C) It will require surgery D) It will cause skin irritation E) It will cause difficulty controlling bowel movements
What might be a complication of surgery near the anus? A) Anal fistula B) Constipation C) Nausea D) Headache E) Fever
A)
What is the primary way hepatitis C is spread? A: Through airborne droplets B: Through blood-to-blood contact C: Through drinking water D: Through mosquito bites E: Through sneezing
B
Which symptom is commonly associated with hepatitis C? A: Coughing B: Muscle aches C: Blurred vision D: Sore throat E: Itchy skin
B
What is the estimated number of people in the UK with chronic hepatitis C in 2019? A: 50,000 B: 118,000 C: 200,000 D: 300,000 E: 400,000
B
How is hepatitis C primarily diagnosed? A: Urine test B: Blood test C: X-ray D: MRI E: Saliva test
B
What is the most common way people get hepatitis C in the UK? A: Through food contamination B: Through blood transfusions C: Through injecting drugs D: Through sexual contact E: Through skin contact
C
What is a common complication of untreated hepatitis C? A: Heart disease B: Liver cirrhosis C: Kidney failure D: Diabetes E: Asthma
B
Which medicine is used to treat hepatitis C? A: Penicillin B: Sofosbuvir C: Insulin D: Aspirin E: Paracetamol
B
What is the primary transmission route of hepatitis C? A: Through saliva B: Through blood C: Through sweat D: Through tears E: Through mucus
B
Which group has a higher risk of hepatitis C infection? A: Pregnant women B: People who inject drugs C: Children D: Elderly people E: Athletes
B
What is the effectiveness rate of the latest hepatitis C treatments? A: 50% B: 70% C: 90% D: 95% E: 100%
C

What is an ectopic pregnancy? A: When a fertilised egg implants itself outside of the womb, usually in one of the fallopian tubes. B: When a fertilised egg implants itself in the stomach. C: When a fertilised egg implants itself in the intestines. D: When a fertilised egg implants itself in the uterus. E: When a fertilised egg implants itself in the bladder.
A,D

What are the symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy? A: A missed period and other signs of pregnancy. B: Tummy pain low down on one side. C: Vaginal bleeding or a brown watery discharge. D: Pain in the tip of your shoulder. E: Feeling very happy and energetic.
A,B,C,D

When should you seek medical advice for an ectopic pregnancy? A: If you have a combination of symptoms and might be pregnant. B: If you have a sharp, sudden, and intense pain in your tummy. C: If you feel very dizzy or faint. D: If you feel sick and look very pale. E: If you feel like you have a common cold.
A,B,C,D

What are the treatments for an ectopic pregnancy? A: Expectant management. B: Medicine such as methotrexate. C: Surgery, usually keyhole surgery (laparoscopy). D: Home remedies like drinking herbal tea. E: Acupuncture.
A,B,C

What should you do if you are struggling to come to terms with the loss of an ectopic pregnancy? A: Seek professional support or counselling. B: Join support groups for people affected by pregnancy loss. C: Speak to your GP about your feelings. D: Ignore your feelings and pretend everything is fine. E: Avoid talking about it with anyone.
A,B,C

When can you try for another baby after an ectopic pregnancy? A: After you have had at least 2 periods. B: After 3 months if treated with methotrexate. C: Immediately after treatment. D: After waiting for 6 months. E: After waiting for 1 year.
A,B

What can cause an ectopic pregnancy? A: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). B: Previous ectopic pregnancy. C: Previous surgery on your fallopian tubes. D: Eating too much junk food. E: Drinking too much coffee.
A,B,C
What can reduce the risk of an ectopic pregnancy? A: Using a condom to protect against STIs. B: Stopping smoking. C: Drinking more water. D: Exercising regularly. E: Eating a balanced diet.
A,B
What is the risk of having another ectopic pregnancy after one? A: Around 10%. B: Around 5%. C: Around 20%. D: Around 30%. E: Around 50%.
A

What should you do if you have a combination of symptoms and might be pregnant? A: Contact your GP or call NHS 111. B: Go to the nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department. C: Wait and see if the symptoms go away. D: Take over-the-counter painkillers. E: Perform a home pregnancy test.
A,B
What is a ganglion cyst? A) A type of skin rash B) A fluid-filled swelling near a joint or tendon C) A bone fracture D) A type of bacterial infection E) A muscle strain
B)
Where do ganglion cysts most commonly occur? A) Feet B) Wrists C) Knees D) Neck E) Back
B)
What is the fluid inside a ganglion cyst called? A) Blood B) Cerebrospinal fluid C) Synovial fluid D) Lymphatic fluid E) Bile
C)
What are the main treatment options for a ganglion cyst? A) Chemotherapy B) Radiotherapy C) Aspiration D) Surgery E) Massage therapy
C),D)

What is aspiration in the context of treating a ganglion cyst? A) Removing the cyst with a laser B) Draining fluid with a needle and syringe C) Applying a cream D) Using a splint E) Injecting a vaccine
B)

What are the two types of surgery that can be used to remove a ganglion cyst? A) Arthroscopy and endoscopy B) Open surgery and arthroscopy C) Laparoscopy and endoscopy D) Open surgery and robotic surgery E) Open surgery and cryosurgery
B)
Which anesthetic can be used during surgery to remove a ganglion cyst? A) Local anaesthetic B) General anaesthetic C) Both local and general anaesthetic D) No anaesthetic E) Epidural anaesthetic
C)

What is the main benefit of keyhole surgery for removing a ganglion cyst? A) It is cheaper B) It causes less pain after the operation C) It is faster D) It is more effective E) It requires no anaesthetic
B)

What might be recommended after surgery to remove a ganglion cyst from the wrist or hand? A) Complete immobilization B) Wearing a sling C) Avoiding all movement D) Taking antibiotics E) Using a wheelchair
B)
What is a possible complication of surgery to remove a ganglion cyst? A) Blindness B) Permanent stiffness and pain C) Hair loss D) Kidney failure E) Severe weight gain
B)

What is a hamstring injury? A) A fracture in the thigh bone B) A strain or tear to the tendons or large muscles at the back of the thigh C) A dislocation of the knee D) A sprain in the ankle E) A tear in the abdominal muscles
B)
How many grades of hamstring injury are there? A) 1 B) 2 C) 3 D) 4 E) 5
C)
What is a grade 1 hamstring injury? A) A complete muscle tear B) A mild muscle pull or strain C) A fracture D) A dislocation E) A severe bruise
B)
What is a grade 3 hamstring injury? A) A mild muscle pull or strain B) A partial muscle tear C) A complete muscle tear D) A sprain E) A fracture
C)
Which activity uses the hamstring muscles the most? A) Standing B) Walking C) Running D) Swimming E) Lifting weights
C)
What is the initial treatment for a hamstring injury? A) Surgery B) RICE therapy C) Intensive exercise D) Heat application E) Massage
B)
What does 'R' stand for in RICE therapy? A) Run B) Rest C) Rehabilitate D) Resume E) Rinse
B)
What does 'I' stand for in RICE therapy? A) Inflammatory drugs B) Ice C) Immobilize D) Inhale E) Injection
B)
What should you do if you have a severe hamstring injury? A) Continue exercising B) See a GP C) Apply heat D) Ignore it E) Drink plenty of water
B)
Which medication can help reduce swelling and inflammation after a hamstring injury? A) Antibiotics B) Steroids C) Ibuprofen D) Antihistamines E) Vitamins
C)

What is phenylketonuria (PKU)? A) A common but mild inherited disorder B) A rare but potentially serious inherited disorder C) A disorder caused by a virus D) A condition that affects only adults E) A condition that affects the immune system
B
What is the main treatment for PKU? A) A high-protein diet B) A low-protein diet and controlled intake of many other foods C) Regular surgery D) Medication only E) No treatment required
B
What happens if PKU is not treated? A) It goes away on its own B) It causes brain damage C) It improves over time D) It leads to improved health E) It has no long-term effects
B
What is the inheritance pattern of PKU? A) Autosomal dominant B) Autosomal recessive C) X-linked dominant D) X-linked recessive E) Mitochondrial inheritance
B

What is aspartame and why should people with PKU avoid it? A) A vitamin that helps with PKU B) A sweetener found in many foods that is converted into phenylalanine in the body C) A medication for PKU D) A type of protein E) A type of carbohydrate
B

What is sapropterin used for in the treatment of PKU? A) To increase phenylalanine levels B) To reduce the level of phenylalanine in the body C) To cure PKU completely D) To prevent PKU E) To cause PKU
B
How often should a child with PKU have their blood tested if they are 1 year or younger? A) Once a month B) Once a week C) Once every 2 weeks D) Once a year E) Never
B
What is the genetic cause of PKU? A) A mutation passed on by the parents B) A virus C) A bacterial infection D) A result of environmental factors E) A result of diet only
A

What are the symptoms of untreated PKU? A) High fever and chills B) Behavioural difficulties, fairer skin and hair, eczema, and a musty smell C) Increased appetite D) Excessive sweating E) Rapid heart rate
B
What foods should be avoided by people with PKU? A) Meat and fish B) Eggs and cheese C) Nuts and seeds D) Flour-based foods E) All of the above
E
Which skin conditions can be managed with emollients? A) Eczema B) Psoriasis C) Diabetes D) Ichthyosis E) Arthritis
A,B
What type of emollient is best for very dry, thickened skin? A) Lotions B) Creams C) Ointments D) Sprays E) Liquids
C,D
Which of the following should be used instead of normal soap for dry or itchy skin? A) Emollient soap substitutes B) Shower gels C) Regular soap D) Antibacterial soap E) Shampoos
A,E
How often should emollients be applied to keep the skin well moisturized? A) Once a day B) 3 or 4 times a day C) Once a week D) Twice a day E) Every other day
B,D

What should you do if your skin stings after using an emollient wash product? A) Continue using it B) Ask a pharmacist for a different product C) Stop using all emollients D) Use more of the product E) Rinse with cold water
B,E
Which type of emollient is good for daytime use? A) Creams B) Lotions C) Ointments D) Sprays E) Gels
A,D

What should you do if you need to use a steroid cream along with an emollient? A) Use them at the same time B) Wait 20 to 30 minutes between applications C) Mix them together D) Use only the steroid cream E) Use only the emollient
B,C

What should be done to reduce the risk of infections from contaminated emollient pots? A) Use a clean spoon or spatula B) Wash hands before use C) Use a dirty spoon D) Use the emollient directly from the pot E) Keep the pot open
A,B
What should you do if you experience a skin reaction to an emollient? A) Continue using it B) Talk to a GP, nurse, or pharmacist C) Apply more emollient D) Switch to aqueous cream E) Use regular soap
B,D
Which activities may irritate the skin and require the application of an emollient beforehand? A) Gardening B) Watching TV C) Reading D) Walking E) Swimming
A,E
What are the main causes of dementia? A) Genetic factors B) Lack of exercise C) Head injuries D) Dietary habits E) Infections
A, C
Which symptoms are commonly associated with dementia? A) Memory loss B) Difficulty with language C) Changes in mood D) Muscle weakness E) High fever
A, B
How can dementia be diagnosed? A) Blood tests B) Brain scans C) Physical examination D) Genetic testing E) Eye exam
B, C
What are some ways to support someone living with dementia? A) Regular exercise B) Social interaction C) Healthy diet D) Isolation E) Limiting fluid intake
A, B
Which organizations provide support for people with dementia? A) Dementia Friends B) Admiral Nurses C) Alzheimer's Society D) Cancer Research UK E) British Heart Foundation
A, B
What are some financial support options for people with dementia? A) NHS care B) Social services C) Legal aid D) Private insurance E) Travel discounts
A, B
What are some ways to prevent dementia? A) Regular exercise B) Healthy diet C) Mental stimulation D) Avoiding social interaction E) Smoking
A, C
What is the role of a 'Dementia Friend'? A) Providing medical advice B) Offering emotional support C) Conducting research D) Administrative tasks E) Financial planning
B, C
What can you do if you've been diagnosed with dementia? A) Seek medical treatment B) Join a support group C) Change your diet D) Avoid social contact E) Stop all physical activity
A, B
What are some legal issues related to dementia? A) Power of attorney B) Wills and estates C) Criminal law D) Immigration law E) Environmental law
A, B
What is a herpes simplex eye infection? A) A bacterial infection B) A viral infection C) A fungal infection D) An allergy E) A parasitic infection
B
Which of the following is a symptom of a herpes simplex eye infection? A) Eye pain B) Green discharge C) Itchy scalp D) Swollen eyelid E) Fever
A,D

If you have a red eye with no pain for more than a few days, what should you do? A) Wait for it to resolve on its own B) See a GP or go to an optician C) Take painkillers D) Drink more water E) Apply ice packs
B
What should you do if you have eye pain and a red eye that's getting worse? A) Wait for a few days B) Call a doctor C) Use over-the-counter eye drops D) Apply warm compresses E) Take antihistamines
B
What immediate action should you take if your eye is very dark red? A) Apply eye cream B) Schedule an appointment with a dermatologist C) Call 999 or go to A&E D) Take a nap E) Drink plenty of fluids
C
What treatment is usually prescribed for a herpes simplex eye infection? A) Antibiotics B) Antiviral medicine C) Steroids alone D) Painkillers E) Eye ointment
B
What can cause a herpes simplex eye infection to come back? A) Lack of sleep B) Exposure to bright light C) Stress D) Eye injury E) Consuming spicy food
B,C,D

What should you do if your herpes simplex eye infection keeps coming back? A) Take antiviral tablets every day B) Avoid sunlight completely C) Consume more vitamin C D) Use steroid eye drops alone E) Drink more milk
A

How can a herpes simplex eye infection affect your sight? A) It can cause cataracts B) It can cause scarring of the cornea C) It can cause color blindness D) It can cause astigmatism E) It can cause glaucoma
B

What should you do if you use contact lenses and have a herpes simplex eye infection? A) Wear them as usual B) Do not wear them until 24 hours after all symptoms have gone C) Clean them with soap D) Soak them in vinegar E) Throw them away
B
Where is cholera mostly found? A) UK B) Europe C) Africa and Asia D) South America E) Australia
C
How can you get cholera? A) Drinking clean water B) Eating food handled by an infected person C) Eating cooked vegetables D) Wearing dirty clothes E) Shaking hands with someone
B
What should you do to avoid cholera while travelling? A) Drink tap water B) Wash your hands with soap and water regularly C) Eat raw seafood D) Use ice in your drinks E) Avoid brushing your teeth
B
Who is usually recommended to get the cholera vaccine? A) All tourists B) Aid or disaster relief workers C) People travelling to the UK D) Children under 5 E) Pregnant women
B
How is the cholera vaccine administered? A) Injection B) Nasal spray C) Drink D) Patch E) Suppository
C
What are the symptoms of cholera? A) Fever and cough B) Watery diarrhoea and tummy pain C) Headache and sore throat D) Rash and itching E) Muscle pain and fatigue
B

When should you see a doctor if you suspect cholera? A) If you have a headache B) If you have severe watery diarrhoea and vomiting C) If you have a runny nose D) If you have muscle cramps E) If you have a fever
B
What is the main treatment for cholera? A) Painkillers B) Drinking plenty of fluids C) Surgery D) Antihistamines E) Vitamin supplements
B
What should you use to replace salts, sugars, and minerals lost through diarrhoea? A) Sports drinks B) Rehydration solution C) Fruit juice D) Soda E) Milk
B
Where can you find health advice for a country you're travelling to? A) Local newspaper B) TravelHealthPro website C) Social media D) Travel agency E) Library
B
Which types of cancer are classified as head and neck cancer? A) Oesophageal cancer B) Mouth cancer C) Thyroid cancer D) Brain tumours E) Voice box cancer
B,E
What are the symptoms of mouth cancer? A) Mouth ulcers B) Persistent lumps in the mouth C) Persistent cough D) Nosebleeds E) Hearing loss
A,B
Which areas can be affected by throat cancer? A) Oropharynx B) Hypopharynx C) Nasopharynx D) Parotid glands E) Submandibular glands
A,B,C
What are the main symptoms of laryngeal cancer? A) Persistent hoarseness B) Difficulty swallowing C) Noisy breathing D) Shortness of breath E) Lump in the neck
A,B,C,D,E
Which salivary glands are most commonly affected by salivary gland cancer? A) Parotid glands B) Sublingual glands C) Submandibular glands D) Nasal glands E) Laryngeal glands
A
What are the symptoms of nasal and sinus cancer? A) Persistent blocked nose B) Nosebleeds C) Decreased sense of smell D) Mucus running from the nose E) Hearing loss
A,B,C,D
What are the symptoms of nasopharyngeal cancer? A) Lump in the neck B) Blocked or stuffy nose C) Nosebleeds D) Hearing loss E) Persistent cough
A,B,C,D
Which areas can be affected by mouth cancer? A) Lips B) Tongue C) Inside of the cheeks D) Floor or roof of the mouth E) Ears
A,B,C,D
What are the most common symptoms of cancer in the oropharynx or hypopharynx? A) Lump in the neck B) Persistent sore throat C) Difficulty swallowing D) Shortness of breath E) Persistent cough
A,B,C
Which areas are not classified as head and neck cancer? A) Oesophageal cancer B) Thyroid cancer C) Brain tumours D) Eye cancer E) Voice box cancer
A,B,C,D

What is the main symptom of prosopagnosia? A) Difficulty recognising faces B) Difficulty recognising voices C) Difficulty recognising names D) Difficulty recognising objects E) Difficulty recognising places
A,E,

What are some other symptoms of prosopagnosia? A) Difficulty recognising emotions on people's faces B) Difficulty recognising people's age and gender C) Difficulty recognising characters in TV programmes D) Difficulty recognising animals E) Difficulty finding your way around
A,B,C,
What mental health issues may arise due to prosopagnosia? A) Social anxiety B) Depression C) Schizophrenia D) Bipolar disorder E) OCD
A,B,

What should you do if you're struggling to recognise people's faces and it's affecting your life? A) See a GP B) Take medication C) Avoid social situations D) Try to remember names better E) Use voice recognition software
A,D,

What are some things you can do to help with prosopagnosia? A) Ask people to introduce themselves B) Use people's voices or body language C) Make a note of distinctive features D) Avoid meeting new people E) Wear a name tag yourself
A,B,C,
What are some causes of prosopagnosia? A) Brain damage B) Stroke C) Encephalitis D) Alzheimer's disease E) Being autistic
A,B,C,

What is the most common type of prosopagnosia? A) From brain damage B) If you do not develop the ability to recognise faces C) From a head injury D) From inflammation of the brain E) From Alzheimer's disease
B,D,

What should you do if you're referred to a specialist for prosopagnosia? A) Take part in a research project B) Use coping strategies C) Seek treatment for depression D) Seek treatment for anxiety E) Avoid social situations
A,B,C,

What are some strategies to cope with prosopagnosia? A) Tell people about the condition before you meet them B) Use name tags C) Avoid social interactions D) Write down the names of colleagues E) Use voice recognition software
A,B,D,

What are some potential impacts of prosopagnosia on daily life? A) Difficulty forming relationships B) Problems at work or school C) Increased social anxiety D) Better memory for names E) Better recognition of voices
A,B,C,
What are the most common symptoms of tonsillitis? A) Sore throat B) Itchy rash C) Swollen, painful glands in your neck D) Muscle cramps E) Fever
A,E
How can you help treat the symptoms of tonsillitis at home? A) Gargle with warm salty water B) Drink hot coffee C) Get plenty of rest D) Take aspirin E) Drink cool drinks to soothe the throat
A,E
What are the severe symptoms of tonsillitis that might require urgent medical attention? A) Bad breath B) Pus-filled spots on your tonsils C) Mild cough D) Difficulty breathing E) Feeling tired
B,D
What are the common causes of tonsillitis? A) Viral infections B) Allergies C) Bacterial infections D) Stress E) Exposure to cold weather
A,C
What should you do if you have a severe sore throat that quickly gets worse? A) Drink more water B) Call 999 C) Take a nap D) Visit a dentist E) Take over-the-counter painkillers
B,E
How long do symptoms of tonsillitis usually last? A) 1-2 days B) 3-4 days C) 1 week D) 2 weeks E) More than a month
B,C
What should you do if you or your child has a high temperature? A) Go to work B) Stay at home and avoid contact with other people C) Exercise D) Take a hot bath E) Eat spicy food
B,E
What can a pharmacist suggest for tonsillitis? A) Lozenges B) Throat sprays C) Antiseptic solutions D) Hot compresses E) Ice cream
A,C

What are the signs that you should see a GP for tonsillitis? A) Symptoms last more than 1 week B) You keep getting throat infections C) You have a mild cough D) You have a runny nose E) You have a headache
A,B
What are the potential complications of tonsillitis? A) Quinsy B) Asthma C) Diabetes D) Flu E) High blood pressure
A,E
What is a colposcopy? A) A test to examine the heart B) A test to take a closer look at your cervix C) A test to examine the liver D) A test to examine the lungs E) A test to examine the kidneys
B)
Which organ does a colposcopy examine? A) Stomach B) Cervix C) Brain D) Pancreas E) Bladder
B)

Why might a colposcopy be done? A) To check for changes in liver cells B) To check for changes in cervical cells caused by HPV C) To check for changes in lung cells D) To check for changes in heart cells E) To check for changes in skin cells
B)
What tool is used to open the vagina during a colposcopy? A) A scalpel B) A speculum C) A stethoscope D) A needle E) A clamp
B)
What is used to examine the cervix in greater detail during a colposcopy? A) An X-ray machine B) A microscope C) An ultrasound machine D) A CT scanner E) An MRI machine
B)

What is the purpose of taking a sample of cells from the cervix during a colposcopy? A) To test for diabetes B) To test for heart disease C) To test for cervical cancer D) To test for high blood pressure E) To test for asthma
C)
What is the sample of cells taken from the cervix called? A) A biopsy B) A blood test C) A urine test D) A saliva test E) A sweat test
A)
Which virus can cause changes to cervical cells that may be examined with a colposcopy? A) Influenza virus B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) C) Hepatitis virus D) HIV E) Dengue virus
B)
What is the opening to the womb from the vagina called? A) Ovary B) Fallopian tube C) Uterus D) Cervix E) Vulva
D)

What is the purpose of a colposcopy? A) To diagnose a heart condition B) To diagnose cervical cell changes C) To diagnose a lung condition D) To diagnose a liver condition E) To diagnose a kidney condition
B)
Which conditions are medical cannabis likely to be prescribed for in England? A) Depression B) Epilepsy C) Muscle stiffness caused by MS D) Diabetes E) Hypertension
B,C,
What are some of the side effects of medical cannabis? A) Decreased appetite B) Feeling high C) Hallucinations D) Increased blood pressure E) Dizziness
A,B,C,E,
Which of the following can Epidyolex be prescribed for? A) Depression B) Lennox-Gastaut syndrome C) Anxiety D) Dravet syndrome E) Asthma
B,D,
What are the risks associated with THC cannabis products? A) Cancer B) Psychosis C) Dependency D) Heart failure E) Lung disease
B,C,
Which form of cannabis-based medicine is used for MS-related muscle spasticity? A) Epidyolex B) Nabilone C) Nabiximols (Sativex) D) CBD oil E) THC oil
C,
Which of the following forms of ID can be used to prove a prescription for medical cannabis? A) Birth certificate B) Photo driving licence C) Proof of age card D) Vaccination card E) Valid passport
B,C,E,
What are the risks of using cannabis products bought illegally off the street? A) Unknown quality B) Unknown ingredients C) Unknown strength D) Legal problems E) Safe to use
A,B,C,D,
Which of the following is true about Nabilone? A) It is a CBD-based medicine B) It is a form of cannabis C) It is taken as a capsule D) It is used for pain relief E) It is a natural form of cannabis
B,C,
Which of the following is true about Epidyolex? A) It contains THC B) It is used for pain relief C) It is used for epilepsy D) It is available over the counter E) It is a form of hemp oil
C,

What are the conditions for getting a prescription for medical cannabis on the NHS? A) It is prescribed by a GP B) It is prescribed by a specialist hospital doctor C) It is prescribed for any form of pain D) It is prescribed for any condition E) It is prescribed for rare forms of epilepsy
B,E,

What is Marfan syndrome? A) A disorder of the body's connective tissues B) A disorder of the body's nervous system C) A disorder of the body's digestive system D) A disorder of the body's immune system E) A disorder of the body's muscular system
A,E
How is Marfan syndrome typically inherited? A) Recessive inheritance B) Autosomal dominant C) X-linked dominant D) Mitochondrial inheritance E) Autosomal recessive
B,E
What are the typical characteristics of Marfan syndrome? A) Short stature B) Abnormally long and slender limbs C) Heart defects D) Vision problems E) Lens dislocation
B,E
What causes the symptoms of Marfan syndrome? A) Increased production of collagen B) Reduced production of fibrillin C) Overactive immune system D) Hormonal imbalance E) Defective fibrillin gene
B,E
How is Marfan syndrome usually diagnosed? A) Blood test B) Thorough physical examination C) MRI scan D) Genetic testing E) Detailed assessment of medical and family history
B,E
What is the treatment focus for Marfan syndrome? A) Curative treatment B) Managing symptoms C) Reducing risk of complications D) Surgery E) Gene therapy
B,C
What is a serious problem that can occur with Marfan syndrome? A) Increased risk of diabetes B) Heart and aorta complications C) Increased risk of cancer D) Vision loss E) Joint pain
B,E
What is the prevalence of Marfan syndrome in the UK? A) 1 in 1,000 B) 1 in 500 C) 1 in 5,000 D) 1 in 10,000 E) 1 in 20,000
C,E

What is the role of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)? A) Provides treatment B) Helps researchers better understand rare diseases C) Provides counseling D) Provides financial assistance E) Conducts clinical trials
B,E

How does the defective fibrillin gene affect the body? A) Causes bones to grow shorter B) Causes parts of the body to stretch abnormally C) Increases muscle strength D) Reduces blood flow E) Results in abnormal bone growth
B,E
Which of the following conditions can NSAIDs relieve symptoms of? A) Headaches B) Painful periods C) Sprains and strains D) Colds E) Flu
Which of the following are types of NSAIDs? A) Ibuprofen B) Naproxen C) Diclofenac D) Celecoxib E) Mefenamic acid

Which of the following should you ask a pharmacist or doctor for advice before taking an NSAID? A) If you are over 65 years of age B) If you are pregnant or trying for a baby C) If you have asthma D) If you have had an allergic reaction to NSAIDs in the past E) If you have had stomach ulcers in the past
Which of the following are possible side effects of NSAIDs? A) Indigestion B) Stomach ulcers C) Headaches D) Drowsiness E) Dizziness
Which of the following medicines should you be particularly careful about taking with NSAIDs? A) Another NSAID B) Low-dose aspirin C) Warfarin D) Ciclosporin E) Diuretics

What should you do if you take too much of an NSAID? A) Contact your GP B) Call NHS 111 C) Call 999 for an ambulance immediately if experiencing serious effects D) Seek medical advice E) All of the above
Which of the following are alternatives to NSAIDs for pain relief? A) Paracetamol B) NSAID creams and gels C) Physiotherapy D) Different medicines and therapies E) Safe medicines for most people
Which of the following are conditions that NSAIDs can help with? A) Arthritis B) Coronavirus (COVID-19) C) Conditions causing long-term pain D) Headaches E) Painful periods
Which of the following are forms in which NSAIDs are available? A) Tablets B) Capsules C) Suppositories D) Creams E) Gels

Which of the following are reasons to get medical advice before taking an NSAID? A) You have any problems with your heart B) You have any problems with your liver C) You have any problems with your kidneys D) You have any problems with your blood pressure E) You have any problems with your circulation
What is the PSA test used for? A) To check for heart conditions B) To check for prostate conditions C) To check for lung conditions D) To check for skin conditions E) To check for liver conditions
B)
What does PSA stand for? A) Prostate Specific Antigen B) Prostate Specific Activity C) Prostate Specific Antibody D) Prostate Specific Analysis E) Prostate Specific Agglutinin
A)
What symptoms may indicate the need for a PSA test? A) Chest pain B) Peeing more than usual C) Shortness of breath D) Blood in your pee E) Problems getting or keeping an erection
B,D,E
Who can ask their GP for a PSA test? A) Men aged 40 or over B) Men aged 50 or over C) Women aged 50 or over D) Anyone with a prostate aged 50 or over E) Only men with symptoms
B,D
What should you avoid for 48 hours before a PSA test? A) Eating B) Drinking C) Anal sex D) Exercise E) Ejaculating
C,D,E
How is a PSA test usually performed? A) Urine test B) Blood test C) Saliva test D) Rectal examination E) X-ray
B)
What other tests might be performed alongside a PSA test? A) MRI scan B) Pee test C) Rectal examination D) Blood test E) Chest X-ray
A,B,C
What can a high PSA level indicate besides prostate cancer? A) Heart disease B) Enlarged prostate (benign prostate enlargement) C) Liver disease D) Lung cancer E) Skin cancer
B)

What should you do if you are worried about needles during a PSA test? A) Avoid the test B) Tell the healthcare professional C) Take a sedative D) Bring someone with you E) Request an alternative test
B,D
How long does it typically take to get PSA test results? A) A few hours B) 1 to 2 weeks C) A few days D) A few months E) Immediately
B)
What is the primary cause of scurvy? A) Lack of vitamin C in the diet B) Excessive vitamin D intake C) Bacterial infection D) Low iron levels E) Too much sugar intake
A
Which of the following is a symptom of scurvy? A) Dry skin B) Feeling very tired and weak all the time C) Frequent urination D) High blood pressure E) Loss of appetite
B
Which group is at higher risk of developing scurvy? A) Athletes B) People who eat very little food C) Heavy meat eaters D) People who eat a lot of dairy E) People who drink a lot of water
B
How is mild scurvy usually treated? A) With antibiotics B) By adding some vitamin C to the diet C) With surgery D) With blood transfusions E) With steroids
B
What vitamin deficiency does scurvy indicate? A) Vitamin A B) Vitamin B12 C) Vitamin C D) Vitamin E E) Vitamin K
C
Which of the following is a source of vitamin C? A) Red meat B) Fish C) Fresh fruit and vegetables D) Dairy products E) Nuts
C
What should you do if you suspect you or your child are at risk of scurvy and feel very tired and weak all the time? A) Call 999 B) See a GP C) Take painkillers D) Drink more water E) Eat more meat
B
Which of the following is an urgent symptom of scurvy? A) Nausea B) Swollen, bleeding gums C) Headache D) Cough E) Sneezing
B
Which of the following can affect your diet and increase the risk of scurvy? A) Regular exercise B) Chemotherapy C) Sleeping a lot D) Drinking coffee E) Watching TV
B
Which specialist might a GP refer you to for treating scurvy? A) Dentist B) Physiotherapist C) Specialist D) Optometrist E) Chiropractor
C
What are common signs of an underactive thyroid? A) Fatigue B) Weight loss C) Tiredness D) Feeling depressed E) Sensitivity to the cold
C,D,
Which treatments are commonly used for an underactive thyroid? A) Hormone tablets B) Surgery C) Radiation therapy D) Dietary supplements E) Insulin injections
A,D,

What are the main causes of an underactive thyroid? A) Immune system attacking the thyroid gland B) Viral infection C) Damage to the thyroid during treatments for thyroid cancer D) Genetic predisposition E) Excessive exercise
A,C,
What is the primary test for diagnosing an underactive thyroid? A) X-ray B) MRI scan C) Thyroid function test D) Blood pressure test E) ECG
C,D,
Which hormones are primarily produced by the thyroid gland? A) Triiodothyronine (T3) B) Thyroxine (T4) C) Insulin D) Adrenaline E) Cortisol
A,B,
What are the potential complications if an underactive thyroid is not treated? A) Heart disease B) Goitre C) Weight gain D) Diabetes E) Myxoedema coma
A,E,
How often do all babies in the UK get screened for congenital hypothyroidism? A) At birth B) At 1 year old C) At 5 days old D) At 1 month old E) At 2 years old
C,D,
What are the symptoms that should prompt a visit to the GP for an underactive thyroid? A) Tiredness B) High fever C) Weight gain D) Depression E) Muscle aches
A,E,
What is the standard treatment for an underactive thyroid? A) Levothyroxine B) Antibiotics C) Chemotherapy D) Physical therapy E) Aspirin
A,E,
What body processes does the thyroid gland help regulate? A) Digestion B) Metabolism C) Respiration D) Circulation E) Excretion
B,D,
Which of the following are symptoms of atherosclerosis? A) Chest pain B) Pain in your arms and legs C) Feeling short of breath D) Feeling confused E) Feeling cold
A,B,C,D
What can an NHS health check detect if you are over 40? A) Early signs of heart disease B) Kidney disease C) Dementia D) Type 2 diabetes E) Flu
A,B,C,D

When should you seek urgent GP advice or get help from NHS 111? A) If you have chest pain that comes and goes B) If you feel short of breath C) If you have pain in your arms and legs when walking or exercising D) If you have a headache E) If you have a fever
A,B,C
What increases your chances of getting atherosclerosis? A) Being over 65 years of age B) Smoking C) High cholesterol D) High blood pressure E) Lack of exercise
A,B,C,D

What should you do to help with atherosclerosis? A) Eat healthily and eat less saturated fat and sugar B) Exercise regularly C) Maintain a healthy weight D) Keep your blood sugar levels under control if you have diabetes E) Drink more alcohol
A,B,C,D

Which medicines might be offered to lower your risk of having a heart attack or stroke due to atherosclerosis? A) Statins B) Medicines to lower your blood pressure C) Medicines to lower your risk of blood clots D) Medicines to lower your blood sugar levels if you have diabetes E) Antibiotics
A,B,C,D
What can atherosclerosis cause if not treated? A) Heart attacks B) Stroke C) Peripheral arterial disease D) Other types of cardiovascular disease E) Asthma
A,B,C,D

When should you call 999 regarding atherosclerosis complications? A) Signs of a heart attack – pain like a tight band or heavy weight in your chest B) Signs of a stroke – face dropping on 1 side, cannot hold both your arms up, difficulty speaking C) Difficulty breathing – gasping for breath, choking, not able to get any words out D) Sudden confusion – unable to think or speak clearly, suddenly do not know where you are E) Severe headache
A,B,C,D

What is atherosclerosis? A) Narrowing of the arteries B) Increased risk of heart attack and stroke C) Fatty deposits build up in the arteries D) Difficulty for blood to flow through arteries E) A type of infection
A,B,C,D

What are some lifestyle changes that can help stop atherosclerosis from getting worse? A) Stopping smoking B) Eating healthily C) Exercising regularly D) Maintaining a healthy weight E) Eating more sugar
A,B,C,D

Which of the following are common symptoms of tuberculosis (TB)? A) a cough that lasts more than 3 weeks B) feeling tired or exhausted C) a high temperature or night sweats D) loss of appetite E) feeling generally unwell
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you've had a cough for more than 3 weeks? A) See a GP B) Call 999 C) Ignore it D) Take over-the-counter medicine E) Visit a dentist
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you have a stiff neck and a severe headache? A) Call 999 B) Go to A&E C) See a GP D) Take ibuprofen E) Visit a chiropractor
A,B,C,D
Which of the following tests can be used to check for tuberculosis (TB)? A) an X-ray B) an ultrasound C) an echocardiogram D) a CT scan E) a brain scan
A,B,C,D
What is the main treatment for tuberculosis (TB)? A) Antibiotics for at least 6 months B) Surgery C) Radiation therapy D) Homeopathic remedies E) Steroid medicine for a few weeks
A,B,C,D

Who is more likely to get tuberculosis (TB)? A) People who spend a lot of time with someone who has active TB B) People who were born in or lived in an area where TB is more common C) People with a weakened immune system D) People who regularly smoke E) People who have had TB before and it was not treated properly
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you're coughing up blood or mucus (phlegm) with blood in it? A) Ask for an urgent GP appointment B) Get help from NHS 111 C) Call 999 D) Take antibiotics E) Visit a pharmacy
A,B,C,D
What is latent TB? A) TB with no symptoms B) TB with symptoms C) A type of TB that cannot be spread D) A type of TB that requires surgery E) A type of TB that only affects the brain
A,B,C,D
What is a Mantoux test? A) A skin test for TB B) A blood test for TB C) A urine test for TB D) A test that involves injecting liquid under the skin E) A test that requires an X-ray
A,B,C,D

Who is the BCG vaccine recommended for? A) Babies who live in areas of the UK where TB is more common B) Babies and children who live with someone who has TB C) People aged 35 and under who are spending more than 3 months in a country where TB is more common D) Healthcare workers who work with people who have TB E) People over 65 years old
A,B,C,D
What are some common causes of sore or dry lips? A) Cold weather B) Dehydration C) Lip injury D) Lack of exercise E) Excessive sweating
A,B,C,

Which of the following should you do if you have sore or dry lips? A) Use a lip balm containing petroleum jelly B) Apply lip balm with SPF 15 every 2 hours C) Drink plenty of water D) Avoid licking dry lips E) Share lip balms with others
A,B,C,

What should you not do if you have sore or dry lips? A) Pick or bite flaky skin B) Lick dry or cracked lips C) Share lip balms with others D) Wash hands before applying lip balm E) Use a lip balm with SPF 15
A,B,C,
If your lips are hot, painful, and swollen, what should you do? A) See a GP B) Apply ice C) Use a lip balm D) Drink more water E) Take a hot shower
A,C,D,
What can a pharmacist advise you about for sore or dry lips? A) The best treatments B) If you need to see a GP C) How to apply makeup D) Dietary changes E) Exercise regimen
A,B,D,
What might your GP prescribe if you have an infected lip? A) Antibiotic cream B) Antifungal cream C) Painkillers D) Vitamins E) Herbal remedies
A,B,C,
What are some common symptoms of a cold sore? A) Tingling feeling B) Burning sensation C) Itching feeling D) Numbness E) Bleeding
A,B,C,
What can cause sore or dry lips besides cold weather? A) Dry air B) Wind C) Lip injury D) Lack of sleep E) Excessive talking
A,B,C,
Why should you not lick dry or cracked lips? A) It can make them sore B) It can spread germs C) It can slow down healing D) It can cause dehydration E) It can cause cold sores
A,C,D,
What should you do to protect your lips in cold weather? A) Cover your lips with a scarf B) Use a lip balm with SPF C) Drink plenty of water D) Avoid going outside E) Wear a hat
A,B,C,
What are the two main types of diabetes? A) Type 1 and Type 2 B) Type A and Type B C) Type X and Type Y D) Type O and Type P E) Type R and Type S
A

What is gestational diabetes? A) Diabetes that only affects men B) Diabetes that develops during pregnancy C) Diabetes caused by a virus D) Diabetes that only affects children E) Diabetes that is genetic
B

What is non-diabetic hyperglycaemia? A) A condition where blood sugar levels are too low B) A condition where blood sugar levels are normal C) A condition where blood sugar levels are high but not enough to be diagnosed as diabetes D) A condition where blood sugar levels are extremely high E) A condition where blood sugar levels fluctuate daily
C

What symptoms should prompt a visit to the GP for potential diabetes diagnosis? A) Feeling very thirsty B) Peeing more frequently than usual C) Feeling very tired D) Weight loss and loss of muscle bulk E) Itching around the penis or vagina
A,B,C
What can cause type 2 diabetes? A) Diet high in sugar B) Lack of exercise C) Overweight or obesity D) Family history of type 2 diabetes E) Certain medicines such as steroids
C,D,E
How can you manage diabetes? A) Eat healthily B) Take regular exercise C) Have regular checks including blood tests D) Quit smoking E) Cut down on alcohol
A,B,C

What is diabetic retinopathy? A) A condition that affects the heart B) A condition that affects the eyes C) A condition that affects the lungs D) A condition that affects the skin E) A condition that affects the liver
B

What should people with diabetes do regarding their eyesight? A) Ignore any problems B) Only go to the doctor if vision is completely lost C) See a doctor if they notice any problems D) Wait for the next screening appointment E) Only see a specialist if recommended
C
What are the potential complications of diabetes related to the feet? A) Loss of feeling B) Reduced blood supply C) Infections D) Ulcers E) Amputations
A,B,E

What is the NHS Diabetes Prevention Programme designed to help with? A) Helping people make lasting lifestyle changes B) Curing type 1 diabetes C) Providing free medication D) Reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes E) Offering genetic testing
A,D
What is the primary cause of scurvy? A) Not enough vitamin D B) Not enough vitamin C C) Not enough vitamin A D) Not enough vitamin E E) Not enough protein
B

Which group is at risk of scurvy? A) People who eat a balanced diet B) People who eat fresh fruits and vegetables C) People who smoke D) People who consume a lot of protein E) People who have a poor diet while pregnant or breastfeeding
E
What are the initial symptoms of scurvy? A) Feeling energetic B) Feeling irritable and sad all the time C) Feeling very tired and weak all the time D) Feeling happy E) Feeling excited
B, C

What type of diet can lead to scurvy? A) A diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables B) A diet with no fresh fruits or vegetables C) A diet high in carbohydrates D) A diet high in protein E) A diet high in fats
B
What should you do if you suspect scurvy and have swollen, bleeding gums? A) Wait for it to pass B) Call 999 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Ignore it E) Go to the dentist
C
What is the best way to prevent a vitamin C deficiency? A) Taking vitamin D supplements B) Eating a healthy, balanced diet C) Drinking plenty of water D) Avoiding all fats E) Eating a lot of meat
B
What is the main source of vitamin C? A) Meat B) Dairy products C) Fruit and vegetables D) Grains E) Nuts
C
What should you do if you have a sudden, severe headache and suspect scurvy? A) Call 999 B) Take painkillers C) Wait for it to pass D) Go to the dentist E) Call a friend
A
What additional step might a GP recommend for treating scurvy? A) Taking vitamin C supplements B) Taking antibiotics C) Taking painkillers D) Taking vitamin D supplements E) Drinking more water
A
What action should you take if you suspect scurvy and have severe chest pain? A) Call 999 B) Take a nap C) Go for a walk D) Eat more protein E) Drink more water
A
What are common causes of twitches? A) Stress and anxiety B) Drinking caffeine or alcohol C) Some medicines D) Tiredness and exhaustion E) Excessive sugar intake
A,B,C,D,
How long do twitches usually last? A) A few seconds B) A few days or weeks C) A few months D) A few years E) Indefinitely
B,
What should you do if a twitch lasts more than 2 weeks? A) See a GP B) Stop taking all medicines C) Drink more caffeine D) Ignore it E) Self-medicate
A,
What should you not do if you have a twitch? A) Drink lots of caffeine B) Drink lots of alcohol C) Stop taking a prescribed medicine without medical advice D) Get plenty of rest E) Try to relax
A,B,C,
What are some conditions that can cause a twitch? A) Benign fasciculation syndrome B) Dystonia C) Motor neurone disease D) Common cold E) Flu
A,B,C,
What parts of the body are commonly affected by twitches? A) Eyes B) Legs C) Ears D) Nose E) Tongue
A,B,

What might a GP do if your twitch does not go away? A) Check for causes like stress or a medicine you're taking B) Refer you to a specialist C) Ask you to come back if the twitch has not stopped in a few weeks D) Prescribe antibiotics E) Advise you to stop all activities
A,B,C,

What are some things you can do to help stop a twitch? A) Get plenty of rest B) Try to find ways to relax C) Stretch and massage any muscles affected by cramps D) Try not to worry about it E) Drink more alcohol
A,B,C,D,
What should you do if you think a prescribed medicine might be causing your twitch? A) See a GP B) Stop taking the medicine immediately C) Drink more caffeine D) Ignore it E) Self-medicate
A,
What happens if you have a twitch in more than one place? A) See a GP B) Ignore it C) Stop all physical activities D) Drink more alcohol E) Self-medicate
A,
Which of the following is the most common cause of teeth grinding? A) Poor diet B) Stress and anxiety C) Physical injury D) Genetic factors E) Bacterial infection
B) Stress and anxiety,
What is a common symptom of teeth grinding? A) Sore throat B) Painful jaw C) Itchy eyes D) Stomach ache E) Fever
B) Painful jaw,
Which type of antidepressant is linked to teeth grinding? A) Tricyclics B) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) C) Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) D) Beta blockers E) Antipsychotics
B) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs),
What can help reduce jaw pain or swelling from teeth grinding? A) Hot compress B) Massage C) Ice pack D) Antibiotics E) Herbal tea
C) Ice pack,
Which of the following is a recommended treatment for teeth grinding? A) Surgery B) Mouth guard or mouth splint C) Acupuncture D) Physical therapy E) Meditation
B) Mouth guard or mouth splint,
What should you do if you grind your teeth and have tooth damage? A) See a dentist B) See a chiropractor C) See a nutritionist D) See a physical therapist E) See a psychologist
A) See a dentist,
Which of the following is not a symptom of teeth grinding? A) Earache B) Disturbed sleep C) Nausea D) Headaches E) Face, neck, and shoulder pain
C) Nausea,
What can a GP help with related to teeth grinding? A) Dental fillings B) Reducing stress C) Orthodontic treatment D) Root canal therapy E) Teeth whitening
B) Reducing stress,
Which of the following is a common sleep problem linked to teeth grinding? A) Insomnia B) Sleep apnoea C) Narcolepsy D) Restless leg syndrome E) Hypersomnia
B) Sleep apnoea,
What should you avoid if you have tooth or jaw pain from teeth grinding? A) Chewing gum B) Drinking water C) Eating soft foods D) Brushing teeth E) Taking vitamins
A) Chewing gum,
Which of the following are symptoms of an MRSA infection under the skin? A) Itchy skin B) Painful and swollen area C) Leaks pus or liquid D) Feels cold E) Looks red
B,C
What should you do if you have a cut or wound that is painful, swollen, and leaks pus or liquid? A) Ignore it B) Call 999 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Apply ice E) Take painkillers
C,B

What are the immediate actions required if someone has difficulty breathing, such as breathlessness or breathing very fast? A) Call 999 B) Give them water C) Apply a bandage D) Drive them to A&E E) Give them antibiotics
A,D
Which of the following are treatments for MRSA? A) Antibiotic tablets B) Surgery C) Herbal remedies D) Physical therapy E) Antibiotics given by injection or a drip
A,E

Who is at a higher risk of getting an MRSA infection? A) People visiting care homes B) People with long stays in hospital C) People with a weakened immune system D) People with a break in their skin E) People with a cold
B,C
What should you do if you're visiting someone in a care home or hospital? A) Avoid touching anything B) Wash or sanitize your hands C) Wear a mask D) Stay away if you have a cold E) Bring food
B,D
What does a screening test for MRSA before going into hospital involve? A) Blood test B) Wiping swabs on the inside of your nostril C) Urine test D) X-ray E) Wiping swabs on the back of your mouth
B,E
If the screening test shows you have MRSA on your skin, what treatment will you need? A) Antibiotics B) Special nasal cream or spray C) Body wash and shampoo D) Physical therapy E) Surgery
B,C
How does MRSA usually spread? A) Through the air B) Through touch C) Through water D) Through food E) Through blood transfusion
B,C
What should you do if you suspect an MRSA infection has spread to your blood or lungs? A) Call 999 B) Take over-the-counter medication C) Apply a cream D) Rest at home E) Go to A&E
A,E

What are the main types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)? A) IBS and IBD B) Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis C) Celiac disease and diverticulitis D) Gastritis and peptic ulcer E) Constipation and hemorrhoids
B)
Which of the following is a symptom of IBD? A) Headache B) Diarrhoea that lasts longer than 4 weeks C) Joint pain D) Fever E) Sneezing
B)
What should you do if you have severe tummy pain related to IBD? A) Take a painkiller B) Call your GP C) Call 999 or go to A&E D) Rest at home E) Drink plenty of water
C)
What is one of the treatments for IBD? A) Physical therapy B) Steroids C) Acupuncture D) Massage E) Chiropractic care
B)
IBD is different from which condition? A) IBS B) Celiac disease C) Ulcerative colitis D) Crohn's disease E) Gastritis
A)
Which charity provides help and support for people living with IBD? A) Cancer Research UK B) British Heart Foundation C) Crohn's and Colitis UK D) Alzheimer's Society E) Diabetes UK
C)
What should you do if you have blood or mucus in your poo? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Drink more water D) Take an antacid E) Exercise more
B)
How long should diarrhoea last before you see a GP? A) 2 days B) 4 days C) 7 days D) 10 days E) 14 days
C)
What is one of the causes of IBD? A) Bacterial infection B) Your immune system attacking your bowel C) Food poisoning D) Stress E) Allergic reaction
B)
What should you do if you are vomiting blood or poo? A) Rest at home B) Call 999 or go to A&E C) Take an antacid D) Drink more fluids E) See a GP
B)
Which of the following is a symptom of vulval cancer? A) Persistent itch in the vulva B) Nausea C) Hair loss D) Shortness of breath E) Fever
A)
What is the most common age group affected by vulval cancer? A) Women under 30 B) Women between 30-40 C) Women over 65 D) Women under 50 E) Teenage girls
C)
Which part of the female body is affected by vulval cancer? A) Ovaries B) Uterus C) Vulva D) Breasts E) Kidneys
C)
