Which of the following is a risk factor for vulval cancer? A) Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) B) High cholesterol C) Diabetes D) High blood pressure E) Obesity
A)
What is the main treatment for vulval cancer? A) Hormone therapy B) Surgery to remove the cancerous tissue C) Alternative medicine D) Acupuncture E) Physical therapy
B)

Which of the following is NOT a symptom of vulval cancer? A) Persistent itch in the vulva B) Pain in the vulva C) A mole on the vulva that changes shape or colour D) Weight gain E) Bleeding from the vulva
D)
What can help reduce the risk of vulval cancer? A) Practising safer sex B) Eating a high-fat diet C) Drinking alcohol D) Avoiding exercise E) Taking vitamin supplements
A)
What is the survival rate for women diagnosed with vulval cancer? A) 3 in every 10 women B) 5 in every 10 women C) 7 in every 10 women D) 9 in every 10 women E) 2 in every 10 women
C)
Which of the following is a skin condition that can increase the risk of vulval cancer? A) Eczema B) Psoriasis C) Lichen sclerosus D) Acne E) Rosacea
C)

Which of the following is a sign that you should see a GP regarding vulval cancer? A) Changes in the usual appearance of your vulva B) Changes in your menstrual cycle C) Changes in your appetite D) Changes in your sleep pattern E) Changes in your vision
A)

What should you do if you have severe difficulty breathing – you’re gasping, choking or not able to get words out? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Drink a glass of water C) Take a nap D) Go for a walk E) Call a friend
A
What should you do if your chest feels tight or heavy? A) Lie down and rest B) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately C) Take a deep breath D) Eat something E) Go to the gym
B
What should you do if you have pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck and jaw? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Take painkillers C) Go for a jog D) Listen to music E) Watch TV
A
What should you do if your lips or skin are turning very pale, blue or grey? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Apply makeup C) Take a shower D) Go to a spa E) Eat some candy
A
What should you do if you feel suddenly confused? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Try to solve a puzzle C) Read a book D) Watch a movie E) Go to sleep
A

What should you do if your child has difficulty breathing – they may make grunting noises or suck their stomach in under their ribcage? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Give them a toy C) Sing a song D) Play a game E) Watch a cartoon
A

What should you do if your child is suddenly confused (agitated, behaving oddly or crying constantly)? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Give them a snack C) Read them a story D) Play with them E) Let them watch TV
A

What should you do if your child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do - their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face? A) Call 999 or go to A&E immediately B) Give them a drink C) Sing a lullaby D) Take a photo E) Go for a walk
A
What should you do if you have difficulty breathing – you may be more short of breath than usual? A) Contact NHS 111 B) Go for a run C) Eat some chocolate D) Play video games E) Take a bath
A
What should you do if you've been coughing for 3 weeks or more? A) See a GP B) Take cough syrup C) Drink hot tea D) Watch a movie E) Go shopping
A
What is a perforated eardrum? A) A hole or tear in your eardrum B) A buildup of wax C) A thickening of the eardrum D) A growth on the eardrum E) A blockage in the ear canal
A,D
How long does a perforated eardrum usually take to heal? A) 1 week B) 2 months C) 6 months D) 1 year E) 2 weeks
B,E
What are common symptoms of a perforated eardrum? A) Hearing loss B) A ringing or buzzing sound in your ear C) Earache or ear pain D) Itching in your ear E) A rash on your ear
A,B
What can cause a perforated eardrum? A) Ear infection B) Injury C) Loud noise D) Sudden change in air pressure E) Excessive sneezing
A,D
What should you do if you have sudden hearing loss? A) Ask for an urgent GP appointment B) Wait for it to go away C) Take a nap D) Drink plenty of water E) Get help from NHS 111
A,E
What treatment might a GP prescribe for a perforated eardrum? A) Antibiotics B) Steroids C) Painkillers D) Surgery E) Eardrops
A,D
What should you do if your symptoms have not started to improve after a few weeks? A) Go back to your GP B) Try home remedies C) Wait another month D) Take a vacation E) Ignore the symptoms
A,B
What should you do to ease pain from a perforated eardrum? A) Take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen B) Apply heat C) Use a cold compress D) Take antibiotics E) Use earplugs
A,D
What should you not do if you have a perforated eardrum? A) Go swimming B) Blow your nose too hard C) Put cotton buds in your ear D) Use eardrops E) Wash your hair
A,C
Is it safe to fly if you have a perforated eardrum? A) Yes B) No C) Only if you wear earplugs D) Only if you take medication E) Only if a doctor approves
A,E

What is deafblindness? A) A complete loss of hearing and sight B) A combination of sight and hearing loss C) A condition affecting only the elderly D) A temporary sensory loss E) A condition affecting only one sense
B)
What is another term for deafblindness? A) Dual sensory loss B) Single sensory loss C) Complete sensory loss D) Temporary sensory loss E) Selective sensory loss
A)
Who is most commonly affected by deafblindness? A) Only babies B) Only young children C) Only adults D) Only older adults E) People of all ages
D)
What is a sign of deafblindness in older people? A) Increased appetite B) Difficulty following a conversation C) Increased energy levels D) Improved vision E) Frequent headaches
B)
What should you do if you think your hearing or eyesight is getting worse? A) Wait and see if it improves B) Visit your GP C) Ignore it D) Consult a friend E) Take over-the-counter medication
B)
What is a common cause of deafblindness in babies? A) Flu B) Rubella C) Common cold D) Chickenpox E) Measles
B)
What is a potential cause of deafblindness in adults? A) High blood pressure B) Cataracts C) Diabetes D) Asthma E) Allergies
B)

What is one of the general aims of care for a deafblind person? A) To improve physical strength B) To preserve and maximise any remaining sight or hearing C) To increase social media usage D) To reduce calorie intake E) To enhance night vision
B)
What is a method of communication that can be taught to deafblind people? A) Sign language B) Hands-on signing C) Lip reading D) Whistling E) Morse code
B)
What organization provides advice and support for deafblind people in the UK? A) NHS B) Sense C) Red Cross D) Save the Children E) UNICEF
B)

What is the normal resting heart rate? A) 50 to 90 beats per minute (bpm) B) 60 to 100 beats per minute (bpm) C) 70 to 110 beats per minute (bpm) D) 80 to 120 beats per minute (bpm) E) 90 to 130 beats per minute (bpm)
B
What can trigger supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)? A) Exercise B) Caffeine C) Alcohol D) Drugs E) Rice
B,C,D
When does supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) often start for the first time? A) In infants B) In children and young adults C) In elderly D) In middle-aged adults E) In newborns
B
What are some symptoms of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)? A) Chest pain B) Feeling weak C) Feeling breathless D) Feeling tired E) Headache
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you keep getting a fast heartbeat? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Drink more water D) Exercise more E) Take painkillers
B
What test might you need if you keep getting a fast heartbeat? A) Blood test B) Electrocardiogram (ECG) C) X-ray D) MRI E) CT scan
B
What should you do if you have a fast heartbeat with shortness of breath, chest pain, or feeling faint? A) Call 999 B) Lie down C) Drink coffee D) Take a nap E) Go for a walk
A

What lifestyle changes can you make to reduce episodes of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)? A) Cutting down on caffeine B) Stopping smoking C) Reducing alcohol intake D) Eating more chocolate E) Increasing salt intake
A,B,C
What treatments might you need in hospital for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)? A) Medicines B) Cardioversion C) Catheter ablation D) Surgery E) Physical therapy
A,B,C
What is the most common permanent cure for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)? A) Medicines B) Cardioversion C) Catheter ablation D) Surgery E) Lifestyle changes
C

Which of the following are symptoms of a staph skin infection? A) A painful red lump or bump on the skin B) Hot, red and swollen skin C) Sores, crusts or blisters D) Redness affecting the skin or eyelids E) A red, swollen eyelid
What are some types of staph skin infections? A) Boil B) Carbuncle C) Abscess D) Cellulitis E) Pneumonia

When should you see a GP if you have a staph skin infection? A) If it's getting worse or spreading quickly B) If it lasts more than a week C) If you have a weakened immune system D) If you keep getting staph infections E) If you have a headache

How can staph bacteria spread to others? A) Through close skin contact B) Through sharing things like towels or toothbrushes C) Through droplets in coughs and sneezes D) Through ingestion E) Through blood transfusion
What are some serious infections that staph bacteria can cause? A) Blood poisoning B) Toxic shock syndrome C) Cellulitis D) Impetigo E) Conjunctivitis

What are some hygiene practices to reduce the chances of getting a staph infection? A) Wash your hands with soap and water regularly B) Keep your skin clean by having a bath or shower every day C) Keep any cuts clean and covered D) Use disposable tissues to blow your nose E) Share towels and razors
Which parts of the body commonly harbor staph bacteria? A) Nose B) Armpits C) Buttocks D) Fingernails E) Ear canals
What are some conditions that can affect the eyes due to staph bacteria? A) Stye B) Conjunctivitis C) Cataract D) Glaucoma E) Macular degeneration
What are some conditions that can affect the skin due to staph bacteria? A) Boils B) Impetigo C) Cellulitis D) Eczema E) Psoriasis

What are some preventive measures for staph infections? A) Do not share towels, washcloths, bed linen, toothbrushes and razors B) Keep any cuts clean and covered C) Wash your hands with soap and water regularly D) Use disposable tissues to blow your nose E) Avoid close contact with others
What are the main ways people with aphasia have trouble with language? A) Reading B) Listening C) Speaking D) Drawing E) Typing or writing
A,C
What are some common causes of aphasia? A) Stroke B) Severe head injury C) Brain tumour D) Fever E) Allergies
A,B
Which parts of the brain are responsible for aphasia? A) Left side B) Right side C) Frontal lobe D) Occipital lobe E) Temporal lobe
A,E
What are some symptoms of aphasia? A) Difficulty speaking B) Difficulty walking C) Difficulty reading D) Difficulty hearing E) Difficulty typing
A,C
What types of aphasia are there? A) Expressive B) Receptive C) Visual D) Auditory E) Olfactory
A,B
What tests are used to diagnose aphasia? A) CT scan B) MRI scan C) Blood test D) X-ray E) EEG
A,B
What is the main type of treatment for aphasia? A) Speech and language therapy B) Medication C) Surgery D) Diet changes E) Physical therapy
A,E
What are some complications of aphasia? A) Isolation B) Anxiety C) Depression D) High blood pressure E) Diabetes
A,B
What are some progressive neurological conditions that can cause aphasia? A) Dementia B) Arthritis C) Heart disease D) Diabetes E) Cancer
A,E
What are some alternative ways of communicating for people with aphasia? A) Drawing pictures B) Using sign language C) Typing on a computer D) Speaking slowly E) Writing letters
C,E
What is the correct pronunciation of Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Gee-yon Bar-ray B) Gay-lan Bar-ray C) Ghee-yan Bar-ray D) Guy-lan Bar-ray E) Ghee-yan Bar-ree
Which part of the body is usually affected first by Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Chest B) Face C) Arms and legs D) Stomach E) Back
What is the typical duration over which symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome get worse? A) 1 week B) 2 to 4 weeks C) 1 month D) 2 months E) 3 months
What is one of the initial symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Itchiness B) Tingling C) Rash D) Fever E) Sweating
Which type of specialist would you be referred to if you are suspected of having Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Cardiologist B) Dermatologist C) Neurologist D) Oncologist E) Psychiatrist
What is the main treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Surgery B) Antibiotics C) Immunotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Physical therapy
How long does the average recovery from Guillain-Barré syndrome take? A) 1 month B) 3 months C) 6 months D) 1 year E) 2 years

What is one of the longer-term problems that some people may experience after recovering from Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Hair loss B) Tingling in the hands and feet C) Loss of taste D) Increased appetite E) Skin discoloration

What kind of therapy might be offered to help manage everyday tasks after recovering from Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Aromatherapy B) Occupational therapy C) Hydrotherapy D) Music therapy E) Art therapy
What is thought to cause Guillain-Barré syndrome? A) Bacterial infection B) Viral infection C) Problems with the immune system D) Genetic disorder E) Environmental factors
What causes scabies? A) Bacteria B) Viruses C) Mites D) Fungi E) Parasites
C)
How is scabies spread? A) Through the air B) Through water C) Through close skin contact D) Through insect bites E) Through contaminated food
C)
What is a common symptom of scabies? A) Severe pain B) Intense itching C) High fever D) Loss of appetite E) Dizziness
B)
What kind of rash does scabies cause? A) A flat rash B) A raised rash or spots C) A scaly rash D) A blistering rash E) A dry rash
B)
Where does the scabies rash usually appear? A) On the face B) On the back C) Between the fingers D) On the legs E) On the feet
C)
What should you do if you suspect you have scabies? A) Wait for it to go away B) See a pharmacist C) Take antibiotics D) Apply ice E) Drink more water
B)
What is the treatment for scabies? A) Antibiotics B) Antiviral medication C) Cream or lotion applied to the body D) Injections E) Surgery
C)
How often should you repeat the treatment for scabies? A) Daily B) Weekly C) Monthly D) Once E) Twice
B)
Who needs to be treated for scabies if you have it? A) Only you B) Everyone in your home C) Only those with symptoms D) Only children E) Only adults
B)
What should you do with clothing and bedding if someone in your home has scabies? A) Throw them away B) Wash them at 60C or higher C) Freeze them D) Burn them E) Leave them outside
B)
Where do swollen glands usually occur? A) On the forehead B) On each side of the neck C) On the back D) Under the chin E) In the armpits
B,D,E
What are some common symptoms that may accompany swollen glands? A) Sore throat B) Cough C) High temperature D) Dizziness E) Itchiness
A,B,C
How long do swollen glands usually take to go down? A) A few hours B) 1 to 2 weeks C) A month D) A few days E) Several months
B,D
What are some ways to ease the symptoms of swollen glands? A) Resting B) Drinking plenty of fluids C) Taking painkillers like paracetamol D) Applying heat E) Eating spicy foods
A,B,C

When should you see a GP about swollen glands? A) If they're getting bigger B) If they feel hard C) If you have no other signs of illness D) If you have swollen glands just above or below your collar bone E) If you have a mild headache
A,B,D
What are some common causes of swollen glands? A) Colds B) Tonsillitis C) Leukaemia D) Allergies E) Ear or throat infections
A,B,E
What should you do if you have swollen glands and difficulty breathing? A) Wait a few days B) Drink more water C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Use a humidifier E) Take antihistamines
C
What are some symptoms that indicate you should see a GP for swollen glands? A) Night sweats B) Very high temperature C) Difficulty swallowing D) Itching E) Feeling hot and shivery
A,B,E
What are some common viral infections that can cause swollen glands? A) Glandular fever B) Flu C) Measles D) Chickenpox E) Common cold
A,E
What are some serious causes of swollen glands? A) Leukaemia B) Lymphoma C) Diabetes D) Asthma E) High blood pressure
A,B
How long does a cough typically last? A) 1 week B) 3 to 4 weeks C) 2 months D) 6 weeks E) 1 year
B)
What should you do if you have a cough? A) See a GP immediately B) Rest and drink plenty of fluids C) Take antibiotics D) Go to the emergency room E) Ignore it
B)
Which of the following can help treat a cough? A) Paracetamol B) Ibuprofen C) Hot lemon and honey D) Pelargonium E) All of the above
E)

What should you do if you have a high temperature or do not feel well enough to do your normal activities? A) Go to work B) Avoid contact with other people C) Exercise D) Eat spicy food E) Drink alcohol
B)
What can a pharmacist help with if you have a cough? A) Cough syrup B) Cough medicine C) Cough sweets D) Decongestants E) A and B
E)

When should you see a GP for a cough? A) If you've had a cough for more than 3 weeks B) If you're losing weight for no reason C) If you have a weakened immune system D) If you're coughing up blood E) All of the above
E)
What should you do if your cough is very bad or quickly gets worse? A) Wait it out B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Take a hot shower D) Go for a run E) Drink cold water
B)
What might a GP do to find out what's causing your cough? A) Listen to your chest with a stethoscope B) Take a sample of any mucus C) Order an X-ray D) Refer you to hospital E) All of the above
E)
When are antibiotics prescribed for coughs? A) Always B) Never C) Only if you have a bacterial infection D) Only if you're at risk of complications E) C and D
E)
What are the most common causes of coughs? A) Smoking B) Heartburn C) Allergies D) Infections E) All of the above
E)
What is the typical age range for children most commonly affected by Reye's syndrome? A) 0-4 years B) 5-14 years C) 15-18 years D) 19-25 years E) 26-30 years
B)
Which symptom of Reye's syndrome typically appears 1 to 3 weeks after a child recovers from a virus like flu or chickenpox? A) Fever B) Cough C) Loss of consciousness D) Rash E) Vomiting
E)

What immediate action should you take if your child has a fit or seizure due to Reye's syndrome? A) Wait and see B) Give them aspirin C) Call the pediatrician D) Call 999 or go to A&E E) Try home remedies
D)
Which type of medicine is linked to the development of Reye's syndrome in young people and children under 16? A) Antibiotics B) Paracetamol C) Salicylates D) Antihistamines E) Steroids
C)
What test may include the insertion of a thin needle into the lower back to remove a small amount of spinal fluid for testing? A) Blood test B) Lumbar puncture C) EEG D) CT scan E) Liver biopsy
B)
What is one of the treatments for Reye's syndrome that helps prevent dehydration? A) Oxygen machine B) Fluids given directly into a vein C) Surgery D) Antibiotics E) Chemotherapy
B)

What rare genetic condition can sometimes lead to Reye's syndrome in children? A) Cystic fibrosis B) Sickle cell anemia C) Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD) D) Hemophilia E) Down syndrome
C)

What should you do if your child is drowsy or lacks energy and you suspect Reye's syndrome? A) Wait for it to pass B) Give them aspirin C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 D) Give them a hot bath E) Try over-the-counter remedies
C)

What preventive measure can reduce the chance of a child getting Reye's syndrome? A) Giving them aspirin regularly B) Avoiding vaccinations C) Thinking about getting your child vaccinated against flu and other common viruses D) Feeding them high-sugar foods E) Limiting their physical activity
C)
Which symptom of Reye's syndrome may include changes in behavior, such as being irritable or aggressive? A) High fever B) Skin rash C) Abdominal pain D) Changes in behavior E) Sore throat
D)
What is bronchitis? A) A skin condition B) Inflammation of the heart C) Inflammation of the airways in the lungs D) A mental health disorder E) A type of cancer
C
What is the usual duration for bronchitis to clear up without treatment? A) 1 week B) 2 weeks C) 3 weeks D) 4 weeks E) 6 weeks
C
What is chronic bronchitis also known as? A) Asthma B) Emphysema C) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) D) Allergies E) Pneumonia
C
Which of the following is a symptom of bronchitis? A) Rash B) Chest pain when coughing C) Itchy eyes D) Joint pain E) Hair loss
B
What should you do if you have a cough for more than 3 weeks? A) Ignore it B) Take a nap C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Go shopping E) Drink coffee
C
What should you do if you suddenly feel confused and do not know where you are? A) Call 999 B) Take a walk C) Drink water D) Watch TV E) Sleep
A
What is one of the things you should do to ease the symptoms of bronchitis? A) Exercise vigorously B) Drink plenty of fluids C) Eat spicy food D) Stay up all night E) Go to a party
B
What should you not do if you have bronchitis? A) Do not smoke B) Do not drink water C) Do not sleep D) Do not eat E) Do not take a shower
A
What should you do if you have pale, blue or blotchy skin, lips or tongue? A) Call 999 B) Go for a run C) Eat chocolate D) Listen to music E) Play video games
A
What is one of the treatments for bronchitis if it is caused by a bacterial infection? A) Surgery B) Antibiotics C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Acupuncture
B

What is deafblindness? A) A total loss of hearing and vision B) A combination of sight and hearing loss C) A condition that affects only children D) A condition that affects only adults E) A mild condition that does not affect daily life
B)
What is another term for deafblindness? A) Sensory enhancement B) Dual sensory loss C) Single sensory loss D) Visual impairment E) Auditory impairment
B)
Which age group is most commonly affected by deafblindness? A) Teenagers B) Young adults C) Older adults D) Newborns E) Middle-aged adults
C)

What are some common signs of deafblindness? A) Difficulty moving around unfamiliar places B) Needing to turn up the volume on the television C) Asking others to speak loudly and clearly D) Difficulty following a conversation E) Difficulty hearing noises such as a knock at the door
What should you do if you think your hearing or eyesight is getting worse? A) Visit your GP B) Ignore it C) Self-medicate D) Wait for it to get better E) Consult a friend
A)
What are some causes of deafblindness? A) Age-related hearing loss B) Genetic conditions like Usher syndrome C) Infections like rubella D) Cerebral palsy E) Eye problems like cataracts

What is the aim of care for a deafblind person? A) To maximize remaining sight or hearing B) To teach alternative methods of communication C) To help retain or develop independence D) To provide medication E) To provide surgery
Which UK-based charity provides advice and support for deafblind people? A) Sense B) Deafblind UK C) Vision UK D) Hearing Aid UK E) Eye Care UK
A),B)
A)
What is the email address for Deafblind UK? A) info@sense.org.uk B) info@deafblind.org.uk C) help@deafblind.org.uk D) support@sense.org.uk E) contact@deafblind.org.uk
B)

What should you do if you are worried about a friend or family member's hearing or eyesight? A) Encourage them to speak to their GP B) Ignore it C) Self-medicate D) Wait for it to get better E) Consult a friend
A)
What is the medical term for low blood sugar? A) Hypoglycaemia B) Hyperglycaemia C) Diabetes D) Insulin E) Glucagon
A
Which of the following is a symptom of low blood sugar? A) Sweating B) Feeling tired C) Feeling dizzy D) Feeling hungry E) Changes in vision
A,B,C,D,E
What should you do if you have symptoms of low blood sugar? A) Eat a sugary snack B) Check your blood sugar C) Take insulin D) Go to sleep E) Drink water
A,B

If someone has severe low blood sugar and becomes unconscious, what should you do first? A) Give them food B) Put them in the recovery position C) Give them a glucagon injection D) Call 999 E) Check their blood sugar
B
What is the recommended first step to treat low blood sugar? A) Eat a sandwich B) Drink fruit juice C) Take insulin D) Go for a walk E) Eat glucose tablets
B,E
What should you do if your blood sugar is still below 4mmol/L after treating low blood sugar? A) Have another sugary snack B) Go to sleep C) Drink alcohol D) Call 999 E) Wait for 30 minutes
A
Which of the following is a condition that can cause low blood sugar in people without diabetes? A) Diabetes B) Addison's disease C) Malnutrition D) Pancreatic tumor E) Insulin injection
B,C,D

What should you do to reduce the risk of low blood sugar if you take medicine for diabetes? A) Follow your treatment plan B) Skip meals C) Drink alcohol D) Carry a glucagon injection kit E) Avoid exercise
A,D
How often should you check your blood sugar while driving if you have diabetes? A) Every hour B) Every 2 hours C) Every 30 minutes D) Every 4 hours E) Before each journey and then every 2 hours
E
Which of the following can cause low blood sugar in people with diabetes? A) Taking too much insulin B) Eating too much C) Exercising without eating D) Drinking a lot of alcohol E) Missing meals
A,C,D,E
What is the most common age group affected by penile cancer? A) 20-30 years old B) 30-40 years old C) Over 50 years old D) 40-50 years old E) Under 20 years old
C)
Penile cancer is considered to be: A) Very common B) Rare C) Moderately common D) Extremely rare E) Average in frequency
B)
Which part of the body does penile cancer affect? A) Prostate B) Kidney C) Penis D) Bladder E) Testes
C)
What does penile cancer primarily affect? A) Females B) Males C) Both males and females D) Children E) Teenagers
B)
Which of the following is NOT a symptom of penile cancer? A) Nausea B) Changes in the skin of the penis C) Lump on the penis D) Bleeding from the penis E) Itching
A)
What is the main cause of penile cancer? A) Smoking B) Alcohol consumption C) Unknown D) Viral infections E) Genetic factors
C)
Which test is commonly used to diagnose penile cancer? A) Blood test B) Biopsy C) X-ray D) MRI E) Urine test
B)
Which of the following is a treatment option for penile cancer? A) Radiation therapy B) Chemotherapy C) Surgery D) Homeopathy E) Physical therapy
Penile cancer is primarily diagnosed in: A) Women B) Men C) Children D) Elderly E) Young adults
B)
What is the primary organ affected by penile cancer? A) Liver B) Lungs C) Penis D) Heart E) Brain
C)

What is peripheral arterial disease (PAD)? A) A condition with fatty deposits in the arteries restricting blood supply to leg muscles. B) A type of skin disease. C) A bone disorder. D) A psychological condition. E) A condition also known as peripheral vascular disease (PVD).
A,E
Which symptoms are commonly associated with PAD? A) Hair loss on legs and feet. B) Numbness or weakness in the legs. C) Ulcers on feet and legs. D) Changing skin color on legs. E) Frequent sneezing.
A,B,C,D

When should you see a GP regarding PAD? A) If you experience recurring leg pain when exercising. B) If you have a headache. C) If you have a sore throat. D) If you have a fever. E) If your symptoms develop quickly or get suddenly worse.
A,E

How is PAD usually diagnosed? A) Through a physical examination by a GP. B) By comparing blood pressure in your arm and ankle. C) Through a blood test. D) By X-ray. E) The difference in blood pressure is called the ankle brachial pressure index (ABPI).
A,B,E
What are the main causes of PAD? A) Smoking. B) Type 1 diabetes. C) High blood pressure. D) High cholesterol. E) Allergies.
A,B,C,D

What are the main lifestyle changes recommended for treating PAD? A) Exercising regularly. B) Not smoking. C) Eating a healthy diet. D) Losing weight if overweight or obese. E) Increasing caffeine intake.
A,B,C,D
What are the potential complications of PAD? A) Coronary heart disease. B) Stroke. C) Heart attack. D) Angina. E) Tooth decay.
A,B,C,D

What is critical limb ischaemia (CLI)? A) A severe burning pain in legs and feet that continues even when resting. B) Wounds and ulcers on feet and legs that do not heal. C) Loss of muscle mass in legs. D) Gangrene. E) A type of skin rash.
A,B,C,D
What treatments are recommended for CLI? A) Angioplasty. B) Bypass graft. C) Amputation below the knee. D) Physical therapy. E) Chemotherapy.
A,B,C
What is the process called that causes PAD? A) Atherosclerosis. B) Arthritis. C) Osteoporosis. D) Neuropathy. E) A build-up of fatty deposits in the walls of the leg arteries.
A,E
What is another name for bladder pain syndrome? A) Urinary tract infection B) Interstitial cystitis C) Kidney stones D) Prostatitis E) Vaginitis
B)

Which of the following is a common symptom of BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Intense pelvic pain B) Sudden strong urges to pee C) Needing to pee more often than usual D) Pain in your lower tummy when your bladder is filling up E) Waking up several times during the night to pee

What should you do if you have blood in your urine and pain in your lower tummy? A) Ignore it B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Call 111 D) Take over-the-counter painkillers E) Wait for it to go away
B), C)
Which of the following demographics is most commonly affected by BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Men under 30 B) Women over 30 C) Children D) Elderly men E) Teenagers
B)

What are some possible causes of BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Damage to the bladder lining B) A problem with the pelvic floor muscles C) Immune system causing an inflammatory reaction D) Chronic urinary infection (UTI) E) A viral infection

Which of the following conditions may be associated with BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Fibromyalgia B) Myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) C) Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) D) Common cold E) Migraine
What should you do if you have pelvic pain that does not go away? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Take antibiotics without a prescription D) Drink more water E) Avoid all physical activity
B)
Which of the following tests might be offered to diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Cystoscopy B) Urine tests C) Ultrasound D) MRI scan E) Blood test
Which of the following medicines might be used to treat BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Paracetamol B) Amitriptyline C) Pentosan polysulfate sodium (Elmiron) D) Lignocaine E) Antibiotics

Which of the following supportive therapies might be helpful for BPS (interstitial cystitis)? A) Physiotherapy B) Acupuncture C) Talking therapies and counselling D) Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) E) Surgery

Which symptoms are commonly associated with temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Pain around your jaw, ear and temple. B: Clicking, popping or grinding noises when you move your jaw. C: Numbness in the face. D: Constant fever. E: Difficulty swallowing.
A,B

What are some recommended self-care practices for easing temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Eat soft food. B: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen. C: Chew gum frequently. D: Hold an ice pack to the jaw. E: Bite your nails.
A,D

Which of the following can be used to relieve pain associated with temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Holding a hot water bottle wrapped in a tea towel. B: Massaging the painful jaw muscles. C: Applying a pack of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel. D: Using a heating pad on high setting. E: Applying ice directly to the skin.
A,C

What should you avoid doing if you have temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Eat soft food. B: Chew gum or pen tops. C: Bite food with your front teeth. D: Drink plenty of water. E: Clench your teeth.
B,E

When should you seek urgent medical advice for temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: If you have difficulty opening your mouth fully. B: If you have a slight headache. C: If you have vision problems. D: If you feel mild stress. E: If you have pain around your jaw, ear or at the side of your head.
A,C

What are some treatments a GP might suggest for temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Stronger painkillers. B: Relaxation techniques to reduce stress. C: Surgery. D: Ways to improve your sleep. E: Physical therapy exercises.
A,D
Which specialists might a GP refer you to for further treatment of temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: A dentist. B: A psychologist. C: A physiotherapist. D: A cardiologist. E: A dermatologist.
A,C
What are some common causes of temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Teeth grinding. B: Wear and tear of the joint. C: Excessive exercise. D: A blow to the head or face. E: Stress.
A,D

What are some symptoms that might indicate a serious problem related to temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Frequent, severe headaches. B: Pain or tenderness at the side of the head or on the scalp. C: Mild jaw pain. D: Vision problems. E: Difficulty opening your mouth fully.
A,D

What are some recommended ways to manage stress related to temporomandibular disorder (TMD)? A: Eat soft food. B: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen. C: Find ways to relax. D: Chew gum frequently. E: Massage the painful jaw muscles.
C,E

Which of the following are potential issues with herbal medicines? A) They may cause problems if you're taking other medicines. B) They could make other medicines less effective. C) They may cause unexpected side effects. D) They are always safe because they are natural. E) They are heavily regulated.
A,B,C

Who should be particularly wary of taking herbal medicines? A) Pregnant or breastfeeding women. B) People with serious health conditions. C) People going to have surgery. D) Athletes. E) People who exercise regularly.
A,B,C

What should you do before undergoing surgery if you take herbal medicines? A) Continue taking them without telling your doctor. B) Stop taking them a few days before surgery. C) Tell your doctor about the herbal medicines you're taking. D) Increase the dosage. E) Start taking new herbal medicines.
B,C

What does the THR marking on a herbal medicine indicate? A) The medicine complies with quality standards. B) The medicine is intended for self-medicated conditions. C) The medicine is completely safe for everyone. D) The medicine has been tested in clinical trials. E) The medicine is FDA approved.
A,B

What are the risks of buying herbal medicines online or by mail order? A) They may be fake or substandard. B) They may contain banned ingredients. C) They may be copies of licensed medicines. D) They are always safer than buying in stores. E) They are cheaper and more effective.
A,B,C

What should you do if you experience side effects from a herbal medicine? A) Report it using the Yellow Card Scheme. B) Stop taking the medicine immediately. C) Consult your doctor. D) Ignore the side effects. E) Increase the dosage.
A,B,C

Which of the following groups should avoid taking herbal medicines? A) People taking other medicines. B) People with liver or kidney disease. C) Pregnant or breastfeeding women. D) Young adults. E) People with minor ailments.
A,B,C

Why is it important to tell your doctor about any herbal medicines you're taking before surgery? A) They may interfere with anaesthesia. B) They may interfere with blood clotting. C) They may increase the risk of bleeding. D) They may enhance the effects of anaesthesia. E) They may speed up recovery.
A,B,C

What does the Yellow Card Scheme help the MHRA identify? A) New side effects associated with medicines. B) Risks associated with herbal remedies. C) Interactions between St John's wort and other medicines. D) Effectiveness of herbal medicines. E) Cost of herbal medicines.
A,B,C

What should you look for when buying a herbal medicine? A) A traditional herbal registration (THR) marking. B) Claims based on traditional usage. C) Information about how and when to use it. D) FDA approval. E) Recommendations from friends.
A,B,C
What is Patau's syndrome? A) A rare genetic disorder caused by an additional copy of chromosome 13 B) A bacterial infection C) A vitamin deficiency D) A hormonal imbalance E) A type of cancer
A
How many pairs of chromosomes does each cell normally contain? A) 21 B) 22 C) 23 D) 24 E) 25
C
What is the primary cause of Patau's syndrome? A) Environmental factors B) Lack of exercise C) Having an additional copy of chromosome 13 D) Poor diet E) Viral infection
C
What is the risk of having a baby with Patau's syndrome? A) 1 in 1,000 B) 1 in 2,000 C) 1 in 4,000 D) 1 in 8,000 E) 1 in 10,000
C
What is the most common symptom of Patau's syndrome in babies? A) High birth weight B) Large head size C) Severe heart defects D) Abnormal growth of the limbs E) Lung disease
C
What is the condition where the brain does not divide into two halves? A) Hydrocephaly B) Holoprosencephaly C) Microcephaly D) Anencephaly E) Spina bifida
B
What is the term for an abdominal wall defect in Patau's syndrome? A) Exomphalos B) Gastroschisis C) Umbilical hernia D) Diastasis recti E) Omphalocoele
A, E
What is the primary cause of chromosomal translocation in Patau's syndrome? A) Exposure to radiation B) Genetic material rearrangement C) Infection during pregnancy D) Use of medications E) Stress
B
What is the primary screening test offered for Patau's syndrome? A) MRI scan B) Combined test C) X-ray D) Blood pressure test E) ECG
B
What is the diagnostic test used to check for Patau's syndrome? A) Amniocentesis B) Biopsy C) CT scan D) Mammogram E) Endoscopy
A
What type of scan is an echocardiogram? A) X-ray B) Ultrasound scan C) MRI D) CT scan E) PET scan
B,C
Who might request an echocardiogram? A) Dentist B) Cardiologist C) GP D) Optometrist E) Physiotherapist
B,C
What is the primary purpose of an echocardiogram? A) Checking lung function B) Analysing heart structure C) Measuring blood sugar D) Assessing bone density E) Detecting brain activity
B,C

What is the difference between an echocardiogram and an electrocardiogram (ECG)? A) They are the same B) Echocardiogram checks heart rhythm C) ECG uses sound waves D) Echocardiogram is an ultrasound scan E) ECG checks electrical activity
D,E
What conditions can an echocardiogram help detect? A) Diabetes B) Heart attack C) Heart failure D) Brain tumor E) Osteoporosis
B,C
What is a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE)? A) A scan using X-rays B) An ultrasound of the chest C) A scan of the throat D) A scan using MRI E) A scan using CT
B,C
What preparation is needed for a transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE)? A) Fasting B) Exercise C) Drinking water D) Taking medication E) Wearing special clothing
A,E
What is a stress echocardiogram? A) A scan done while resting B) A scan done during exercise C) A scan using contrast agent D) A scan using X-rays E) A scan using MRI
B,C
What is used in a contrast echocardiogram? A) X-rays B) Contrast agent C) Sedative D) Local anaesthetic E) Electrodes
B,C
What are the potential risks of a transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE)? A) Radiation exposure B) Sore throat C) Dizziness D) Damage to the throat E) Headache
B,D
What is the primary cause of head lice infestations? A) Dirty hair B) Head-to-head contact C) Poor hygiene D) Sharing combs E) Wearing hats
B)
How can head lice be detected? A) Blood tests B) X-rays C) Finding live lice with a fine-toothed comb D) Hair dye E) Ultrasound
C)
What is the best method to get rid of head lice? A) Wet combing B) Hot water washing C) Shaving the head D) Using herbal remedies E) Applying essential oils
A)
What should you do if wet combing does not work? A) Repeat the process daily B) Use a medicated lotion or spray C) Apply a head lice repellent D) Use an electric comb E) Consult a GP
B)
How often should wet combing be done to catch newly hatched lice? A) Daily B) Every other day C) On days 1, 5, 9, and 13 D) Weekly E) Monthly
C)

What should you do if you find head lice on a family member? A) Keep them home from school B) Wash all laundry on a hot wash C) Treat everyone with close contact on the same day D) Use a head lice repellent E) Shave their head
C)
What are head lice eggs (nits) like? A) Black and shiny B) Brown or white and attached to the hair C) Green and sticky D) Red and itchy E) Blue and smooth
B)
How can you prevent head lice? A) Using medicated lotions B) Wet combing regularly with a detection comb C) Wearing a hat D) Applying essential oils E) Shaving the head
B)
What is the typical length of head lice? A) 1mm B) 3mm C) 5mm D) 10mm E) 15mm
B)
What should you do if medicated lotions or sprays do not work? A) Use a stronger chemical B) Consult a pharmacist C) Shave the head D) Apply more frequently E) Use an electric comb
B)
What is Paget's disease of bone? A) A condition that affects bone renewal B) A type of skin cancer C) A rare type of breast cancer D) A condition that affects the liver E) A type of heart disease
A)
Which age group is Paget's disease of bone most common in? A) Children under 10 B) Teenagers C) People under 50 D) Older people E) People in their 20s
D)
Which parts of the body are commonly affected by Paget's disease of bone? A) Eyes B) Lungs C) Pelvis D) Toes E) Liver
C)
What are some symptoms of Paget's disease of bone? A) Bone or joint pain B) Fever C) Coughing D) Skin rash E) Changes in bone shape
A),E)
Which cells are responsible for absorbing old bone in Paget's disease of bone? A) Osteoclasts B) Osteoblasts C) Neurons D) Muscle cells E) White blood cells
A)
What is the main treatment for Paget's disease of bone? A) Antibiotics B) Bisphosphonate medication C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Surgery
B)

How does Paget's disease of bone affect bone cells? A) It stops bone remodeling B) It causes bone cells to absorb bone at a faster rate C) It only affects the bone marrow D) It causes bone cells to produce stronger bone E) It only affects the skin
B)
Which further problems can Paget's disease of bone lead to? A) Fragile bones B) Skin infections C) Kidney failure D) Enlarged bones E) Permanent hearing loss
Which supportive therapies can help with Paget's disease of bone? A) Physiotherapy B) Sleep therapy C) Hormone therapy D) Occupational therapy E) Aromatherapy
A),D)
What is the general term sometimes used to refer to Paget's disease of bone? A) Paget's syndrome B) Paget's disease C) Paget's disorder D) Paget's condition E) Paget's infection
B)

What are the symptoms of bowel incontinence? A) Poo leaking out without control B) Feeling the need to poo but not making it to the toilet in time C) Not being able to get fully clean after going to the toilet D) Seeing streaks or stains of poo in your underwear E) Experiencing a burning sensation while urinating
A,B,C,D

When should you see a GP regarding bowel incontinence? A) If you think you have bowel incontinence B) If you have changes in your poo that are not getting better C) If you have black or dark red poo D) If you have bloody diarrhoea E) If you experience frequent headaches
A,B,C,D

What might a GP do to diagnose bowel incontinence? A) Talk to you about your symptoms B) Examine you by feeling your tummy C) Ask for a poo sample D) Refer you to a specialist for more tests E) Perform a brain scan
A,B,C,D

What treatments might a GP recommend for bowel incontinence? A) Review of your diet and medicines B) Medicines to make you poo less often or soften your poo C) Incontinence pads or pants D) Plugs that go inside your bottom E) A new diet of only fruits and vegetables
A,B,C,D

What might a specialist incontinence service recommend for bowel incontinence? A) Review of your diet and medicines B) Exercises to strengthen your pelvic floor and bottom C) Techniques to help empty the lower part of your bowels D) Surgery E) A strict exercise regimen of running 5 miles daily
A,B,C,D

What types of surgery might be recommended for bowel incontinence? A) Repairing muscles in your bottom B) Making a new anal sphincter using muscle from your thigh C) Putting an artificial sphincter in your bottom D) Making a small opening in your tummy for a pouch E) Removing your appendix
A,B,C,D

What support is available if you have bowel incontinence? A) Help from NHS talking therapies B) Support from charities C) Getting a RADAR key for accessible toilets D) Information and support from Bladder & Bowel Community E) A personal chef to cook specific meals
A,B,C,D

What are some common causes of bowel incontinence? A) Eating certain foods or drinks B) Weaker muscles around your bottom C) Health conditions affecting your digestive system D) Health conditions making you less aware of when you need to poo E) Excessive physical activity
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you have black or dark red poo? A) Ask for an urgent GP appointment B) Get help from NHS 111 C) Call 111 D) Get help from 111 online E) Wait and see if it resolves on its own
A,B,C,D
What might happen if you are referred to a specialist for more tests regarding bowel incontinence? A) Blood tests B) A colonoscopy C) An ultrasound scan D) A brain scan E) A full body X-ray
A,B,C
What are the symptoms of sick building syndrome? A) Nausea B) Headaches C) Sneezing D) Dry, itchy skin E) Chest pain
B), D)
What should you do if you think you have sick building syndrome? A) Speak to your doctor B) Speak to your manager C) Speak to the building owner D) Ignore the symptoms E) Speak to your local council
B), C)

What can you do to ease symptoms of sick building syndrome yourself? A) Open windows to improve ventilation B) Set the temperature at about 19C C) Stay indoors all day D) Increase stress levels E) Take regular screen breaks
A), E)
What are the possible causes of sick building syndrome? A) Poor ventilation B) Bright or flickering lights C) Loud noises D) Problems with cleaning E) Exposure to sunlight
A), B)

What should you do if you have symptoms of sick building syndrome at work? A) Speak to your manager B) Take a day off C) Ignore the symptoms D) Speak to your local Health and Safety Executive (HSE) office E) Change jobs
A), D)
What are the common symptoms of sick building syndrome? A) Headaches B) Blocked or runny nose C) Dry, sore eyes or throat D) Sweating E) Fever
A), C)
What can you do to manage sick building syndrome symptoms during breaks? A) Go outside for fresh air B) Stay indoors C) Increase screen time D) Eat more junk food E) Take a nap
A), D)
What are some environmental factors that might contribute to sick building syndrome? A) Poor ventilation B) Lack of natural light C) Crowded desks D) High humidity E) Exposure to smoke
A), C)
What are some physical symptoms of sick building syndrome? A) Nausea B) Dry, itchy skin C) Muscle pain D) Skin rashes E) Abdominal pain
B), D)

What can you do to improve indoor air quality and reduce sick building syndrome symptoms? A) Open windows B) Use air fresheners C) Increase humidity D) Set the temperature at about 19C E) Turn off air conditioning
A), D)
What is testicular cancer? A) Cancer found in the lungs B) Cancer found in the testicles C) Cancer found in the brain D) Cancer found in the stomach E) Cancer found in the liver
B)
Which of the following is a symptom of testicular cancer? A) Headache B) Lump in the testicle C) Shortness of breath D) Loss of appetite E) Fever
B)
What is the main cause of testicular cancer? A) Smoking B) Unknown C) Excessive alcohol consumption D) Poor diet E) Lack of exercise
B)
Which test is commonly used to diagnose testicular cancer? A) Blood test B) X-ray C) Ultrasound D) MRI E) Biopsy
C)
What is the first step after diagnosing testicular cancer? A) Surgery B) Chemotherapy C) Radiation therapy D) Consultation with a specialist E) Physical therapy
D)
Which organ is primarily affected by testicular cancer? A) Kidneys B) Testicles C) Lungs D) Heart E) Liver
B)
What is the initial treatment for testicular cancer? A) Pain medication B) Surgery C) Physical therapy D) Dietary changes E) Psychotherapy
B)
Where can you find information on testicular cancer? A) NHS website B) Local library C) Social media D) Grocery store E) Post office
A)
What kind of support is available for testicular cancer patients? A) Financial support B) Emotional support C) Physical therapy D) Nutritional counseling E) Legal advice
B)
Which of the following is not a common symptom of testicular cancer? A) Swelling in the testicle B) Fever C) Lump in the testicle D) Pain in the testicle E) Change in testicle size
B)

What is tongue-tie? A) A condition where the tongue is too large B) A condition where the piece of skin connecting the tongue to the bottom of the mouth is shorter or tighter than usual C) A condition where the tongue is too small D) A condition where the tongue is too long E) A condition where the tongue is too dry
B
What is a common symptom of tongue-tie in babies? A) Green tongue B) Tongue looks heart-shaped when lifted or stuck out C) Tongue turns blue D) Tongue has spots E) Tongue is very long
B

What difficulty might a baby with tongue-tie experience while feeding? A) Swallowing too much milk B) Have difficulty attaching or staying attached to the breast or bottle teat C) Refusing to feed D) Sleeping during feeds E) Crying loudly during feeds
B

What can a mother experience if her baby has tongue-tie and she is breastfeeding? A) Sore nipples or painful and swollen breasts B) Excessive milk production C) Loss of appetite D) High fever E) Swollen hands
A
Who should you speak to if you think your baby or child has tongue-tie? A) A dentist B) A midwife, health visitor or GP C) A pharmacist D) A nutritionist E) A psychologist
B

What is the primary treatment for tongue-tie if it is causing problems? A) Medication B) Breastfeeding or bottle-feeding advice from a trained health professional C) Physical therapy D) Speech therapy E) A special diet
B

What type of surgery might be performed for tongue-tie? A) Tongue enlargement B) Tongue reduction C) A small surgery to cut the piece of skin connecting the tongue to the bottom of the mouth D) Tongue color change E) Tongue texture change
C
In young babies, the surgery for tongue-tie is usually done with what? A) Local anaesthetic B) No anaesthetic C) General anaesthetic D) Topical anaesthetic E) Oral anaesthetic
B

What is a common outcome after surgery for tongue-tie in babies? A) The baby gets worse B) Most babies get better quickly and are able to feed better C) The baby develops a fever D) The baby's tongue turns blue E) The baby starts crying more
B

How can tongue-tie affect an adult? A) It makes them unable to walk B) It can make it difficult to move the tongue C) It causes severe headaches D) It leads to loss of hearing E) It results in loss of vision
B
What are lipomas typically described as? A) Soft and squishy B) Hard and immovable C) Red and painful D) Fast-growing E) Harmless
A,E
Where do lipomas commonly appear? A) Shoulders B) Chest C) Arms D) Back E) Eyes
A,B,C,D
What should you do if you discover a lump on your body? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Remove it yourself D) Apply a warm compress E) Wait for it to disappear
B
What characteristics do lipomas usually have? A) Soft B) Painful C) Move slightly under the skin D) Grow quickly E) Appear only on the face
A,C
Under what conditions might a lipoma be removed on the NHS? A) If it's growing B) If it's causing symptoms C) If it's painful D) If it's on the forehead E) If it's expensive
A,B
What is the typical size range of a lipoma? A) Size of a pea B) Few centimetres across C) Size of a grapefruit D) Size of a football E) Size of a pinhead
A,B
What should you do if a lump is hard and does not move? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Apply ice D) Take painkillers E) Wait for it to move
B
What might a GP do if there's doubt about a lump? A) Refer for a scan B) Ignore it C) Prescribe medication D) Order blood tests E) Perform surgery immediately
A
What is a common location for a lipoma? A) Shoulders B) Chest C) Arms D) Back E) Toes
A,B,C,D
What is a typical characteristic of lipomas in terms of growth? A) Grow slowly B) Grow quickly C) Grow only at night D) Grow only when exposed to sunlight E) Do not grow at all
A
What should you do if you chip a tooth? A) Call a GP. B) Put the piece of tooth in milk and see a dentist. C) Ignore it and wait for it to heal. D) Try to fix it yourself with glue. E) Call 911.
B,E
Who can provide treatment for a broken tooth? A) A nurse. B) A dentist. C) A pharmacist. D) A physical therapist. E) A GP.
B,E

What should you do if your dentist is closed? A) Wait until they reopen. B) Call 111 for advice. C) Go to the emergency room. D) Try to fix the tooth yourself. E) Call the dentist to hear their answerphone.
B,E
What can a dentist do for a cracked tooth? A) Perform root canal treatment. B) Prescribe antibiotics. C) Provide a filling or crown. D) Refer you to a GP. E) Glue the fragment of tooth back on.
A,E

What should you do if you don't have a dentist? A) Call 111 for advice. B) Go to the nearest pharmacy. C) Find a dentist near you and ask for an emergency appointment. D) Wait until you can find a dentist. E) Call 911.
A,C
What should you do with a piece of broken tooth? A) Throw it away. B) Put it in milk or saliva. C) Keep it in your pocket. D) Call a GP. E) Take it to a dentist.
B,E
What is a common treatment for a badly broken tooth? A) Root canal treatment. B) Painkillers. C) Ice packs. D) Bandages. E) A filling or crown.
A,E
Who should you contact for out-of-hours dental emergencies? A) Your GP. B) Call 111. C) A pharmacist. D) An optometrist. E) A dentist.
B,E

What should you do if you cannot get an emergency dental appointment? A) Go to the emergency room. B) Call 111 for advice. C) Wait until the next day. D) Try to fix the tooth yourself. E) Find a dentist near you and ask for an emergency appointment.
B,E
What is an important step to take if a tooth is chipped or broken? A) Ignore it. B) Put the piece of tooth in milk or saliva. C) Call a GP. D) Try to fix it yourself. E) See a dentist.
B,E
Where can ticks that spread tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) be found? A) Africa B) Most of Europe C) Australia D) Russia E) South America
B,D
What can you do to avoid tick bites? A) Wear dark-coloured clothing B) Walk on clearly defined paths C) Apply perfume D) Use an insect repellent E) Wear short sleeves
B,D
What should you do if you find a tick that has bitten you? A) Crush the tick B) Use tweezers to remove it C) Leave it alone D) Squeeze the tick E) Apply heat to the bite
B
What are the initial flu-like symptoms of tick-borne encephalitis (TBE)? A) A high temperature B) Sneezing C) Coughing D) Headache E) Aches and pains
A,D
What more serious symptoms can occur if the TBE infection spreads to the brain? A) A stiff neck B) Yellow skin C) Chest pain D) A severe headache E) A fit (seizure)
A,E

What should you do if you experience flu-like symptoms after being bitten by a tick? A) Wait for the symptoms to pass B) Call 999 immediately C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Ignore the symptoms E) Take antibiotics without consulting a doctor
C

What should you do if you experience a stiff neck and a severe headache after a tick bite? A) Take over-the-counter painkillers B) Call 999 or go to A&E C) Wait for the symptoms to pass D) Apply a cold compress E) Drink plenty of fluids
B

How can you get information about the risks of TBE in a country you're traveling to? A) Check the TravelHealthPro website B) Ask a friend who has traveled there C) Read travel blogs D) Consult a travel agent E) Search on social media
A
What is the recommended number of TBE vaccine injections for travel? A) 1 injection B) 2 injections C) 3 injections D) 4 injections E) 5 injections
B
What should you do after being outdoors to prevent TBE? A) Take a hot shower B) Drink plenty of water C) Check your skin and hair D) Eat a balanced meal E) Apply sunscreen
C
Which of the following are common causes of breast pain? A) Injuries B) Mastitis C) Breast cancer D) Heartburn E) Sprains
A,B,E
When is breast pain linked to periods likely to occur? A) During pregnancy B) Up to 2 weeks before a period C) After menopause D) Only during ovulation E) Immediately after a period
B
What medications can sometimes cause breast pain? A) Paracetamol B) Contraceptive pill C) Antibiotics D) Antidepressants E) Vitamin E tablets
B,D

What are some signs that you should seek urgent medical help for breast pain? A) Nipple discharge B) Breast changing shape C) Very high temperature D) Red, hot or swollen breast E) Dimpling of the breast skin
A,B,C,D,E

What are some non-urgent reasons to see a GP about breast pain? A) If the pain is not improving B) If you have a history of breast cancer in your family C) If you have signs of pregnancy D) If the painkillers are not helping E) If you have a rash on your nipple
A,B,C,D

What are some things you can do to ease breast pain? A) Take paracetamol or ibuprofen B) Use vitamin E tablets C) Wear a properly fitted bra D) Rub painkilling gel on your breasts E) Sleep in a soft bra
A,C,D,E
What are some other causes of breast pain? A) Pregnancy B) Anxiety C) Injuries to the neck D) Hormone changes during menopause E) A breast abscess
A,C,D,E
Which of the following is unlikely to be a symptom of breast cancer? A) Breast pain B) Hard lump in the breast C) Nipple discharge D) Breast changing shape E) Red, hot or swollen breast
A

What are some signs that breast pain might be related to a more serious condition? A) Pain that comes and goes B) Pain that spreads to the armpit C) Pain that is dull, heavy or aching D) Pain with a very high temperature E) Pain with red, hot or swollen breast
D,E
What are some conditions that can cause breast pain? A) Mastitis B) Breast abscess C) Flu D) Pregnancy E) Injuries
A,B,D,E

What is an aneurysm? A) A blockage in a blood vessel B) A bulge in a blood vessel caused by a weakness in the blood vessel wall C) A tumor in the blood vessel D) An inflammation of the blood vessel E) A narrowing of the blood vessel
B
Where do aneurysms commonly develop? A) In the lungs B) In the brain C) In the bones D) In the muscles E) In the skin
B
What is the condition called when a brain aneurysm bursts? A) Stroke B) Subarachnoid haemorrhage C) Migraine D) Epilepsy E) Aneurysmitis
B
What is one of the symptoms of a burst brain aneurysm? A) A mild headache B) A sudden agonising headache C) Dizziness D) Fever E) Blurred vision
B
What is the medical term for an aneurysm that develops inside the brain? A) Cranial aneurysm B) Intracranial aneurysm C) Brain tumor D) Cerebral haemorrhage E) Neural aneurysm
B
What is one of the treatments for a brain aneurysm? A) Radiation therapy B) Chemotherapy C) Filling the aneurysm with tiny metal coils (coiling) D) Acupuncture E) Herbal remedies
C
What is one of the risk factors for developing a brain aneurysm? A) Diabetes B) Smoking C) Low blood pressure D) High cholesterol E) Asthma
B
What is the estimated prevalence of brain aneurysms? A) 1 in 2 people B) 1 in 20 people C) 1 in 100 people D) 1 in 1000 people E) 1 in 10,000 people
B
What is one way to prevent a brain aneurysm from rupturing? A) Eating a high-sugar diet B) Increasing salt intake C) Avoiding smoking D) Drinking alcohol E) Avoiding exercise
C
What is the approximate number of people who have a ruptured brain aneurysm in England each year? A) 1 in 100 B) 1 in 1000 C) 1 in 15,000 D) 1 in 100,000 E) 1 in 1,000,000
C
What is an adenoidectomy? A) Removal of the tonsils B) Repair of a deviated septum C) Removal of enlarged adenoids D) Treatment for asthma E) Surgery for a blocked ear
C
What are adenoids? A) Lumps of tissue in the lungs B) Part of the immune system C) Bones in the throat D) Glands that produce saliva E) Muscles in the neck
B

Why might a doctor suggest waiting before performing an adenoidectomy? A) To see if the problems get better by themselves B) To save on medical costs C) To avoid surgery D) To wait for the child to grow older E) To use alternative treatments
A
What type of anaesthetic is used during an adenoidectomy? A) Local anaesthetic B) General anaesthetic C) Epidural anaesthetic D) Topical anaesthetic E) IV anaesthetic
B

What might happen after an adenoidectomy? A) The child might feel sick B) The child might have a blocked nose C) The child might have a sore throat D) The child might have bad breath E) The child might have a temporary change to their voice
A,B,C,D,E

What can parents do to help their child recover after an adenoidectomy? A) Keep them at home for a week B) Give them paracetamol or ibuprofen C) Encourage them to eat their usual foods D) Make sure they drink lots of fluids E) Avoid being around other people
A,B,C,D,E

What are some possible complications of an adenoidectomy? A) Bleeding in the throat B) Damage to the teeth C) Infection where the adenoids were removed D) Problems breathing E) The adenoids growing back
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if your child has a lot of pain after an adenoidectomy? A) Give them more pain medication B) Wait for it to pass C) Call 999 D) Ask for an urgent GP appointment E) Take them to the pharmacy
D

What should you do if your child has bleeding from the throat after an adenoidectomy? A) Apply pressure with a cloth B) Give them ice to suck on C) Call 999 D) Wait and see if it stops E) Take them to the pharmacy
C
What are some common problems caused by enlarged adenoids? A) Difficulty breathing through the nose B) Sleep apnoea C) Glue ear D) Frequent ear infections E) Snoring
A,B,C,D,E

What is club foot? A) A condition where the foot turns in and under B) A condition where the foot turns outwards C) A condition where the foot is abnormally large D) A condition where the foot is abnormally small E) A condition where the foot is flat
A, B,
What is the main tendon affected in club foot? A) Achilles tendon B) Quadriceps tendon C) Hamstring tendon D) Patellar tendon E) Biceps tendon
A, B,
When is club foot usually diagnosed? A) After the baby is born B) During the routine ultrasound scan C) At 3 months old D) At 1 year old E) During the first trimester
A, B,
What is the main treatment for club foot? A) Ponseti method B) Surgery C) Physiotherapy D) Casting E) Medication
A, D,

What is the typical outcome for children with club foot? A) Most are treated successfully B) They learn to walk at the usual age C) They may have a slightly shorter leg D) They may have a larger foot E) They may not be able to wear regular footwear
A, B,
What is the chance of having a second child with club foot if the first child has it? A) 1 in 35 B) 1 in 100 C) 1 in 10 D) 1 in 50 E) 1 in 5
A, C,
What is the chance of having a child with club foot if one parent has it? A) 1 in 30 B) 1 in 50 C) 1 in 100 D) 1 in 5 E) 1 in 20
A, B,
What is the chance of having a child with club foot if both parents have it? A) 1 in 3 B) 1 in 10 C) 1 in 50 D) 1 in 20 E) 1 in 100
A, B,
What is one of the rare conditions linked to club foot? A) Spina bifida B) Down syndrome C) Autism D) Cerebral palsy E) ADHD
A, B,
What organization offers support for club foot? A) Steps Worldwide B) American Heart Association C) National Institutes of Health D) World Health Organization E) Red Cross
A, B,
Which of the following are common infections treated with antifungals? A) Ringworm B) Athlete's foot C) Vaginal thrush D) Ear infection E) Severe dandruff
A,B,C,E
Which of these are types of antifungal medicines? A) Cream B) Capsule C) Injection D) Eye drops E) Pessary
A,B,C,E
Which of these are common names for antifungal medicines? A) Clotrimazole B) Econazole C) Fluconazole D) Vitamin C E) Nystatin
A,B,C,E
Which of these are serious fungal infections that may need hospital treatment? A) Aspergillosis B) Tonsillitis C) Fungal meningitis D) Common cold E) Severe dandruff
A,C
Which of these are methods by which antifungal medicines work? A) Killing the fungus B) Preventing the fungus from growing C) Reducing fever D) Enhancing immune response E) Improving appetite
A,B
Which of these are mild side effects of antifungal medicines? A) Itching or burning B) Redness C) Feeling sick D) Hair loss E) Tummy (abdominal) pain
A,B,C,E
Which of these are severe side effects of antifungal medicines? A) Allergic reaction B) Severe skin reaction C) Liver damage D) Increased appetite E) Jaundice
A,B,C,E
Which of these are examples of more serious fungal infections? A) Athlete's foot B) Aspergillosis C) Fungal meningitis D) Ringworm E) Vaginal thrush
B,C

Which of these are important things to consider before taking antifungal medicines? A) Existing conditions or allergies B) Possible side effects C) Interaction with other medicines D) Suitability during pregnancy or breastfeeding E) Frequency of exercise
A,B,C,D

Which of these actions should you take if you have severe side effects from antifungal medicines? A) Stop using the medicine B) See a GP or pharmacist C) Go to A&E or call 999 D) Continue using the medicine E) Take more medicine
A,B,C
What are the common symptoms of dengue fever? A) High temperature B) Severe headache C) Constant coughing D) Stiff neck E) Feeling or being sick
A, E
Which parts of the world are most affected by dengue? A) North Pole B) Central and South America C) Arctic Circle D) Australia E) Parts of Africa and Asia
B, E
What should you do if you feel unwell after traveling to a country where dengue is found? A) Take a hot bath B) Eat spicy food C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Go to the gym E) Drink alcohol
C
What are the symptoms of severe dengue? A) Mild fever B) Severe tummy pain C) Dry cough D) Bleeding gums or nose E) Regular sneezing
B, D
How can you ease the symptoms of dengue fever? A) Drinking plenty of fluids B) Taking anti-inflammatory painkillers C) Resting D) Exercising vigorously E) Taking paracetamol
A, E
What should you do if you have severe dengue symptoms? A) Wait it out B) Call 999 or go to A&E C) Drink more coffee D) Watch TV E) Take a nap
B
In which season is there a higher risk of getting dengue in parts of southern Europe? A) Winter B) Spring to November C) Summer D) Autumn E) Spring to Autumn
B
Which countries in Europe have reported cases of dengue? A) Germany B) Croatia C) Denmark D) France E) Poland
B, D
What should you avoid doing if you have dengue fever? A) Taking paracetamol B) Resting C) Drinking fluids D) Taking ibuprofen or aspirin E) Eating healthy food
D
How can you prevent dengue infection? A) Wear long-sleeved clothing B) Eat lots of garlic C) Use insect repellent D) Drink lots of soda E) Sleep under a mosquito net
A, E
Which of the following food colours are linked to hyperactivity in children? A) E102 (tartrazine) B) E104 (quinoline yellow) C) E133 (Brilliant Blue FCF) D) E122 (carmoisine) E) E129 (allura red)
A,B,D,E

What is the recommended action if you think your child's diet may be affecting their behaviour? A) Consult a nutritionist B) Keep a diary of their diet and behaviour C) Avoid all E numbers D) Immediately stop feeding them artificial colours E) Speak to their GP first
B,E

Which organization funded the research linking certain food colours to hyperactivity? A) World Health Organization B) Food Standards Agency C) United Nations D) National Health Service E) European Union
B

What should you do if you want to avoid food colours linked to hyperactivity? A) Check food labels B) Look for alternative products that do not contain them C) Avoid all E numbers D) Only eat organic foods E) Consult a dietician
A,B
Which condition may benefit from avoiding certain food colours? A) Autism B) Diabetes C) ADHD D) Asthma E) Allergies
C

What does an E number indicate for food additives? A) They are dangerous B) They have passed safety tests and are approved for use in the EU C) They are artificial D) They are natural E) They are not suitable for children
B

What is the warning label required for products containing the 6 food colours linked to hyperactivity? A) 'May contain nuts' B) 'May have an adverse effect on activity and attention in children' C) 'Not suitable for vegetarians' D) 'Contains artificial flavours' E) 'May cause allergic reactions'
B
Which of the following is NOT linked to hyperactivity? A) Genetics B) Food colours C) Exercise D) Diet E) Tartrazine
C

What should you do if you notice a possible link between food colours and your child's behaviour? A) Consult a psychiatrist B) See if avoiding these colours helps C) Immediately change their diet D) Ignore the link E) Speak to their GP first
B,E
Which of the following foods may contain the 6 food colours linked to hyperactivity? A) Soft drinks B) Fruits C) Vegetables D) Cakes E) Ice cream
A,D,E
What is the primary cause of a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) A burst blood vessel in the brain B) A heart attack C) A virus D) A lung infection E) A brain tumor
A
Which of the following is a common symptom of a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) A sudden severe headache B) A mild fever C) A rash D) A cough E) A stomach ache
A
What diagnostic test is typically used to check for signs of bleeding around the brain in suspected cases of subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) MRI B) CT scan C) X-ray D) Blood test E) Ultrasound
B
Which age group is most commonly affected by subarachnoid haemorrhages? A) 18-30 B) 30-45 C) 45-70 D) 70-85 E) 85 and above
C
What is one of the risk factors for developing a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) Smoking B) Lack of exercise C) Poor diet D) High cholesterol E) Diabetes
A

What is one of the short-term complications of a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) Further bleeding at the site of any aneurysm B) Kidney failure C) Liver disease D) Respiratory problems E) Skin infections
A
Which of the following is a long-term complication of a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) Epilepsy B) High blood pressure C) Asthma D) Arthritis E) Allergies
A
What is a common physical activity that sometimes triggers a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) Coughing B) Running C) Swimming D) Cycling E) Yoga
A
Which treatment is often given to prevent short-term complications of a subarachnoid haemorrhage? A) Medication B) Surgery C) Physical therapy D) Radiation therapy E) Acupuncture
A
Which ethnic group is more commonly affected by subarachnoid haemorrhages? A) Black people B) Asian people C) Hispanic people D) White people E) Native American people
A
What is an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)? A) A swelling in the aorta B) A swelling in the liver C) A swelling in the lungs D) A swelling in the brain E) A swelling in the kidneys
A
What is the main symptom of an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Headache B) Chest pain C) Tummy or back pain D) Dizziness E) Nausea
C
What should you do if you have tummy or back pain that does not go away or keeps coming back? A) Ignore it B) Take painkillers C) See a GP D) Drink more water E) Exercise more
C
What should you do if you have sudden, severe pain in your tummy or back? A) Call 999 B) Take a nap C) Drink tea D) Go for a walk E) Wait it out
A
What is the main test to find out if you have an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Blood test B) X-ray C) MRI D) Ultrasound scan E) CT scan
D
At what age are men offered an ultrasound test for abdominal aortic aneurysm screening? A) 50 B) 55 C) 60 D) 65 E) 70
D
What is the treatment for a small abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Surgery B) Radiation therapy C) Lifestyle changes D) Chemotherapy E) Physical therapy
C
What is the treatment for a large abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Diet change B) Medication C) Surgery D) Physiotherapy E) Acupuncture
C
What is one of the risk factors for an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) High sugar intake B) High blood pressure C) Low vitamin C levels D) High calcium levels E) Low iron levels
B
What is the size classification for a medium abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) 2.5cm to 3.4cm B) 3.5cm to 4.4cm C) 4.5cm to 5.4cm D) 5.5cm to 6.4cm E) 6.5cm to 7.4cm
C

What is the primary purpose of a lumbar puncture? A) To diagnose heart disease B) To treat a condition, such as an infection C) To measure blood pressure D) To check for diabetes E) To find out if symptoms are caused by a brain or spine condition
B, E
What should you do if you feel pain during a lumbar puncture? A) Ignore it B) Tell the doctor or specialist C) Take a painkiller immediately D) Leave the procedure room E) Drink water
B, C
What type of anaesthetic is usually given during a lumbar puncture? A) General anaesthetic B) Local anaesthetic C) Spinal anaesthetic D) IV anaesthetic E) Oral anaesthetic
B, C
Where is a lumbar puncture typically performed? A) At home B) In a pharmacy C) In hospital D) In a gym E) In a dental clinic
C, D
What should you do after a lumbar puncture to help with recovery? A) Rest for at least 24 hours B) Do physical work C) Drink plenty of fluids D) Avoid lying flat E) Take antibiotics
A, C
What are common side effects of a lumbar puncture? A) Headache B) Fever C) Back pain D) Nausea E) Swelling where the needle went into your back
A, C
What should you do if you have severe pain after a lumbar puncture? A) Take a hot bath B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Go for a run D) Drink alcohol E) Ignore it
B, E

Why might a lumbar puncture be difficult to perform? A) Due to the patient's age B) Due to the patient's weight C) Sometimes it's difficult to do D) Due to the patient's diet E) Due to the patient's height
C, D
What should you do if you have a headache after a lumbar puncture? A) Take paracetamol B) Drink coffee C) Do heavy lifting D) Ignore it E) Try lying flat on your back
A, E
What are possible complications of a lumbar puncture? A) Long-term back pain B) Hair loss C) Infection D) Nerve damage E) Tooth decay
A, D

Which of the following are recommended to treat body odour? A) Eat strong smelling food B) Wash your armpits, groin and feet at least twice a day with soap and dry thoroughly C) Use antiperspirants and deodorants D) Change and wash your clothes regularly E) Do not exercise
B,C,D
What should you do if body odour affects your self-esteem? A) Ignore it B) See a GP C) Eat more spicy food D) Drink more coffee E) Stop washing
B
Which fabrics are recommended to wear to reduce body odour? A) Synthetic fabrics B) Cotton C) Wool D) Silk E) Plastic
B,C,D
What can a pharmacist help with regarding body odour? A) Stronger antiperspirants B) Armpit or sweat shields C) Foot powders for sweaty feet D) Surgery to remove sweat glands E) Strong smelling food
A,B,C

What treatments might a GP suggest for severe body odour and sweating? A) Stronger, prescription antiperspirants B) Injections in your armpits to reduce sweat C) Surgery to remove the sweat glands D) Drinking more coffee E) Eating more spicy food
A,B,C
What can make body odour worse? A) Cold weather B) Exercise C) Hot weather D) Hormonal changes E) Being underweight
B,C,D
Which conditions may be linked to body odour? A) Common cold B) Diabetes C) Kidney disease D) Liver disease E) Flu
B,C,D
What should you avoid to treat body odour? A) Eating too much strong smelling or spicy food B) Drinking too much coffee or alcohol C) Exercising D) Wearing natural fabrics E) Using deodorants
A,B

What can you do to reduce body odour? A) Shave your armpits regularly B) Wear antibacterial socks C) Eat more strong smelling food D) Drink more alcohol E) Use soap substitutes that are gentler on your skin
A,B,E

When should you see a GP about body odour? A) When it is affecting your self-esteem B) When you notice a change in how it usually smells C) When you suddenly begin to sweat much more than usual D) When you eat too much spicy food E) When you drink too much coffee
A,B,C

What is a colostomy? A) A surgery to remove the stomach B) An operation to divert one end of the colon through an opening in the tummy C) A procedure to insert a tube into the nose D) A treatment for kidney stones E) A surgery to remove the appendix
B
Why might a colostomy be needed? A) To cure a headache B) To treat cancer C) To treat a broken leg D) To treat a skin rash E) To treat bowel incontinence
B,E
A colostomy can be used to treat which of the following? A) Bowel cancer B) Crohn's disease C) Diverticulitis D) Anal cancer E) Vaginal cancer
A,B,C,D,E
What are the two main types of colostomy? A) End colostomy B) Loop colostomy C) Side colostomy D) Middle colostomy E) Top colostomy
A,B
Which of the following is a type of surgery used to carry out a colostomy? A) Open surgery B) Laparoscopic surgery C) Endoscopic surgery D) Radiation therapy E) Chemotherapy
A,B
What is the name of the opening created in a colostomy? A) Stoma B) Stent C) Drain D) Valve E) Catheter
A
What is the position of the stoma in a colostomy? A) On the right-hand side of the tummy B) On the left-hand side of the tummy C) Above the waist D) On the back E) On the chest
B
What might you have after a colostomy to help you breathe? A) A ventilator B) A nebulizer C) An oxygen mask D) An inhaler E) A humidifier
C
What is the role of a stoma nurse? A) To perform the surgery B) To teach you how to care for your stoma C) To prescribe medication D) To perform physical therapy E) To provide dietary advice
B
How soon after a colostomy might you be able to leave the hospital? A) 1-2 days B) 3-10 days C) 2-3 weeks D) 1 month E) 6 months
B

What is a gastrectomy? A) A dietary plan for weight loss B) A procedure to remove part or all of the stomach C) A medication to treat digestive issues D) A type of physiotherapy E) A diagnostic test for abdominal pain
B
When is a gastrectomy often used? A) To treat asthma B) To treat stomach cancer C) To treat migraines D) To treat skin infections E) To treat heart disease
B
Which of the following is a less common reason for a gastrectomy? A) Stomach ulcers B) Seizures C) Life-threatening obesity D) Oesophageal cancer E) Non-cancerous tumours
A,C,D,E
What are the main types of gastrectomy? A) Total gastrectomy B) Partial gastrectomy C) Sleeve gastrectomy D) Oesophagogastrectomy E) Colonectomy
A,B,C,D
What type of anaesthetic is used during a gastrectomy? A) Local anaesthetic B) General anaesthetic C) Spinal anaesthetic D) Epidural anaesthetic E) No anaesthetic is needed
B
What are the two different techniques for carrying out a gastrectomy? A) Open gastrectomy B) Closed gastrectomy C) Keyhole surgery D) Laser surgery E) Robotic surgery
A,C
Which technique usually results in faster recovery and less pain? A) Open gastrectomy B) Keyhole surgery C) Closed gastrectomy D) Laser surgery E) Robotic surgery
B
How long does it typically take to recover from a gastrectomy? A) A few hours B) A few days C) 1 or 2 weeks D) A few months E) Over a year
C
What is a possible complication of a gastrectomy? A) Anaemia B) Arthritis C) Diabetes D) Osteoporosis E) Asthma
A,D
What might you need after a gastrectomy to ensure proper nutrition? A) Vitamin supplements B) Physical therapy C) Chemotherapy D) Radiation therapy E) Dialysis
A

How is Legionnaires' disease primarily transmitted? A) Drinking contaminated water B) Inhaling droplets of water containing bacteria C) Skin contact with infected individuals D) Eating contaminated food E) Sneezing
B
Where is Legionnaires' disease most commonly caught? A) At home B) In hotels, hospitals, or offices C) In ponds, lakes, and rivers D) In supermarkets E) In schools
B
Which of the following are symptoms of Legionnaires' disease? A) A cough B) Shortness of breath C) Chest pain D) Swollen feet E) Loss of taste
A,B,C

What should you do if you have symptoms of Legionnaires' disease? A) Drink plenty of water B) Take over-the-counter pain relievers C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Go to the gym E) Eat spicy food
C
Which of the following can be sources of Legionnaires' disease? A) Air conditioning systems B) Humidifiers C) Spa pools and hot tubs D) Taps and showers that are not used often E) Toilet seats
A,B,C,D
What is the typical treatment for Legionnaires' disease? A) Bed rest B) Antibiotics given directly into a vein C) Vitamin supplements D) Oxygen through a face mask or tubes in your nose E) Surgery
B,D
What is the usual duration of antibiotic treatment for Legionnaires' disease? A) 1 to 3 weeks B) 1 month C) 2 months D) 6 months E) 1 year
A

Which of the following is NOT a common source of Legionnaires' disease? A) Drinking water that contains the bacteria B) Other people with the infection C) Places like ponds, lakes, and rivers D) Humidifiers E) Spa pools and hot tubs
A,B,C
