What should you do if you have a cough that's lasted 3 weeks or more? A) Ignore it B) Take a hot shower C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Drink more milk E) Go for a run
C
What might be needed if you are diagnosed with Legionnaires' disease? A) A machine to help you breathe B) Regular exercise C) A special diet D) Daily massages E) Antibiotics
A,E

What should you do if someone has heat exhaustion? A) Move them to a cool place B) Remove all unnecessary clothing C) Get them to drink a sports or rehydration drink D) Give them a hot bath E) Wrap them in a blanket
A), B)
Which of the following are signs of heat exhaustion? A) Tiredness B) Dizziness C) Excessive sweating D) Cold skin E) Lack of thirst
A), B)
What should you do if someone has heat exhaustion and you're struggling to treat the symptoms? A) Call 999 B) Drive them to A&E C) Contact 111 D) Give them a cold shower E) Call a friend
C), D)
Which of the following are signs of heatstroke? A) Hot skin that's not sweating B) A very high temperature C) Confusion and lack of coordination D) A seizure or fit E) Feeling cold
A), B)

What should you do if someone has heat exhaustion and is still unwell after 30 minutes of resting in a cool place? A) Call 999 B) Give them more water C) Put them in the recovery position D) Wrap them in a heating blanket E) Give them a hot drink
A), C)

To help prevent heat exhaustion or heatstroke, what should you do? A) Drink more cold drinks B) Wear light-coloured, loose clothing C) Avoid the sun between 11am and 3pm D) Exercise heavily E) Drink hot beverages
A), B)
What should you do if someone has heat exhaustion and is not getting better? A) Call 999 B) Drive them to A&E C) Contact 111 D) Keep them in a hot room E) Give them a hot drink
A), C)
Which of the following are symptoms of heat exhaustion? A) Headache B) Feeling sick or being sick C) Fast breathing or heartbeat D) Feeling very cold E) Skin becoming dry
A), B)

What should you do to cool someone down if they have heat exhaustion? A) Spray or sponge them with cool water B) Fan them C) Use cold packs under the armpits or on the neck D) Wrap them in a heating blanket E) Give them a cold shower
A), B)

What should you do if you are inside on a very hot day to prevent heat exhaustion or heatstroke? A) Close curtains B) Close windows if it's hotter outside C) Turn off electrical equipment and lights that get hot D) Open all windows E) Turn on all electrical equipment
A), B)
Which of the following is a common cause of hip pain? A) Sprain or strain B) Osteoarthritis C) Rheumatoid arthritis D) Joint infection E) Hip fracture
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you have severe hip pain that started suddenly but you've not had a fall or injured your hip? A) Call 999 B) See a GP C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Use painkillers E) Do gentle stretching exercises
C
Which of the following are symptoms of a hip fracture? A) Severe pain B) Unable to walk C) Hot, swollen hip D) Stiffness after moving E) Pain worse when walking
A,B
What should you do if hip pain is stopping you doing normal activities or affecting your sleep? A) See a GP B) Call 999 C) Use ice pack D) Wear comfortable shoes E) Do not sit in low chairs
A
Which of the following are treatments for hip pain? A) Stronger painkillers B) Physiotherapy C) Occupational therapy D) Steroid injections E) Hip replacement
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you have hip pain and feel generally unwell and have a high temperature or feel hot and shivery? A) See a GP B) Call 999 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Use painkillers E) Rest
C
Which of the following are symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis? A) Pain and stiffness worse after not moving B) Hot, swollen hip C) Severe pain D) Unable to walk E) Bruising after exercise
A
What should you do if you have severe hip pain after a fall or injury? A) See a GP B) Call 999 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Use painkillers E) Do gentle stretching exercises
B
Which of the following are symptoms of osteoarthritis? A) Over 45 years of age, pain worse when walking B) Stiffness after moving C) Hot, swollen hip D) Severe pain E) Bruising after exercise
A,B

What should you do if the hip pain has not improved after treating it at home for 2 weeks? A) See a GP B) Call 999 C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Use painkillers E) Do gentle stretching exercises
A
What are dentures made of? A) Gold B) Acrylic (plastic) C) Nylon D) Metal E) Wood
B,C,D
What problems can gaps left by missing teeth cause? A) Eating difficulties B) Speech issues C) Teeth growing into the gap D) Headaches E) Loss of taste
A,B,C
What types of dentures are there? A) Complete dentures B) Partial dentures C) Temporary dentures D) Permanent dentures E) Replacement dentures
A,B
What can dentures help prevent? A) Eating problems B) Speech problems C) Gum disease D) Tooth decay E) Heart disease
A,B,C,D
Who can fit dentures? A) Dentist B) Clinical dental technician C) Orthodontist D) General practitioner E) Pharmacist
A,B

What should you do if you remove your dentures at night? A) Keep them moist B) Store them in a dry place C) Clean them with toothpaste D) Store them in a sealed box E) Keep them in water or a suitable cleaning solution
A,E
What should you avoid eating with new dentures? A) Soft foods B) Chewing gum C) Sticky foods D) Hard foods E) Sharp-edged foods
B,C,D,E
What can happen if dentures are not cleaned regularly? A) Bad breath B) Gum disease C) Tooth decay D) Oral thrush E) Headaches
A,B,C,D
What should you use to clean your dentures? A) Toothpaste B) Denture cleaner C) Soap D) Mouthwash E) Non-abrasive denture cleaner
B,E

When should you see your dentist regarding your dentures? A) When they click while talking B) When they slip C) When they feel uncomfortable D) When they are visibly worn E) When you have signs of gum disease
A,B,C,D,E

What is polyhydramnios? A) A condition with too little amniotic fluid B) A condition with too much amniotic fluid C) A condition with no amniotic fluid D) A condition with too much blood flow E) A condition with too little blood flow
B)
What symptoms might indicate polyhydramnios? A) Indigestion and heartburn B) Constipation C) Breathlessness D) Swollen feet and legs E) Urinary tract infections (UTIs)
What should you do if you experience a sudden increase in tummy size? A) Wait for it to go away B) Call your midwife C) Take painkillers D) Do nothing E) Get help from NHS 111
B),E)
How might polyhydramnios be diagnosed? A) Blood test B) Biopsy C) Ultrasound scan D) Physical examination E) X-ray
C),D)

What are some possible causes of polyhydramnios? A) Gestational diabetes B) Being pregnant with more than 1 baby C) An infection during pregnancy D) A problem with your baby swallowing E) Your baby having a genetic condition
What treatments might be offered for polyhydramnios? A) Draining amniotic fluid B) Blood transfusion C) Extra check-ups D) Surgery E) Medication
A),C)
What complications can arise from severe polyhydramnios? A) Waters breaking early B) Placental abruption C) Umbilical cord prolapse D) Premature birth E) Low birth weight

Why might you need to give birth in hospital if you have polyhydramnios? A) To be monitored closely B) To avoid any problems C) To ensure quick treatment D) To have a caesarean section E) To avoid infection
What might make it harder to hear the baby's heartbeat at appointments? A) Extra amniotic fluid B) Low blood pressure C) High blood pressure D) Gestational diabetes E) Fetal movements
A)
What should you do if you have concerns about your labour and birth plan? A) Talk to your doctor B) Talk to your midwife C) Talk to your family D) Talk to your friends E) Look it up online
B)
Which of the following could be common causes of tiredness and fatigue? A) Insomnia B) Unhealthy lifestyle C) Stress D) Kidney stones E) Excessive caffeine intake
A,B,
What are some illnesses that can cause tiredness and fatigue? A) Glandular fever B) COVID-19 C) Common cold D) Flu E) Strep throat
A,B,
Which of the following are hormonal changes that can cause tiredness and fatigue? A) Puberty B) Pregnancy C) Menopause D) High blood pressure E) Diabetes
A,B,
What are some symptoms of iron deficiency anaemia? A) Lack of energy B) Heart palpitations C) Shortness of breath D) Fever E) Joint pain
A,B,
What are some symptoms of overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)? A) Very tired B) Feeling nervous C) Muscle weakness D) Headache E) Dizziness
A,B,
What can you do to help with tiredness or fatigue? A) Have a healthy diet B) Exercise regularly C) Stay up late D) Drink lots of soda E) Use smartphones before sleep
A,B,

What are some symptoms of myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)? A) Extreme fatigue for at least 3 months B) Problems with thinking C) Flu-like symptoms D) Itchy skin E) Blurred vision
A,B,
Which of the following should you avoid to help with tiredness or fatigue? A) Do not smoke B) Do not drink too much alcohol C) Eat more sugary snacks D) Exercise more E) Use screens before sleep
A,B,
What are some possible treatments for tiredness or fatigue? A) Talking therapies B) Advice on better sleep C) Herbal supplements D) Acupuncture E) Meditation
A,B,

When should you see a GP regarding tiredness or fatigue? A) If you've been feeling tired for a few weeks B) If your tiredness affects daily life C) If you feel tired and have weight loss D) If you have a fever E) After drinking alcohol
A,B,
Which types of cardiomyopathy are mentioned in the text? A) Dilated cardiomyopathy B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy D) Inflammatory cardiomyopathy E) Tachycardia
A,B,
What are the symptoms associated with heart failure? A) Shortness of breath B) Extreme tiredness C) Ankle swelling D) Headaches E) Joint pain
A,B,
What are the possible causes of dilated cardiomyopathy? A) Inherited gene mutation B) Uncontrolled high blood pressure C) Viral infection D) Lack of exercise E) Poor diet
A,B,
What are the possible symptoms of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? A) Dizziness B) Chest pain C) Shortness of breath D) Temporary loss of consciousness E) Nausea
A,B,
What are the diagnostic tests for cardiomyopathy? A) Electrocardiogram (ECG) B) Echocardiogram C) MRI scan D) Blood test E) X-ray
A,B,
What lifestyle changes are recommended for managing cardiomyopathy? A) Eat a healthy diet B) Do gentle exercise C) Quit smoking D) Drink more alcohol E) Avoid stress
A,B,

What are the treatment options for obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? A) Injection of alcohol into the heart B) Septal myectomy C) Medication for blood pressure D) Physical therapy E) Open heart surgery
A,B,
What are the potential risks associated with dilated cardiomyopathy? A) Heart failure B) Heart valve problems C) Irregular heartbeat D) Liver disease E) Kidney failure
A,B,
What are the possible complications of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? A) Heart infection (endocarditis) B) Abnormal heart rhythms C) Leaky mitral valve D) High cholesterol E) Diabetes
A,B,
What are the symptoms of restrictive cardiomyopathy? A) Breathlessness B) Tiredness C) Ankle swelling D) Headaches E) Fever
A,B,
What is epilepsy? A) A rare condition affecting the heart B) A common condition affecting the brain C) A virus D) A mental illness E) A skin disorder
B
What are seizures? A) Bursts of electrical activity in the brain B) Heart palpitations C) Muscle cramps D) Fever E) Hallucinations
A
What age does epilepsy usually start? A) Teenage years B) Middle age C) Childhood or in people over 60 D) Young adults E) Infancy
C
What are possible symptoms of epilepsy? A) Uncontrollable jerking and shaking B) Losing awareness and staring blankly C) Becoming stiff D) Strange sensations E) Passing out
A,B,C,D,E

When should you call 999 for an ambulance regarding epilepsy? A) If someone is having a seizure for the first time B) If a seizure lasts more than 5 minutes C) If someone has lots of seizures in a row D) If someone has breathing problems or is seriously injured E) If someone is having a mild headache
A,B,C,D
What are the main treatments for epilepsy? A) Anti-epileptic drugs B) Surgery to remove part of the brain C) A procedure to put an electrical device in the body D) A special diet E) Herbal remedies
A,B,C,D

Can people with epilepsy have normal lives? A) Yes, if seizures are well controlled B) No, epilepsy is too debilitating C) Only if they take herbal supplements D) Only if they avoid all physical activity E) Only if they live in isolation
A
What factors should people with epilepsy consider before doing certain activities? A) Driving B) Certain jobs C) Swimming D) Using contraception E) Planning a pregnancy
A,B,C,D,E
What can cause epilepsy? A) Stroke B) Brain tumour C) Severe head injury D) Drug abuse E) Brain infection
A,B,C,D,E
What is the main cause of epilepsy? A) Scrambled electrical signals in the brain B) Heart disease C) Kidney failure D) Lung infection E) Skin infection
A
What are the symptoms of type 1 diabetes? A) Fatigue B) Dizziness C) Frequent urination D) Headache E) Weight loss
C,E,
What is one of the main treatments for type 1 diabetes? A) Diet pills B) Insulin C) Aspirin D) Vitamins E) Antibiotics
B,
What is a common complication of type 1 diabetes? A) Hypoglycemia B) Hyperglycemia C) Tooth decay D) Common cold E) Allergies
A,B,
What is a tool used to monitor blood glucose levels in type 1 diabetes? A) Thermometer B) Blood pressure monitor C) Continuous glucose monitor (CGM) D) Oxygen saturation monitor E) ECG machine
C,
What should a person with type 1 diabetes do to manage their condition? A) Exercise regularly B) Count carbohydrates C) Avoid all sugars D) Drink alcohol daily E) Take painkillers
A,B,
What is a common issue that type 1 diabetics may face? A) Hypos B) Hypertension C) Anemia D) Asthma E) Hypers
A,E,
What is a useful resource for children and young people with type 1 diabetes? A) My Type 1 Diabetes B) DigiBete C) WebMD D) Wikipedia E) NHS Choices
B,
What is a recommended course for type 1 diabetics? A) Insulin therapy course B) Dietary course C) Type 1 diabetes course D) Exercise course E) Meditation course
C,
What is a common device used to administer insulin? A) Insulin pump B) Inhaler C) Nebulizer D) Pill dispenser E) Syringe
A,E,
What is a common symptom when newly diagnosed with type 1 diabetes? A) Increased thirst B) Blurred vision C) Itching D) Hair loss E) Increased appetite
A,E,
Which parts of the body are most commonly affected by fungal nail infections? A) Toenails B) Fingernails C) Elbows D) Knees E) Ears
A, B
Where do fungal nail infections usually start? A) Center of the nail B) Edge of the nail C) Tip of the nail D) Beneath the skin E) Center of the toe
B
What are the common symptoms of a fungal nail infection? A) Brittle nails B) Discoloured nails C) Thicker nails D) Painful heels E) Swollen toes
A, B, C
What can a pharmacist suggest for treating a fungal nail infection? A) Antifungal nail medicine B) Painkillers C) Antibiotics D) Vitamin supplements E) Corticosteroids
A

What should you do if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system and get a fungal nail infection? A) See a podiatrist B) Ignore the infection C) Use home remedies D) Apply antifungal cream E) Drink more water
A
How long does it typically take to treat a fungal nail infection with antifungal nail medicine? A) 1-2 weeks B) 1 month C) 2-3 months D) 6-12 months E) 1 year
D
What are some side effects of antifungal tablets prescribed for fungal nail infections? A) Headaches B) Itchy rash C) Stomach ache D) Feeling sick and diarrhoea E) High blood pressure
A, B, C, D
What should you do to prevent fungal nail infections? A) Treat athlete's foot B) Keep your nails short C) Keep your feet clean and dry D) Wear flip-flops in showers E) Share towels
A, B, C, D

What can happen if a fungal nail infection is left untreated in someone with diabetes? A) It can cause serious health problems B) It can cause headaches C) It can cause fever D) It can cause indigestion E) It can cause dizziness
A

What should you do if you have a severe fungal nail infection that hasn't responded to treatment? A) See a GP B) Wait for it to go away C) Apply more antifungal cream D) Soak your feet in hot water E) Use essential oils
A
Which factors increase the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)? A) Premature birth B) High birthweight C) Sleeping on the back D) Smoking during pregnancy E) Sleeping on a sofa
A,D,E

What are some recommendations to reduce the risk of SIDS? A) Always place the baby on their stomach to sleep B) Place the baby in the 'feet to foot' position C) Keep the baby's head uncovered D) Let the baby sleep in the same room as you for the first 6 months E) Use a soft, uneven mattress
B,C,D
What are the signs that require immediate medical attention for a baby? A) Baby stops breathing B) Baby has a slight cough C) Baby is unconscious D) Baby has a minor illness E) Baby will not wake up
A,C,E

What should you avoid to reduce the risk of SIDS? A) Not sharing a bed with your baby if you or your partner smoke B) Sharing a bed with your baby if they weighed under 2.5kg at birth C) Smoking during pregnancy D) Sleeping on a sofa with your baby E) Letting the baby get too hot
A,C,D

What are some precautions to take when sharing a bed with your baby? A) Make sure there are no pillows or duvets near your baby B) Keep other children and pets in the bed C) Use a firm, flat, waterproof mattress D) Sleep on a sofa with your baby E) Keep the baby's head uncovered
A,C,E
What is the recommended room temperature for a baby's comfortable sleeping environment? A) 10C to 15C B) 16C to 20C C) 21C to 25C D) 26C to 30C E) 31C to 35C
B

What are some steps to take if you're worried about your baby's health? A) Give your baby plenty of fluids B) See your GP or call NHS 111 C) Let your baby get too hot D) Ignore minor illnesses E) Dial 999 for an ambulance if your baby stops breathing
A,B,E

What are some support services available if a baby dies suddenly and unexpectedly? A) The Lullaby Trust B) Local sources of help and support C) Police and healthcare professionals D) SUDC.UK E) Bereavement counseling
A,B,C

What are some benefits of breastfeeding related to SIDS prevention? A) Breastfeeding reduces the risk of SIDS B) Breastfeeding increases the risk of SIDS C) Breastfeeding has no effect on SIDS D) Breastfeeding helps regulate the baby's temperature E) Breastfeeding makes the baby sleep on their back
A,D

What are the differences between SIDS and SUDC? A) SIDS affects babies under 1 year old B) SUDC affects children over 1 year old C) SIDS is more common in baby boys D) SUDC is caused by tobacco smoke E) SIDS is more common in premature babies
A,B,C

When should you call 999 or go to A&E immediately for shortness of breath? A) If you have severe difficulty breathing B) If your chest feels tight or heavy C) If you feel suddenly confused D) If your lips or skin are turning very pale, blue or grey E) If you feel sick or are being sick
A, B, C, D

What are some immediate action indicators for children with shortness of breath? A) If they have difficulty breathing – they may make grunting noises B) If they are suddenly confused (agitated, behaving oddly or crying constantly) C) If they are limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do D) If they have lips or skin that are turning very pale, blue or grey E) If they have a fever
A, B, C, D

When should you contact NHS 111 for shortness of breath? A) If you have difficulty breathing B) If you feel sick or are being sick C) If you're coughing up blood D) If you have pain or swelling in 1 of your legs E) If you have heart palpitations
A, B, C, D, E

When should you see a GP for shortness of breath? A) If your shortness of breath gets worse when you've been doing your normal activities B) If you feel short of breath and have swollen ankles C) If you've been coughing for 3 weeks or more D) If you have a headache E) If you have a rash
A, B, C
What are some common causes of shortness of breath? A) Asthma B) A chest infection C) Being overweight D) Smoking E) A heart murmur
A, B, C, D
What could be more serious causes of shortness of breath? A) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) B) Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis C) Heart failure D) Lung cancer E) A common cold
A, B, C, D

What should you not do if you experience shortness of breath? A) Drive to A&E B) Bring any medicines you take with you C) Call 999 D) Ask someone to drive you E) Try to self-diagnose the cause of shortness of breath
A, E

What are some resources for coping with shortness of breath? A) Asthma + Lung UK: living well with breathlessness B) Supporting someone with breathlessness website C) NHS 111 D) National Heart Foundation E) Local pharmacy
A, B

What are some symptoms that require immediate medical attention for adults? A) Severe difficulty breathing B) Chest feels tight or heavy C) Pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck and jaw D) Lips or skin are turning very pale, blue or grey E) Feeling tired
A, B, C, D

What are some symptoms that require immediate medical attention for children? A) Difficulty breathing – they may make grunting noises B) Suddenly confused (agitated, behaving oddly or crying constantly) C) Limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do D) Lips or skin are turning very pale, blue or grey E) Having a runny nose
A, B, C, D
What is the main symptom of colour vision deficiency? A) Seeing double B) Blurred vision C) Difficulty telling colours apart D) Eye pain E) Sensitivity to light
C)

Which of the following can be a sign of colour vision deficiency in a child? A) Using the wrong colours when drawing B) Having difficulty with colouring tasks C) Lacking interest in colouring D) Smelling food before eating E) Complaining of eye pain
What are the two main tests for colour vision deficiency? A) Ishihara test B) Eye chart test C) Colour arrangement tests D) Blood tests E) MRI scan
A),C)
Who can get free NHS eye tests? A) Children under 18 B) People with diabetes C) People on Universal Credit D) People with glaucoma E) People with high blood pressure
What should you do if you or your child has signs of colour vision deficiency? A) Go to the emergency room B) Visit an optician C) Take a home test D) Wait for it to go away E) Consult a dietician
B)
What can cause colour vision deficiency? A) Eye conditions like glaucoma B) Other conditions like diabetes C) An eye or head injury D) A stroke E) Allergies
Which of the following careers might be affected by colour vision deficiency? A) Pilot B) Train driver C) Teacher D) Nurse E) Lawyer
A),B)
What should you do if your child has been diagnosed with colour vision deficiency? A) Tell the school B) Change their diet C) Keep them indoors D) Give them medication E) Ignore it
A)
What is the current treatment for familial colour vision deficiency? A) Surgery B) Medication C) Glasses D) Most people adapt E) Eye drops
D)

What can help if colour vision deficiency is caused by an underlying medical condition? A) Changing medicines B) Treating the condition C) Wearing sunglasses D) Avoiding bright lights E) Eating more vegetables
A),B)
How is hepatitis A spread? A) Through unclean water B) By sharing needles C) Through physical contact D) Through the air E) By eating shellfish
A, B, C
Which parts of the world have a higher risk of hepatitis A? A) Africa B) Asia C) The Middle East D) Europe E) Australia
A, B, C
What are some symptoms of hepatitis A infection? A) High temperature B) Jaundice C) Dark brown pee D) Sneezing E) Coughing
A, B, C
Who is at high risk of catching hepatitis A? A) Travelers to high-risk countries B) People with long-term liver disease C) Healthcare workers D) People with asthma E) Pregnant women
A, B, C
What are some ways to prevent hepatitis A? A) Vaccination B) Drinking bottled water C) Avoiding shellfish D) Wearing a mask E) Using a condom
A, B, C

How long are you usually infectious with hepatitis A? A) 7 days after jaundice starts B) 7 days after symptoms start C) 14 days after symptoms start D) 30 days after jaundice starts E) 2 days after symptoms start
A, B, C
What should you do if you think you have hepatitis A? A) See a GP B) Drink plenty of fluids C) Avoid preparing food for others D) Take a hot shower E) Share needles with others
A, B, C
What are some things you should not do if you have hepatitis A? A) Drink alcohol B) Prepare food for others C) Have sex without a condom D) Take painkillers E) Wear loose-fitting clothing
A, B, C
Which countries are considered high-risk for hepatitis A? A) United States B) Central and South America C) Africa D) Australia E) The Middle East
B, C, E

What are some ways to reduce the risk of hepatitis A when traveling? A) Washing hands thoroughly B) Drinking bottled water C) Avoiding uncooked fruit and vegetables D) Using a condom E) Sharing needles
A, B, C
Which age group is lichen sclerosus most common in? A) Children B) Men over 50 C) Women over 50 D) Teenagers E) Elderly men
C,E
What are the common symptoms of lichen sclerosus? A) Itchy white patches B) Smooth or crinkled skin C) Easily damaged skin D) Red patches E) Purple spots
A,B
Where does lichen sclerosus most often appear? A) On the scalp B) Around the opening to the vagina (vulva) and anus C) On the foreskin and end of the penis D) On the back E) On the face
B,C

What should you not do if you have lichen sclerosus? A) Scratch or rub the affected skin B) Wear tight or restrictive clothes C) Wash your underwear with detergent D) Use vaginal lubricant E) Apply cream regularly
A,B
What is the most common treatment for lichen sclerosus? A) Antibiotics B) Steroid cream C) Painkillers D) Surgery E) Physical therapy
B,D
What can happen to the skin affected by lichen sclerosus over time? A) It becomes smoother B) It becomes scarred and tight C) It turns purple D) It becomes less sensitive E) It becomes more elastic
B,C
What are the possible complications of lichen sclerosus? A) Increased risk of cancer B) Headaches C) Nausea D) High fever E) Fatigue
A,D
What might cause lichen sclerosus? A) Poor personal hygiene B) Immune system attacking the skin C) Bacterial infection D) Viral infection E) Excessive sun exposure
B,C
What should you use instead of regular soap if you have lichen sclerosus? A) Regular shampoo B) Emollient soap substitute C) Baking soda D) Lemon juice E) Vinegar
B,D

What should you do if you have been diagnosed with lichen sclerosus and treatment is not helping? A) Take over-the-counter painkillers B) See a GP C) Stop all treatments D) Increase physical activity E) Change your diet
B,E
What are the main symptoms of Behçet's disease? A) Genital and mouth ulcers B) Red, painful eyes and blurred vision C) Acne-like spots D) Headaches E) Painful, stiff and swollen joints
A,B,C,D
What are some of the serious and potentially life-threatening problems associated with Behçet's disease? A) Permanent vision loss B) Strokes C) Heart failure D) Diabetes E) Kidney failure
A,B
Which tests may be used to diagnose Behçet's disease? A) Blood tests B) Urine tests C) X-rays D) CT scan E) MRI scan
A,B,C,D

What is a pathergy test? A) A test that involves pricking your skin with a needle B) A test that involves injecting a dye C) A test that involves a blood sample D) A test that involves a urine sample E) A test that involves a hair sample
A
What are the criteria for a confident diagnosis of Behçet's disease? A) At least 3 episodes of mouth ulcers over the past 12 months B) Genital ulcers C) Eye inflammation D) Skin lesions E) Pathergy
A,B,C,D
What is thought to be the cause of Behçet's disease? A) An autoinflammatory condition B) A bacterial infection C) A viral infection D) A fungal infection E) A genetic disorder
A
Which ethnic groups are most likely to develop Behçet's disease? A) Mediterranean B) Middle Eastern C) Asian D) African E) European
A,B,C
Which medicines are used to control the symptoms of Behçet's disease? A) Steroids B) Immunosuppressants C) Biological therapies D) Antibiotics E) Painkillers
A,B,C
Where are the NHS Centres of Excellence for Behçet's disease located in England? A) London B) Birmingham C) Liverpool D) Manchester E) Leeds
A,B,C

What is the role of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) in relation to Behçet's disease? A) To help scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat the condition B) To provide financial support to patients C) To conduct clinical trials D) To offer psychological counseling E) To provide home care services
A

Which parts of the brain are affected by frontotemporal dementia? A) The occipital and parietal lobes B) The frontal and temporal lobes C) The cerebellum and brainstem D) The thalamus and hypothalamus E) The motor cortex and sensory cortex
What is the typical age range for diagnosis of frontotemporal dementia? A) 25-45 B) 45-65 C) 65-85 D) 85-105 E) 105-125

Which of the following are symptoms of frontotemporal dementia? A) Loss of vision B) Acting inappropriately or impulsively C) Struggling with planning and organization D) Speaking slowly E) Severe headaches

What are some of the physical problems that may occur with frontotemporal dementia? A) Slow or stiff movements B) Loss of bladder or bowel control C) Muscle weakness D) Difficulty swallowing E) Loss of hearing
Which tests may be used to diagnose frontotemporal dementia? A) Blood tests B) MRI scan C) Lumbar puncture D) EKG E) Eye exam
What are some treatments for frontotemporal dementia? A) Physiotherapy B) Occupational therapy C) Speech and language therapy D) Chemotherapy E) Radiation therapy
What is the average survival time after the onset of frontotemporal dementia symptoms? A) 2-4 years B) 5-7 years C) 8-10 years D) 11-13 years E) 14-16 years
What causes frontotemporal dementia? A) Clumps of abnormal protein forming inside brain cells B) Viral infection C) Nutritional deficiency D) Trauma E) Bacterial infection
What are some other names for frontotemporal dementia? A) FTD B) Pick's disease C) Frontotemporal lobar degeneration D) Behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia E) Progressive non-fluent aphasia
What are some of the support services available for people with dementia? A) NHS and social services B) Voluntary organizations C) Specialist support groups D) Genetic testing E) Acupuncture
What is the main characteristic of restricted growth (dwarfism)? A) Extremely tall height B) Unusually short height C) Abnormal weight gain D) Enlarged body parts E) Excessive hair growth
B,D

Which of the following are types of restricted growth? A) Proportionate short stature (PSS) B) Disproportionate short stature (DSS) C) Elastic short stature D) Fluid short stature E) Flexible short stature
A,B
What are some physical problems associated with restricted growth? A) Bowed legs B) Curved spine C) Enlarged ears D) Extra fingers E) Webbed toes
A,B
What are some common causes of proportionate short stature (PSS)? A) Being born to small parents B) Growth hormone deficiency C) Noonan syndrome D) Prader-Willi syndrome E) Achondroplasia
A,B
Which genetic syndromes can cause proportionate short stature (PSS)? A) Turner syndrome B) Noonan syndrome C) Prader-Willi syndrome D) Down syndrome E) Marfan syndrome
A,B
What is the most common cause of disproportionate short stature (DSS)? A) Achondroplasia B) Osteoporosis C) Scoliosis D) Rickets E) Osteogenesis imperfecta
A,C
How is growth hormone deficiency diagnosed? A) Growth hormone stimulation tests B) Brain scan C) Blood tests D) Ultrasound E) X-ray
A,B
What treatments are available for restricted growth? A) Growth hormone injections B) Leg-lengthening procedure C) Vitamin supplements D) Physical therapy E) Surgery
A,B
What is achondroplasia? A) A rare genetic condition causing poor bone growth B) A condition affecting the eyes C) A skin disorder D) A lung disease E) A heart condition
A,D
What are some methods used to diagnose restricted growth? A) Growth hormone stimulation tests B) Brain scan C) Prenatal diagnosis D) Blood tests E) MRI
A,C
What is the common term for high blood pressure? A) Hypotension B) Hypertension C) Thrombosis D) Hyperglycemia E) Hypoglycemia
B)
Which of the following is not a risk factor for high blood pressure? A) Age B) Ethnicity C) Diet high in sugar D) Smoking E) Overweight
C)
What should you do if you think you might have high blood pressure? A) Ignore it B) Get your blood pressure checked C) Take aspirin daily D) Drink more coffee E) Stop exercising
B)
Which symptom is rarely associated with high blood pressure? A) Headaches B) Blurred vision C) Chest pain D) Nausea E) Dizziness
A)
What should you do if you have chest pain that comes and goes? A) Ignore it B) Call 999 C) Take a nap D) Eat a salty snack E) Get help from NHS 111
E)

What does a blood pressure reading of 140/90 indicate for someone under 80 years old? A) Normal blood pressure B) Low blood pressure C) High blood pressure D) Critically low blood pressure E) Critically high blood pressure
C)
What is a potential risk of untreated high blood pressure? A) Diabetes B) Heart attacks C) Arthritis D) Asthma E) Osteoporosis
B)
What is one lifestyle change recommended to lower blood pressure? A) Eating more salt B) Drinking more alcohol C) Exercising regularly D) Smoking E) Eating more sugary foods
C)

When is a GP likely to prescribe medicine for high blood pressure? A) If your blood pressure is normal B) If you're at lower risk of problems C) If your blood pressure is very high D) If you're underweight E) If you have low blood pressure
C)
Where can you get more information and advice about high blood pressure? A) Local bakery B) Blood Pressure UK C) Local gym D) Local library E) Local cinema
B)

What is spirometry used for? A) Diagnosing heart attacks B) Measuring how much air you can breathe out in one forced breath C) Diagnosing skin conditions D) Monitoring lung conditions E) Checking for diabetes
B,D
Which of the following conditions can be diagnosed using spirometry? A) Asthma B) Cystic fibrosis C) Pulmonary fibrosis D) Appendicitis E) Rheumatoid arthritis
A,B,C
What should you avoid doing before a spirometry test? A) Smoking B) Drinking alcohol C) Strenuous exercise D) Eating large meals E) Taking a shower
A,B,C,D
During a spirometry test, you will be asked to: A) Run on a treadmill B) Inhale fully C) Exhale quickly D) Hold your breath for a minute E) Swallow a pill
B,C
What type of lung disease can spirometry help diagnose? A) Obstructive airways disease B) Restrictive lung disease C) Infectious lung disease D) Allergic lung disease E) Genetic lung disease
A,B

Who might be advised to undergo spirometry? A) People with a persistent cough B) People over 35 who smoke C) People with high blood pressure D) People with a recent head injury E) People with a persistent rash
A,B
What might be the side effects of a spirometry test? A) Dizziness B) Fainting C) Feeling shaky D) Feeling sick E) Severe headache
A,B,C,D
Which of the following is a contraindication for spirometry? A) Unstable angina B) Recent heart attack C) Uncontrolled high blood pressure D) Recent stomach surgery E) Recent foot surgery
A,B,C,D
What does a spirometer measure? A) Heart rate B) Amount of air you can breathe out in one second C) Blood pressure D) Total volume of air you can exhale in one forced breath E) Body temperature
B,D
Why might spirometry be performed before surgery? A) To check general health B) To diagnose cancer C) To measure blood sugar levels D) To assess lung function E) To check for infections
A,D
What is an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)? A) A liver condition B) A swelling in the aorta C) A type of kidney stone D) A heart disease E) A lung infection
B)
What is the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the tummy? A) Vein B) Aorta C) Capillary D) Arteriole E) Bronchial artery
B)
What are the main symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Tummy or back pain B) Pulsing feeling in your tummy C) Lump in your tummy D) Itchy skin E) Loss of hearing
What should you do if you have sudden, severe pain in your tummy or back? A) Call 999 B) Take painkillers C) Drink plenty of water D) Wait and see E) Call a friend
A)
What is the main test to find out if you have an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) X-ray B) Ultrasound scan C) Blood test D) MRI E) CT scan
B)
What are the sizes of an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Small (3cm to 4.4cm or smaller) B) Medium (4.5cm to 5.4cm) C) Large (5.5cm or bigger) D) Extra-large (over 7cm) E) Micro (less than 1cm)
At what age are men offered abdominal aortic aneurysm screening? A) 50 B) 60 C) 65 D) 70 E) 75
C)
What lifestyle changes can help lower the risk of getting an abdominal aortic aneurysm? A) Eat healthily B) Exercise regularly C) Try to lose weight D) Smoke cigarettes E) Increase alcohol intake

What are some common sounds associated with tinnitus? A) Ringing B) Buzzing C) Whooshing D) Throbbing E) Crackling
