What treatment can a GP offer for corns and calluses? A) Give antibiotics if infected B) Refer to a foot specialist C) Provide pain relief D) Cut away the corn or callus E) Apply ice packs
A,B

What can a foot specialist do to treat corns and calluses? A) Cut away the corn or callus B) Provide patches to soften the skin C) Offer specially made soft pads D) Apply ice packs E) Prescribe painkillers
A,B,C

What should you do to find out about self-referring to a podiatrist? A) Ask the reception staff at your GP surgery B) Check your GP surgery's website C) Contact your integrated care board (ICB) D) Search online for NHS podiatrists near you E) Ignore the problem
A,B,C,D
What are probiotics primarily composed of? A: Live bacteria and yeasts B: Dead bacteria and yeasts C: Chemicals D: Vitamins E: Minerals
A,B,
How are probiotics typically consumed? A: As food supplements B: In yoghurts C: As injections D: Inhaled E: Intravenously
A,B,
What is one potential benefit of probiotics? A: Helping to ease some symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) B: Curing cancer C: Treating eczema D: Improving eyesight E: Enhancing muscle strength
A,

What is a concern regarding the regulation of probiotics? A: They are classed as medicine B: They go through rigorous testing C: The product may not contain the bacteria stated on the label D: They are always effective E: They are expensive
C,

What should you do before taking probiotic supplements if you have a weakened immune system? A: Consult a nutritionist B: Take double the dose C: Avoid all dairy products D: Talk to a doctor E: Increase your exercise
D,

What is a potential issue with the effectiveness of probiotics? A: The bacteria may not survive long enough to reach your gut B: Probiotics are always effective C: Probiotics are only available in medicine form D: Probiotics are only for children E: Probiotics are only effective in winter
A,
What is one area where probiotics have shown little evidence of effectiveness? A: Treating eczema B: Improving digestion C: Boosting the immune system D: Enhancing skin health E: Reducing stress
A,

What is a general safety statement about probiotics for most people? A: Probiotics are unsafe for everyone B: Probiotics are safe for most people C: Probiotics cause severe side effects D: Probiotics should be avoided by healthy individuals E: Probiotics are only safe for children
B,

What is the primary function of probiotics in the gut? A: To restore the natural balance of bacteria B: To kill all bacteria C: To increase stomach acid D: To promote weight loss E: To reduce appetite
A,

What is a consideration when choosing a type of probiotic? A: Different types may have different effects on the body B: All types of probiotics are the same C: Only one type of probiotic exists D: Probiotics are only effective in pill form E: Probiotics are only for adults
A,
What is the characteristic feeling of vertigo? A: Feeling dizzy B: Feeling like everything is spinning C: Feeling lightheaded D: Feeling like you are falling E: Feeling like you are running
B,C,

What should you do to ease vertigo symptoms? A: Move your head quickly B: Turn on the lights if you get up at night C: Sleep with your head slightly raised D: Bend over to pick things up E: Use a walking stick if you're at risk of falling
B,C,E,

When should you see a GP for vertigo? A: If you have vertigo that will not go away B: If you have vertigo and a severe headache C: If you have vertigo and a very high temperature D: If you have vertigo and double vision E: If you have vertigo and leg or arm weakness
A,C,
What should you bring with you if you go to A&E for vertigo? A: A list of your allergies B: Any medicines you take C: Your ID card D: A friend E: A change of clothes
B,D,
What could a GP prescribe for vertigo caused by an infection? A: Painkillers B: Antibiotics C: Steroids D: Antihistamines E: Vitamins
B,D,
What should you do if you drive and have vertigo? A: Stop driving immediately B: Tell the DVLA about your vertigo C: Only drive during the day D: Avoid highways E: Carry a special permit
B,C,
What are the most common causes of vertigo? A: Inner ear problems B: Heart problems C: Brain tumors D: Low blood sugar E: High blood pressure
A,D,
What is BPPV? A: A type of migraine B: A condition where specific head movements cause vertigo C: A form of diabetes D: A heart condition E: A type of eye infection
B,D,
What is labyrinthitis? A: An inner ear infection caused by a cold or flu virus B: A type of skin rash C: A brain infection D: A lung condition E: A type of food poisoning
A,D,
What is Ménière's disease? A: A rare inner ear condition B: A type of arthritis C: A form of cancer D: A liver disease E: A cardiovascular condition
A,D,
Which of the following are common allergens? A) Tree and grass pollen B) House dust mites C) Peanuts D) Cats and dogs E) Bee and wasp stings
A,B,C,D,E
What are some symptoms of an allergic reaction? A) Runny nose B) Pain around cheeks C) Coughing D) Itchy skin E) Diarrhoea
A,B,C,D,E

When should you call 999 for an allergic reaction? A) Lips, mouth, throat or tongue become swollen B) Breathing very fast or struggling to breathe C) Throat feels tight or struggling to swallow D) Skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale E) Someone faints and cannot be woken up
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you have an adrenaline auto-injector during a serious allergic reaction? A) Use it immediately B) Follow instructions on the injector C) Call 999 for an ambulance D) Check if the person feels better E) Take the person to the hospital
A,B,C,D,E
What are some treatments for allergies? A) Avoiding the allergen B) Antihistamines C) Steroid tablets D) Adrenaline auto-injectors E) Desensitisation (immunotherapy)
A,B,C,D,E
What are some tests for allergies? A) Skin prick test B) Patch test C) Blood tests D) Special diet E) X-ray
A,B,C,D,E

What is an allergy? A) A reaction to something harmless B) A reaction to something dangerous C) A reaction to something unknown D) A reaction to something poisonous E) A reaction to something infectious
A,B,C,D,E
What should you do if you think you or your child may have an allergy? A) See a GP B) Go to the pharmacy C) Go to the dentist D) Call an ambulance E) Wait and see if it goes away
A,B,C,D,E
What is a common symptom of hay fever? A) Runny nose B) Sneezing C) Itchy eyes D) Coughing E) Wheezing
A,B,C,D,E
What is a serious allergic reaction called? A) Anaphylaxis B) Asthma attack C) Heart attack D) Stroke E) Seizure
A,B,C,D,E

What are the first signs of scarlet fever? A: Red eyes and coughing B: High temperature, sore throat, and swollen neck glands C: Skin blisters and vomiting D: Muscle pain and diarrhea E: Headache and dizziness
B
How long after the first symptoms does the rash appear in scarlet fever? A: Within 2 hours B: 12 to 48 hours C: After 1 week D: 2 to 3 days E: Immediately
B
What does the rash of scarlet fever look like? A: Flat and smooth B: Small, raised bumps C: Large, pus-filled blisters D: Dark spots E: Rough, like sandpaper
E
What is the term for the red, swollen tongue with little bumps seen in scarlet fever? A: Raspberry tongue B: Berry tongue C: Strawberry tongue D: Cherry tongue E: Grape tongue
C
On which part of the body does the rash not appear in scarlet fever? A: Chest B: Tummy C: Face D: Arms E: Legs
C
How long does scarlet fever typically last? A: 1 day B: 2 days C: Around 1 week D: 1 month E: 2 weeks
C
How long can you spread scarlet fever if you do not take antibiotics? A: 1 day B: 3 days C: 2 to 3 weeks D: 1 week E: 5 days
C
What is one of the main treatments for scarlet fever? A: Surgery B: Antibiotics C: Steroids D: Chemotherapy E: Radiation therapy
B
What should you do if you have scarlet fever symptoms? A: Go to the emergency room B: See a GP C: Drink plenty of water D: Take over-the-counter cold medicine E: Rest at home
B
What is a common complication of scarlet fever? A: Appendicitis B: Rheumatic fever C: Kidney failure D: Stroke E: Liver disease
B
Which parts of the body are commonly affected by angioedema? A) Lips, tongue, and eyelids B) Arms and legs C) Ears and nose D) Neck and back E) Hands or feet
A, E
What should you do if your lips, mouth, throat, or tongue suddenly become swollen? A) Call a friend B) Drink water C) Call 999 D) Take a nap E) Watch TV
C
What are some treatments for angioedema? A) Antihistamine medicine B) Aspirin C) Steroid tablets D) Ice packs E) Identifying and avoiding the underlying cause
A, E

What is a sign of a serious allergic reaction that may need immediate treatment in hospital? A) Feeling very sleepy B) Having a rash that's swollen, raised or itchy C) Feeling very hungry D) Feeling very cold E) Someone faints and cannot be woken up
B, E

What is hereditary angioedema? A) A type of angioedema caused by an allergic reaction to certain foods B) A rare and potentially life-threatening type of angioedema that's often inherited from your parents C) A non-allergic reaction to a medicine D) A very rare type of angioedema that you can get if you have lymphoma E) Long-term angioedema where the cause is unknown
B

What should you do if part of your body suddenly becomes swollen, such as your hands, feet, or genitals? A) Call a doctor B) Take a painkiller C) Go to the gym D) Drink coffee E) Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111
A, E
What are some antihistamine medicines used to treat angioedema? A) Cetirizine B) Acetaminophen C) Fexofenadine D) Ibuprofen E) Loratadine
A, C
What can happen if the bowel becomes swollen due to angioedema? A) Headache B) Stomach pain C) Earache D) Back pain E) Toothache
B
What is a medical emergency related to angioedema? A) Difficulty sleeping B) Difficulty breathing C) Difficulty walking D) Difficulty seeing E) Difficulty talking
B
What can happen if the throat becomes swollen due to angioedema? A) Breathing difficulties B) Vision loss C) Hearing loss D) Memory loss E) Taste loss
A
What are the main symptoms of norovirus? A) Fever B) Diarrhoea C) Cough D) Nausea E) Sneezing
B,D
How long does it usually take to feel better from norovirus? A) 1 day B) 2 days C) 3 days D) 1 week E) 2 weeks
C,B
What should you do if you have norovirus? A) Stay hydrated B) Take antibiotics C) Visit the hospital D) Eat spicy food E) Exercise heavily
A,D
How is norovirus spread? A) Through the air B) By touching contaminated surfaces C) By eating food prepared by someone infected D) By drinking tap water E) By kissing
B,C
What is the best way to prevent the spread of norovirus? A) Using alcohol hand gel B) Washing hands with soap and water C) Wearing a mask D) Avoiding public places E) Taking vitamins
B,C

When should you stay off school or work if you have norovirus? A) After 1 day without symptoms B) After 2 days without symptoms C) After 3 days without symptoms D) After 4 days without symptoms E) After 7 days without symptoms
A,B
What should you do if your child has signs of dehydration? A) Give them more water B) Call 111 C) Take them to the park D) Give them candy E) Put them to bed
B,C
What should you do if you have bloody diarrhoea? A) Take painkillers B) Call 111 C) Eat spicy food D) Go to bed E) Drink alcohol
B,C
What should you do if you vomit blood? A) Call 999 B) Go to bed C) Take antacids D) Drink milk E) Exercise
A,C

What is considered severe pain? A) Pain that comes and goes B) Pain that makes it hard to think or talk C) Pain that you can manage to get up from D) Pain that is annoying but does not stop daily activities E) Pain that makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
B,E
Which bacteria are responsible for causing botulism? A) Staphylococcus aureus B) Clostridium botulinum C) Escherichia coli D) Streptococcus pneumoniae E) Salmonella
B,E
What are the initial symptoms of botulism? A) Feeling sick B) Vomiting C) Stomach cramps D) Diarrhoea E) Constipation
A,B,C,D
What is the most serious complication of untreated botulism? A) Kidney failure B) Heart attack C) Paralysis spreading to breathing muscles D) Blindness E) Liver failure
C,E
Where are Clostridium botulinum bacteria commonly found? A) In the air B) In soil C) In dust D) In river or sea sediments E) In the human body
B,C,D,E
Which type of botulism is caused by eating contaminated food? A) Food-borne botulism B) Wound botulism C) Infant botulism D) Air-borne botulism E) Water-borne botulism
A,B,C
What is the primary treatment for botulism? A) Surgery B) Neutralising the toxins with antitoxins C) Supporting body functions D) Chemotherapy E) Radiation therapy
B,C,E

How can food-borne botulism be prevented? A) By eating food from bulging cans B) By avoiding foul-smelling preserved foods C) By eating out-of-date foods D) By following food hygiene procedures E) By avoiding foods stored at the incorrect temperature
B,D,E
What should you not give to babies under the age of 1 to prevent infant botulism? A) Milk B) Honey C) Water D) Formula E) Juice
B,E

What is the best way to avoid getting wound botulism? A) By injecting heroin B) By stopping heroin use C) By injecting heroin into the skin or muscles D) By using heroin contaminated with bacteria E) By seeking help for heroin addiction
B,E
What are the symptoms of botulism in affected babies? A) Strong cry B) Weak cry C) Difficulty feeding D) Floppy head, neck and limbs E) Hyperactivity
B,C,D,E
Which of the following are common types of joint pain? A) Knee pain B) Shoulder pain C) Back pain D) Foot pain E) Neck pain
A,B,D,E
What are possible causes of joint pain? A) Sprain or strain B) Osteoarthritis C) Flu D) Bursitis E) Rheumatoid arthritis
A,B,D,E
What should you do to ease joint pain? A) Rest the affected joint B) Use an ice pack C) Take painkillers D) Carry heavy objects E) Stop moving the affected joint
A,B,C

When should you see a GP about joint pain? A) If the pain is getting worse B) If the pain has not improved after 2 weeks C) If your joints are stiff for more than 30 minutes after waking up D) If you have a fever E) If you have a headache
A,B,C
What are symptoms of gout? A) Hot, swollen toe joint B) Very bad pain that comes on suddenly C) Nausea D) Dizziness E) Fatigue
A,B
What should you do if you have joint pain and the skin around it is swollen and feels hot? A) Go to A&E B) Ask for an urgent GP appointment C) Take a hot bath D) Apply a warm compress E) Call 999
B
What are some treatments a GP might prescribe for joint pain? A) Stronger painkillers B) Antibiotics C) Vitamins D) Physiotherapy E) Steroid injections
A,B,D,E
What are symptoms of osteoarthritis? A) Pain worse when walking B) Stiffness after moving C) Itchy skin D) Loss of appetite E) Over the age of 45
A,B,E
What are symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis? A) Pain and stiffness felt in both sides of your body B) Worse after not moving C) Shortness of breath D) Chest pain E) Fever
A,B
What should you do if you have very bad joint pain after a fall or injury? A) Go to A&E B) Call 999 C) Take a nap D) Drink plenty of water E) Apply a warm compress
A,B

What is Patau's syndrome caused by? A: An additional copy of chromosome 12 B: An additional copy of chromosome 13 C: An additional copy of chromosome 14 D: An additional copy of chromosome 15 E: An additional copy of chromosome 16
B
How many pairs of chromosomes does a normal cell contain? A: 21 pairs B: 22 pairs C: 23 pairs D: 24 pairs E: 25 pairs
C
What is the risk of having a baby with Patau's syndrome? A: 1 in 1000 B: 1 in 2000 C: 1 in 3000 D: 1 in 4000 E: 1 in 5000
D
What is the condition where the brain does not divide into two halves? A: Holoprosencephaly B: Hydrocephaly C: Microcephaly D: Anencephaly E: Encephalitis
A
What is the main cause of Patau's syndrome? A: Environmental factors B: Radiation exposure C: Parental behavior D: Random error during conception E: Diet during pregnancy
D
What is the term for an abdominal wall defect where the intestines are outside the body? A: Exomphalos B: Omphalocoele C: Gastroschisis D: Umbilical hernia E: Diastasis recti
A, B
What is the screening test offered at 10 to 14 weeks of pregnancy for Patau's syndrome? A: Blood test B: Ultrasound scan C: Combined test D: Amniocentesis E: Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
C
What is the term for having extra fingers or toes? A: Polydactyly B: Syndactyly C: Brachydactyly D: Clinodactyly E: Ectrodactyly
A

What is the average lifespan of children born with Patau's syndrome? A: Most survive into adulthood B: Most survive for a few years C: More than 9 out of 10 die during the first year D: Most survive for a few months E: Most survive for a few weeks
C
What is the term for a condition where the bottom of the feet are rounded? A: Rocker-bottom feet B: Clubfoot C: Flat feet D: Pes cavus E: Pes planus
A
What is empyema? A) A type of cancer B) Pockets of pus in the body C) A heart condition D) A skin disease E) A viral infection
B)
What is the most common location for empyema? A) Stomach B) Brain C) Pleural space D) Liver E) Kidney
C)
What are the symptoms of empyema? A) Headache B) Fever C) Chest pain D) Weight loss E) Blurred vision
What causes empyema? A) Viral infection B) Bacterial infection C) Genetic disorder D) High blood pressure E) Allergic reaction
B)
What diagnostic tools are used for empyema? A) MRI B) X-ray C) Ultrasound scan D) Blood sample E) Eye exam
What is the most common cause of empyema? A) Bronchiectasis B) Blood clot C) Pneumonia D) Tuberculosis E) Cancer
C)
What treatments are used for empyema? A) Chemotherapy B) Antibiotics C) Chest drain D) Radiation therapy E) Physical therapy
B), C)
What is a chest drain used for in empyema treatment? A) To drain fluid B) To measure blood pressure C) To inject medication D) To monitor heart rate E) To perform surgery
A)
What are the risk factors for developing empyema? A) High cholesterol B) Diabetes C) Weakened immune system D) Acid reflux E) Smoking
What is a stoma in the context of empyema treatment? A) A type of surgery B) An opening in the chest C) A medication D) A diagnostic tool E) A physical therapy technique
B)
Which organs can be involved in a pelvic organ prolapse? A) Womb B) Bowel C) Kidney D) Bladder E) Top of the vagina
A,B,D

What are some symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse? A) Feeling of heaviness around your lower tummy B) Dragging discomfort inside your vagina C) Feeling like there's something coming down into your vagina D) Feeling or seeing a bulge or lump in or coming out of your vagina E) Constant fever
A,B,C

When should you see a GP regarding pelvic organ prolapse? A) If you have any of the symptoms B) If you notice a lump in or around your vagina C) If you have a headache D) If you experience back pain E) If you have difficulty swallowing
A,B

What might a doctor do during an internal pelvic examination? A) Feel for any lumps in your pelvic area B) Gently put a speculum into your vagina C) Ask you to lie on your left-hand side D) Perform a heart ultrasound E) Check your blood pressure
A,B,C
What further tests might a GP refer you to if you have bladder problems? A) Urine test B) Inserting a small tube into your bladder C) Blood test D) Ear examination E) Eye test
A,B
What lifestyle changes can help with pelvic organ prolapse? A) Losing weight B) Avoiding heavy lifting C) Preventing or treating constipation D) Increasing salt intake E) Smoking cessation
A,B,C
What are some treatment options for pelvic organ prolapse? A) Pelvic floor exercises B) Hormone treatment C) Vaginal pessaries D) Surgery E) Acupuncture
A,B,C

What can weaken your pelvic floor and increase the chance of pelvic organ prolapse? A) Pregnancy and childbirth B) Getting older and going through menopause C) Being overweight D) Having a heart condition E) Excessive exercise
A,B,C

What are the main types of prolapse? A) Bladder bulging into the front wall of the vagina B) Womb bulging or hanging down into the vagina C) Top of the vagina sagging down D) Bowel bulging forward into the back wall of the vagina E) Liver bulging into the pelvis
A,B,D
How is pelvic organ prolapse usually classified? A) On a scale of 1 to 4 B) On a scale of A to D C) With colors D) With letters E) With numbers
A,E
What are actinic keratoses? A) Dry, scaly patches of skin B) Wet, smooth patches of skin C) Red, blistering patches of skin D) Small, hard bumps E) Shiny, flat patches of skin
A
What usually causes actinic keratoses? A) Sun damage B) Viral infection C) Chemical exposure D) Genetic factors E) Poor hygiene
A
What is the usual size range of actinic keratoses patches? A) Less than 0.5cm B) 1cm to 2cm C) 3cm to 4cm D) 5cm to 6cm E) More than 7cm
B
What colors can actinic keratoses patches be? A) Blue B) Green C) Pink to red to brown D) Black E) Yellow
C
Where do actinic keratoses patches usually appear? A) Face, hands, and arms B) Back and chest C) Feet and ankles D) Stomach and thighs E) Ears, scalp, and legs
A,E
What should you do if you notice new patches on your skin? A) Ignore them B) See a GP C) Apply moisturizer D) Wait for them to go away E) Cover them with makeup
B
What is one of the treatments for actinic keratoses? A) Hydrating lotions B) Prescription creams and gels C) Antibiotics D) Laser therapy E) Acupuncture
B
What is photodynamic therapy (PDT)? A) A type of massage B) A treatment involving special cream and light C) A dietary supplement D) A surgical procedure E) A type of meditation
B

What should you do to protect your skin if you have actinic keratoses? A) Use sunscreen with SPF 15 B) Wear a hat and clothing that fully covers your arms and legs C) Sunbathe regularly D) Use sunlamps E) Go into the sun between 11am and 3pm
B
What is the recommended SPF for sunscreen if you have actinic keratoses? A) 10 B) 20 C) 30 D) 40 E) 50
C
What is dyspraxia also known as? A) Cerebral palsy B) Developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD) C) Autism spectrum disorder D) Dyslexia E) Stroke
B
Which of the following does dyspraxia NOT affect? A) Intelligence B) Co-ordination skills C) Fine motor skills D) Social situations E) Planning skills
A
Who should you see if you think you have undiagnosed dyspraxia? A) A physiotherapist B) An occupational therapist C) A GP D) A psychologist E) A psychiatrist
C
Which of the following is NOT a symptom of dyspraxia? A) Difficulty with balance B) Poor memory C) Trouble with fine motor skills D) Difficulty with mathematics E) Poor social skills
D
Which therapy can help with managing everyday tasks for someone with dyspraxia? A) Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) B) Occupational therapy C) Physical therapy D) Speech therapy E) Art therapy
B
Which of the following can increase the risk of developing dyspraxia? A) Being born prematurely B) Having a family history of dyspraxia C) Being female D) Having a high IQ E) Being overweight
A,B
What is a recommended way to manage dyspraxia? A) Keeping fit B) Learning to use a computer C) Using a calendar or diary D) Talking positively about challenges E) Joining a support group
A,B,C,D
Which of the following is NOT a condition that may co-occur with dyspraxia? A) ADHD B) Dyscalculia C) Anxiety D) Cerebral palsy E) Dyslexia
D
What is the online forum for adults with dyspraxia called? A) Dyspraxia Support B) Dyspraxic Adults C) Dyspraxia Friends D) Dyspraxia Chat E) Dyspraxia Forum
B
Which of the following is NOT a symptom of dyspraxia? A) Difficulty with writing B) Poor balance C) Difficulty with driving D) Poor memory E) Poor emotional regulation
D

What are the common symptoms of anaphylaxis? A) Swelling of your throat and tongue B) Difficulty breathing or breathing very fast C) Difficulty swallowing, tightness in your throat or a hoarse voice D) Wheezing, coughing or noisy breathing E) Feeling tired or confused
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you suspect someone is having an anaphylactic reaction? A) Use an adrenaline auto-injector B) Call 999 C) Lie down D) Remove the sting if stung by an insect E) Use a 2nd adrenaline auto-injector if symptoms haven't improved after 5 minutes
A,B,C,D,E
What are some common causes of anaphylaxis? A) Foods such as nuts B) Medicines such as antibiotics C) Insect stings such as wasp and bee stings D) Anaesthetics E) Latex
A,B,C,D,E
What are some treatments for anaphylaxis in the hospital? A) Adrenaline given by an injection or drip in your vein B) Oxygen C) Fluids given by a drip in your vein D) Surgery E) Chemotherapy
A,B,C

What should you do to help prevent anaphylaxis? A) Avoid the food, medicine or thing that you're allergic to B) Carry 2 adrenaline auto-injectors with you at all times C) Check your adrenaline auto-injector expiry dates regularly D) Practise how to use your adrenaline auto-injector E) Teach friends, family, colleagues or carers how and when to use your adrenaline auto-injector
A,B,C,D,E

What are the signs that you should call 999 for anaphylaxis? A) Your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen B) You're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe C) Your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow D) Your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale E) You suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
A,B,C,D,E

What are some symptoms that may indicate a serious allergic reaction? A) Swelling of your throat and tongue B) Difficulty breathing or breathing very fast C) Difficulty swallowing, tightness in your throat or a hoarse voice D) Wheezing, coughing or noisy breathing E) Feeling tired or confused
A,B,C,D,E

What should you do if you have been stung by an insect during an anaphylactic reaction? A) Try to remove the sting if it's still in the skin B) Apply ice to the sting C) Take painkillers D) Cover the sting with a bandage E) Lie down and elevate your feet
A,E

What are some things you should do to prepare for an anaphylactic reaction? A) Carry 2 adrenaline auto-injectors with you at all times B) Check your adrenaline auto-injector expiry dates regularly C) Practise how to use your adrenaline auto-injector D) Teach friends, family, colleagues or carers how and when to use your adrenaline auto-injector E) Wear medical alert jewellery
A,B,C,D,E

What are some things you should avoid to prevent anaphylaxis? A) Avoid the food, medicine or thing that you're allergic to B) Do not leave your adrenaline auto-injectors anywhere too hot or cold C) Regularly check food labels D) Inform staff at restaurants and cafes about your allergy E) Use your adrenaline auto-injector if you think you may have anaphylaxis, even if your symptoms are mild
A,B,C,D,E
What is congenital heart disease? A) A disease that affects the kidneys B) A term for a range of birth defects that affect the heart C) A lung disorder D) A skin condition E) A mental health issue
B

What does the term 'congenital' mean? A) It means the condition is present from birth B) It means the condition is acquired later in life C) It means the condition is inherited D) It means the condition is caused by injury E) It means the condition is caused by stress
A
What is one of the most common types of birth defect? A) Cleft lip B) Congenital heart disease C) Club foot D) Down's syndrome E) Cerebral palsy
B

What are some risk factors for congenital heart disease? A) Regular exercise B) Drinking coffee C) The mother having rubella during pregnancy D) The mother taking certain medicines during pregnancy E) The mother having poorly controlled type 1 diabetes
C,D,E
How is congenital heart disease often diagnosed? A) Through a blood test B) Through an ultrasound scan in pregnancy C) Through an X-ray D) Through a dental exam E) Through a hearing test
B

What are some symptoms of congenital heart disease in babies and children? A) Rapid heartbeat B) Swelling of the legs C) Extreme tiredness D) A blue tinge to the skin E) Difficulty breathing when feeding
A,B,C,D,E
What is a common type of congenital heart defect? A) Septal defects B) Coarctation of the aorta C) Pulmonary valve stenosis D) Transposition of the great arteries E) Underdeveloped heart
A,B,C,D,E

What is the treatment for mild congenital heart defects? A) They often don't need to be treated B) They always require surgery C) They are treated with antibiotics D) They are treated with radiation therapy E) They are treated with chemotherapy
A

What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS)? A) A service that provides treatment for congenital heart disease B) A service that helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat congenital heart disease C) A service that provides financial aid to families D) A service that offers counseling E) A service that provides free medical check-ups
B
What are the four main sections of the heart called? A) Left atrium B) Left ventricle C) Right atrium D) Right ventricle E) Left auricle
A,B,C,D
Which of the following are symptoms of asbestosis? A: Shortness of breath B: Persistent cough C: Chest pain D: Dizziness E: Clubbed fingertips
A,B,E
How many years can it take for symptoms of asbestosis to appear after exposure to asbestos? A: 10-15 years B: 20-30 years C: 5-10 years D: 30-40 years E: 40-50 years
B,D
Which jobs may have exposed you to asbestos? A: Office worker B: Heating and ventilation engineer C: Plumber D: Electrician E: Gardener
B,C,D
What tests might a GP refer you for if they suspect asbestosis? A: Blood test B: Chest X-ray C: Lung function tests D: Urine test E: CT scan of the lungs
B,C,E
Which treatments can help manage symptoms of asbestosis? A: Pulmonary rehabilitation B: Oxygen therapy C: Surgery D: Using an inhaler E: Chemotherapy
A,B,D

What can you do to ease symptoms and lower chances of infections if you have asbestosis? A: Quit smoking B: Get the flu vaccination C: Avoid sunlight D: Get the pneumococcal vaccination E: Eat more sugar
A,B,D
Which of the following are not symptoms of asbestosis? A: Dizziness B: Wheezing C: Chest pain D: Fever E: Extreme tiredness
A,D
Asbestosis is caused by exposure to what material? A: Silica B: Asbestos C: Coal dust D: Wood dust E: Plastic
B
What should you do if you suspect you have asbestosis? A: See a GP B: Wait for symptoms to worsen C: Self-medicate D: Contact a lawyer E: Avoid medical care
A,D
Which of the following are advanced symptoms of asbestosis? A: Clubbed fingertips B: Mild cough C: Persistent cough D: Dizziness E: Extreme tiredness
A,E
Which of the following symptoms are typical of costochondritis? A: Sharp chest pain B: Itchy skin C: Headache D: Tingling sensation E: Pain when moving your upper body
A,E,
What actions may worsen the pain from costochondritis? A: Drinking water B: Lying down C: Breathing deeply D: Eating spicy food E: Pressing the middle of your chest
B,C,
What should you do if you think you have costochondritis? A: Ignore it B: Call 999 C: Get help from NHS 111 D: Drink more water E: Take a nap
C,E,
Which of the following are treatments for costochondritis? A: Steroid injection B: Antibiotics C: Local anaesthetic D: Ice cream E: Ibuprofen
A,E,
How long can costochondritis last? A: A few hours B: A few weeks C: Several months D: A few seconds E: A lifetime
B,C,
What should you do if you have sudden chest pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck, or jaw? A: Take a painkiller B: Call 999 C: Drink tea D: Go for a walk E: Sleep it off
B,E,
Which of the following can cause costochondritis? A: An injury to your chest B: Eating too much candy C: Watching TV D: Coughing a lot E: Texting too much
A,D,
What other conditions can sometimes cause costochondritis? A: Fibromyalgia B: Acne C: Common cold D: Rheumatoid arthritis E: Sunburn
A,D,
What should you do if you have very bad pain from costochondritis that does not get better over time? A: Ignore it B: Call 999 C: Get a steroid injection D: Eat more vegetables E: Take a hot bath
C,E,
Which of the following actions can worsen the pain from costochondritis? A: Moving your upper body B: Watching a movie C: Breathing deeply D: Reading a book E: Lying down
A,E,
What does hypnotherapy aim to do? A: Cure physical ailments B: Treat conditions or change habits C: Predict the future D: Improve physical strength E: Enhance memory
B
What is the first step in a hypnotherapy session? A: Immediate hypnosis B: Discussion with the therapist to agree on methods C: Physical examination D: Meditation E: Exercise routine
B
What state does a hypnotherapist lead you into? A: Deep sleep B: Deeply relaxed state C: Hyperactive state D: State of confusion E: State of extreme focus
B

What should you do first if you have a personality disorder and want to try hypnotherapy? A: Consult a nutritionist B: Check with a GP C: Start exercising D: Stop all medications E: Watch educational videos
B
Is hypnotherapy usually available on the NHS? A: Yes B: No C: Only for children D: Only for the elderly E: Only for emergency cases
B
Who can you ask about getting hypnotherapy on the NHS? A: A pharmacist B: A GP C: A dentist D: A teacher E: A lawyer
B

What is the legal requirement for hypnotherapists in the UK? A: Specific training required B: No specific training required by law C: Must have a medical degree D: Must be a licensed psychologist E: Must complete a PhD
B

What should you do when looking for a private hypnotherapist? A: Choose someone with a healthcare background B: Choose the cheapest option C: Choose someone with no training D: Choose someone who is not registered E: Choose someone who promises instant results
A

What should you ensure if you have mental ill health or a serious illness? A: The therapist is trained in working with your condition B: The therapist is untrained C: The therapist is a friend D: The therapist is a family member E: The therapist is a celebrity
A

What should you do if you're looking for a therapist for your child? A: Make sure they're trained to work with children B: Choose someone who is not trained C: Choose someone based on cost D: Choose someone who is not registered E: Choose someone who promises instant results
A

What is stammering characterized by? A) Repeating sounds or syllables B) Making sounds longer C) A word getting stuck or not coming out at all D) Speaking very fast E) Difficulty pronouncing certain letters
A,B,C
Which type of stammering is most common in early childhood? A) Developmental stammering B) Acquired stammering C) Late-onset stammering D) Psychological stammering E) Genetic stammering
A
What can cause acquired or late-onset stammering? A) Head injury B) Stroke C) Progressive neurological condition D) Certain drugs or medicines E) Dietary changes
A,B,C,D

Why is it important to get advice early for stammering in pre-school age children? A) Treatment is often successful B) It helps the child develop social skills C) It prevents the child from learning new words D) It ensures the child will never stammer again E) It is required by law
A
What factors may play a part in causing stammering? A) Developmental factors B) Inherited factors C) Parental behavior D) Environmental pollution E) Small differences in brain efficiency
A,B,E

What can help a child who stammers to speak more easily? A) Creating a relaxed environment B) Strategies to increase fluency C) Working on feelings associated with stammering D) Using electronic devices E) Taking vitamin supplements
A,B,C,D
What is the estimated prevalence of stammering in adults? A) 1 in 10 B) 1 in 20 C) 1 in 50 D) 1 in 100 E) 1 in 200
C
Which of the following is a characteristic of stammering? A) Saying 'mu-mu-mu-mummy' B) Making 'mmmmmmummy' sounds C) A word getting stuck D) Speaking very loudly E) Not being able to read
A,B,C

What should you do if you have concerns about your child's speech or language development? A) Talk to a GP or health visitor B) Ignore it as it will go away on its own C) Give the child more screen time D) Consult a dietician E) Refer the child to a speech and language therapist (SLT)
A,E

What is the role of genes in stammering? A) Genes have no role B) Genes are thought to have a role C) Genes cause stammering in all cases D) Genes can be altered to cure stammering E) Genes are only relevant in adults
B

What are some things you should do at home to help with bedwetting? A) Wake your child regularly at night B) Give your child caffeinated drinks C) Use waterproof covers on the mattress D) Make sure your child goes to the toilet 4-7 times a day E) Punish your child
C,D,

What are some things you should not do to help with bedwetting? A) Give your child enough water B) Punish your child C) Regularly wake your child at night D) Use bedwetting alarms E) Make sure your child has easy access to a toilet
B,C,

What are some important things to know about bedwetting in young children? A) It is abnormal B) It is common C) It can take some time for a child to stay dry D) It can be caused by diabetes E) Many children under the age of 5 wet the bed
B,C,E

When should you see a GP regarding bedwetting? A) If your child has never wet the bed B) If your child has started wetting the bed after being dry for 6 months C) If you've tried home remedies and your child keeps wetting the bed D) If your child wets the bed every night E) If your child is under 5
B,C,
What are some treatments a GP might suggest for bedwetting? A) Avoiding caffeine B) Bedwetting alarm C) Medicine to reduce nighttime urine D) Punishing the child E) Regularly waking the child
B,C,

What are some possible causes of bedwetting in children? A) Not feeling the need to pee while sleeping B) Making too much pee at night C) Stress at home or school D) Drinking too much water E) Lack of sleep
A,B,C

What should you do if treatments from a GP do not work? A) Punish the child B) Continue waking the child regularly C) Refer the child to a specialist D) Stop giving the child water E) Use stronger punishment
C,

What is an important advice for parents of children who wet the bed? A) Make sure the child is punished B) Ensure the child has easy access to a toilet C) Avoid giving the child caffeinated drinks D) Regularly wake the child E) Use bedwetting alarms
B,C,

What are some things that are not recommended for treating bedwetting? A) Using waterproof covers B) Punishing the child C) Regularly waking the child D) Giving the child caffeinated drinks E) Making sure the child goes to the toilet before bed
B,C,D
What are some resources for more information on bedwetting? A) NHS website B) Bladder and Bowel UK C) ERIC, the Children's Bowel & Bladder Charity D) Local pharmacy E) Punishment guides
B,C,
Which of the following are symptoms of gastritis? A) Tummy pain B) Dizziness C) Indigestion D) Feeling full and bloated E) Severe headache
A,C,D
What should you do if you're vomiting bright red blood or your vomit looks like ground coffee? A) Call 999 B) Go to A&E C) Take a painkiller D) Drink water E) Wait and see
A,B
What are some causes of gastritis? A) Infection with H. pylori B) Drinking too much alcohol C) Taking anti-inflammatory painkillers D) Eating spicy food E) Lack of exercise
A,B,C
Which tests might a doctor arrange to diagnose gastritis? A) Breath test B) Blood test C) X-ray D) MRI E) Poo sample test
A,B,E
What are some treatments for gastritis? A) Antibiotics B) Surgery C) Antacids D) Stopping anti-inflammatory painkillers E) Sleeping pills
A,C,D
What should you do if gastritis is causing mild indigestion symptoms? A) Reduce caffeine intake B) Lie on an extra pillow in bed C) Eat spicy food D) Drink alcohol E) Smoke
A,B
What should you do if you have tummy pain or indigestion for longer than 1 week? A) See a GP B) Take more painkillers C) Ignore it D) Drink more alcohol E) Go to sleep
A
Which doctor might you be referred to if gastritis is not getting better? A) Dentist B) Gastroenterologist C) Cardiologist D) Dermatologist E) Psychologist
B
What should you not do if you have gastritis? A) Eat 3 to 4 hours before going to bed B) Have acidic food or drink C) Drink alcohol D) Smoke E) Exercise
A,B,C,D
Which medicines can a pharmacist recommend for mild indigestion? A) Antacids B) Sleeping pills C) Proton pump inhibitors D) Antidepressants E) Alginates
A,C,E
Which of the following are symptoms of prostatitis? A) Pain when peeing B) Pain in your scrotum C) High temperature D) Blue skin E) Nausea
A,B,C

When should you see a GP regarding prostatitis? A) If you have symptoms of prostatitis B) If you cannot pee C) If you have blue lips D) If you are feeling anxious E) If you have a rash that does not fade
A,B,E
What immediate action should be taken if you have severe difficulty breathing? A) Go to A&E B) Call 999 C) Take paracetamol D) Drink plenty of fluids E) Consult a specialist
A,B,E
What are the treatments for prostatitis? A) Antibiotics B) Cognitive behavioural therapy C) Physiotherapy D) Surgery E) Drinking coffee
A,B,C

What should you do if you have been taking antibiotics for prostatitis for 48 hours but your symptoms have not improved? A) Ask for an urgent GP appointment B) Go to A&E C) Stop taking antibiotics D) Drink more water E) Consult NHS 111
A,B,E
Which of the following are causes of prostatitis? A) Urinary tract infection B) Inflammation C) Anxiety D) Allergies E) Low testosterone
A,B,C
What should you do to help with prostatitis symptoms? A) Drink plenty of fluids B) Take paracetamol or ibuprofen C) Finish the whole course of antibiotics D) Avoid exercise E) Eat spicy food
A,B,C
What are the treatments for chronic prostatitis? A) Antibiotics B) Acupuncture C) Counselling D) Surgery E) Chemotherapy
A,B,C
What symptoms may indicate sepsis in prostatitis? A) Confusion B) Slurred speech C) Pale skin D) Rash that does not fade E) Itchy skin
A,B,D
What should you do if you suddenly feel confused and have slurred speech? A) Go to A&E B) Call 999 C) Take a nap D) Drink more water E) Consult a specialist
A,B,E
What are the symptoms of food poisoning? A) Feeling sick (nausea) B) Dizziness C) Stomach cramps D) Severe headache E) Diarrhoea
A,E
How long does it take for symptoms of food poisoning to start? A) A few hours B) A few days C) A few weeks D) Immediately E) A few months
A,B
What is the most important thing to do when treating food poisoning yourself? A) Eat lots of solid food B) Drink lots of fluids C) Take antibiotics D) Exercise regularly E) Sleep for long hours
B,C

How long should you stay off school or work after having diarrhoea or vomiting due to food poisoning? A) Until you feel better B) At least 2 days after symptoms stop C) 1 day after symptoms stop D) Immediately after symptoms stop E) 3 days after symptoms stop
B,D

What can cause food to be contaminated with germs leading to food poisoning? A) Not cooked thoroughly B) Not frozen or chilled correctly C) Left out for too long D) Handled by someone who is ill E) Only eating red meat
A,B
Which types of bacteria commonly cause food poisoning? A) Campylobacter B) Streptococcus C) Salmonella D) E. coli E) Influenza
A,C
What is one of the most common causes of food poisoning in the UK? A) Salmonella B) Campylobacter C) Influenza D) Streptococcus E) Norovirus
A,B
What are some ways to avoid food poisoning? A) Always wash your hands B) Cook food thoroughly C) Store food properly D) Avoid eating after 'use by' date E) Eat only organic food
B,D
What should you do if you suspect you have food poisoning? A) Go to the hospital immediately B) Drink lots of fluids C) Take over-the-counter medication D) Rest E) Avoid all food
B,D
What are some common symptoms of food poisoning? A) Muscle pain B) Nausea C) High temperature D) Skin rash E) Diarrhoea
B,E
What are the symptoms of compartment syndrome? A) Burning pain or deep ache B) Nausea C) Swelling or bulging of the muscle D) Fever E) Numbness, weakness or pins and needles
A,C,E
What are the types of compartment syndrome? A) Chronic compartment syndrome B) Acute compartment syndrome C) Subacute compartment syndrome D) Mild compartment syndrome E) Severe compartment syndrome
A,B,E

What should you do if you suspect sudden, severe pain is caused by compartment syndrome? A) Call 999 or go to A&E B) Apply ice to the affected area C) Take mild painkillers D) Rest and elevate the affected area E) See a GP
A,B,E
What are the tests that may be done to diagnose compartment syndrome? A) Blood test B) X-ray C) MRI scans D) Compartment pressure measurement E) Ultrasound
B,C,D
What is the treatment for sudden (acute) compartment syndrome? A) Physiotherapy B) Fasciotomy C) Anti-inflammatory painkillers D) Skin graft E) Rest
B,D,E

What are the ways to relieve symptoms of chronic compartment syndrome? A) Avoid the activity that caused them B) Use anti-inflammatory painkillers C) Have physiotherapy D) Surgery E) Use inserts (orthotics) in your shoes
A,B,E

What are the signs of severe pain according to the NHS? A) Pain that comes and goes B) Pain that is always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk C) Pain that makes it very hard to move D) Pain that is annoying but does not stop you doing daily activities E) Pain that you cannot sleep
B,C,E
What should you do if you have symptoms of compartment syndrome when exercising? A) Call an ambulance B) See a GP C) Apply a tight bandage D) Take a hot shower E) Stop exercising and rest
B,D,E
What are the complications of not treating acute compartment syndrome? A) Skin graft B) Physiotherapy C) Permanent muscle damage D) Fever E) Nausea
A,B,C
What are the non-urgent actions to take if you suspect compartment syndrome? A) Call 999 B) See a GP C) Apply ice to the affected area D) Take mild painkillers E) Rest and elevate the affected area
B,D,E

What are the signs that you might have threadworms? A) Small, white worms in your poo B) Extreme itching around your anus C) A red, itchy worm-shaped rash on your skin D) Loss of weight E) A large worm in your poo
A,B
Where are threadworms commonly caught? A) UK B) Asia C) Africa D) South America E) Australia
A
Which of the following worms can cause a red, itchy worm-shaped rash? A) Threadworms B) Roundworms C) Hookworms D) Tapeworms E) Pinworms
C
Which professional should you see if you have a red, itchy worm-shaped rash? A) Pharmacist B) GP C) Nurse D) Dentist E) Optician
B

C
How long should you take medicine prescribed for worm infections? A) 1 to 3 days B) 1 week C) 2 weeks D) 1 month E) 3 months
A

How can you catch worms? A) Touching objects with worm eggs B) Eating raw fruit and vegetables C) Walking barefoot on soil with worms D) Touching soil with worm eggs E) Eating undercooked beef, pork or freshwater fish
A,C,E

What should you do to prevent worm infections? A) Wash your hands regularly B) Drink bottled or boiled water in high-risk areas C) Thoroughly wash garden-grown fruit and vegetables D) Deworm pet dogs and cats regularly E) Dispose of dog and cat poo in a bin

What should you do if your symptoms do not get better in 2 weeks after treatment for worms? A) Ignore it B) Visit a pharmacist C) Go back to the GP D) Stop taking medicine E) Eat more vegetables
C
Which worms look like tiny pieces of white cotton? A) Threadworms B) Roundworms C) Hookworms D) Tapeworms E) Pinworms

Which of the following are causes of alcohol-related liver disease? A) Regularly drinking too much alcohol B) Eating too much sugar C) Being very overweight D) Not exercising enough E) Viral infection
A,C,
What are the common symptoms of cirrhosis? A) Feeling very tired and weak all the time B) Loss of appetite C) Yellow skin and whites of the eyes D) Frequent headaches E) Itchy skin
A,B,E,

A,B,
What are the main causes of liver disease? A) Obesity B) Undiagnosed hepatitis infection C) Alcohol misuse D) Smoking E) Lack of sleep
A,B,C,
Which types of hepatitis have vaccines available? A) Hepatitis A B) Hepatitis B C) Hepatitis C D) Hepatitis D E) Hepatitis E
A,B,
What lifestyle changes can help prevent liver disease? A) Maintaining a healthy weight B) Drinking plenty of water C) Not drinking too much alcohol D) Avoiding caffeine E) Regular exercise
A,C,E,
What are the possible causes of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease? A) Being very overweight B) Regularly drinking too much alcohol C) Viral infection D) Genetic factors E) Smoking
A,D,
What are the possible causes of hepatitis? A) Catching a viral infection B) Regularly drinking too much alcohol C) Being very overweight D) Genetic factors E) Smoking
A,B,

Which condition may be caused by a problem with the immune system? A) Alcohol-related liver disease B) Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease C) Primary biliary cholangitis D) Haemochromatosis E) Hepatitis
C,D,
What are the possible causes of haemochromatosis? A) A gene that runs in families B) Viral infection C) Being very overweight D) Alcohol consumption E) Smoking
A,D,
Which of the following are colors that bedbugs can be? A) Dark yellow B) Red C) Green D) Brown E) White
A,B,D
What are the typical sizes of adult bedbugs? A) 1mm B) 5mm C) 10mm D) 20mm E) 50mm
B,D,E
Where do bedbugs often hide? A) On bed frames B) Under loose wallpaper C) Behind pictures D) In the garden E) In the kitchen
A,B,C
What are the signs of bedbugs? A) Bites B) Spots of blood on bedding C) Small brown spots on bedding D) Sweet smell E) Loud buzzing
A,B,C
How can bedbug bites appear on the skin? A) Raised and itchy B) Often in a line or grouped together C) Purple on black or brown skin D) Blue spots E) Yellow dots
A,B,C
What are the possible reactions to bedbug bites? A) Itchy B) Painful swelling C) Severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) D) Nausea E) Fever
A,B,C
How long do bedbug bites usually take to clear up? A) A few hours B) A week or so C) A month D) Several months E) A year
B,C,D
What can you do to treat bedbug bites? A) Put something cool on the affected area B) Keep the affected area clean C) Scratch the bites D) Use hydrocortisone cream E) Take antibiotics
A,B,D
What can a pharmacist help with for bedbug bites? A) Mild steroid cream B) Antihistamines C) Antibiotics D) Vaccines E) Surgery
A,B,C

What should you do if you think you have bedbugs? A) Contact your local council B) Wash affected bedding on a hot wash C) Keep clutter around your bed D) Bring secondhand furniture indoors without checking E) Regularly clean and vacuum
A,B,E
What are the symptoms of DVT (deep vein thrombosis) in the leg? A) Throbbing pain in 1 leg B) Swollen veins that are hard or sore C) Numbness in the leg D) Sharp pain in the toes E) Fever
A,B

When should you seek immediate medical attention for DVT? A) If you have breathlessness and chest pain B) If you have a headache C) If you have a fever D) If you have a sore throat E) If you have joint pain
A,D
Who is more likely to get DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) People over 60 B) People who are overweight C) People who are active D) People who have had DVT before E) People who drink lots of water
A,B
What are the main treatments for DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Blood-thinning medicines B) Surgery to remove blood clots C) Physical therapy D) High-dose vitamins E) Psychotherapy

What should you do to help recover from DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Walk regularly B) Keep your affected leg raised when sitting C) Avoid exercise D) Eat high-fat foods E) Take frequent naps
A,B
What can you do to lower your chance of getting DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Stay a healthy weight B) Drink plenty of fluids C) Sit still for long periods D) Cross your legs while sitting E) Smoke
A,B
What should you do during a long journey to lower your chances of getting DVT? A) Wear loose clothing B) Drink plenty of water C) Avoid alcohol D) Stay seated the entire time E) Eat high-sugar foods
A,B

What might happen if you have DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Blood clots can travel to your lungs B) Blood clots can travel to your brain C) You may experience a migraine D) You may have a skin rash E) You may have a pulmonary embolism
A,E
What is a common site for DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Thigh B) Calf C) Hand D) Neck E) Back
A,B

What might a doctor do if they think you have DVT (deep vein thrombosis)? A) Refer you to hospital for an ultrasound scan B) Give you an injection of a blood-thinning medicine C) Prescribe antibiotics D) Advise you to rest E) Perform a heart MRI
A,B
What does CPR stand for? A) Cardiac Prolonging Resuscitation B) Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation C) Cardiorespiratory Prolongation D) Cardiac Pulmonary Redaction E) Cardiopulmonary Reanimation
B,E
Which of the following are methods used in CPR? A) Chest compressions B) Electrical shocks C) Artificial ventilation D) Intravenous fluids E) Defibrillation
A,E
What are the chances of CPR restarting the heart and/or breathing? A) 1 in 10 B) 1 in 5 C) 1 in 20 D) 1 in 100 E) Between 1 and 2 in 10
A,E
What factors increase the chances of CPR being successful? A) Healthy organs B) Proximity to trained personnel C) Availability of defibrillators D) Previous organ damage E) Severe illness
A,B

What does DNACPR stand for? A) Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation B) Do Not Administer Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation C) Do Not Attempt Cardiac Resuscitation D) Do Not Attempt Resuscitation E) Do Not Administer Resuscitation
A,D
Who can make a DNACPR decision? A) The patient B) The doctor C) The healthcare team D) A family member E) A friend
A,B
Where is a DNACPR form kept? A) In the patient's medical records B) With the patient at home C) In a care home D) In the hospital E) With the doctor
A,B

What is an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT)? A) A document that explains when you want to refuse CPR B) A document that explains when you want to refuse all treatments C) A legal document to refuse CPR D) A medical record of past treatments E) A document that explains when you want to receive CPR
A,C

What happens if a patient lacks capacity to make a DNACPR decision? A) Doctors check for an ADRT B) Doctors check for an LPA C) A best interest's decision is made by the senior doctor D) The patient's family decides E) The patient's friends decide
A,B
How long can a DNACPR form last? A) For a short period B) With no end date C) Only being reviewed if the situation changes D) Until the patient recovers E) For a fixed period of time
A,B
What is the primary cause of tetanus? A) Virus B) Bacteria C) Fungus D) Parasite E) Allergy
B)
What is the main way tetanus bacteria can get into your body? A) Through the air B) Through a wound C) Through food D) Through water E) Through skin contact
B)
How soon after infection do symptoms of tetanus usually start? A) Within 1 day B) 4 to 21 days C) After 1 month D) Within 2 hours E) After 1 year
B)
Which symptom is a classic sign of tetanus? A) Dizziness B) Lockjaw C) Fatigue D) Sneezing E) Rash
B)

What should you do if you have a wound and are not sure if you’ve been fully vaccinated against tetanus? A) Ignore it B) Clean it with water C) Ask for an urgent GP appointment D) Take antibiotics E) Wait for it to heal
C)
What immediate action should be taken if you have a large or deep wound and are experiencing muscle spasms? A) Call 999 or go to A&E B) Apply ice C) Take painkillers D) Sleep it off E) Call a friend
A)
What is the primary treatment for tetanus in a hospital setting? A) Surgery B) Cleaning the wound C) Physical therapy D) Blood transfusion E) Acupuncture
B)
How many doses of the tetanus vaccine are required for full vaccination? A) 2 doses B) 3 doses C) 4 doses D) 5 doses E) 6 doses
D)
When is the first tetanus vaccine typically given in the NHS vaccination schedule? A) At birth B) At 8 weeks C) At 1 year D) At 2 years E) At 5 years
B)

What action should be taken before traveling to ensure protection against tetanus? A) Avoid traveling B) Take travel insurance C) Get a tetanus vaccination if not fully vaccinated D) Drink plenty of water E) Carry a first aid kit
C)

What is the medical term for the time leading up to menopause when symptoms are experienced but periods have not stopped? A) Menopause B) Postmenopause C) Perimenopause D) Pre-menopause E) Hormonal pause
C,D
What are the typical symptoms of menopause and perimenopause? A) Headaches B) Mood swings C) Brain fog D) Hot flushes E) Toothaches
B,D
Which surgical procedures can cause menopause? A) Appendectomy B) Oophorectomy C) Hysterectomy D) Tonsillectomy E) Cholecystectomy
B,C
What is the usual age range for natural menopause? A) 30-40 B) 45-55 C) 60-70 D) 75-85 E) 55-65
B,E
How long after the last period must a woman go without menstruation to be considered in menopause? A) 6 months B) 12 months C) 18 months D) 24 months E) 36 months
B,C
Which treatments can cause menopause? A) Antibiotics B) Chemotherapy C) Radiation therapy D) Painkillers E) Vaccinations
B,C
Menopause can impact which aspects of a woman's life? A) Relationships B) Work C) Travel D) Hobbies E) Diet
A,B
Which of the following can replace missing hormones and help relieve menopause symptoms? A) Vitamins B) Hormone replacement therapy C) Herbal remedies D) Exercise E) Acupuncture
B,C
What is the term for the removal of the ovaries? A) Hysterectomy B) Oophorectomy C) Nephrectomy D) Thyroidectomy E) Appendectomy
B,C
When do menopause symptoms typically begin? A) Immediately after periods stop B) Years before periods stop C) Only after periods stop D) Only during perimenopause E) After a hysterectomy
B,D
What are the common reasons for needing intensive care? A: A road accident B: A serious head injury C: A severe fall D: A common cold E: Severe burns
A, B, E
What type of equipment may be used in an ICU? A: A ventilator B: A trampoline C: Monitoring equipment D: A treadmill E: IV lines and pumps
A, C, E
What are some of the lingering problems after intensive care? A: Extreme tiredness (fatigue) B: Improved appetite C: Depression D: Increased energy E: Sleep problems
A, C, E
What are the different names for intensive care units? A: ICUs B: CCUs C: ITUs D: HCUs E: SCUs
A, B, C
What are some common serious short-term conditions that may require intensive care? A: A heart attack B: A migraine C: A stroke D: A common cold E: Sepsis
A, C, E
What are some of the things that may be restricted when visiting an ICU? A: Flowers B: Books C: Fruits D: Touching the patient E: Bringing in certain things
A, B, E
What types of tubes might be used in an ICU? A: Drains B: Catheters C: Feeding tubes D: IV lines E: Tracheostomy tubes
A, B, D
What are some mental health issues that might arise after intensive care? A: Happiness B: Anxiety C: PTSD D: Confidence E: Depression
B, C, E

What are some of the things that can be done to make a patient in an ICU more comfortable? A: Bring in flowers B: Talk to the patient C: Avoid visiting if ill D: Read to the patient E: Provide familiar voices
B, D, E
What are some of the websites that provide information about intensive care? A: ICU steps website B: HealthUnlocked website C: Intensive Care Society website D: Healthtalk website E: ICU forum
A, B, C
Where is rabies commonly found? A) Europe B) Africa C) Australia D) Asia E) North America
Africa,Asia,
Which of the following can transmit rabies? A) Mosquitoes B) Dogs C) Snakes D) Bats E) Fish
Dogs,Bats,
What should you do if you're bitten by an animal abroad? A) Ignore it B) Wait until you get back home C) Get medical help immediately D) Apply ice E) Take painkillers
Get medical help immediately,
What should you do to reduce the risk of rabies while traveling? A) Pet stray animals B) Get vaccinated C) Avoid medical help D) Wash bites with soap and water E) Feed wild animals
Get vaccinated,Wash bites with soap and water,
Which parts of the world have a higher risk of rabies? A) North America B) Central and South America C) Europe D) Australia E) Asia
Central and South America,Asia,
What is the recommended action if you're bitten by a bat in the UK? A) Ignore it B) Wait for symptoms C) Get medical help immediately D) Apply ice E) Take painkillers
Get medical help immediately,
What are the symptoms of rabies? A) Fever B) Hallucinations C) Paralysis D) Sneezing E) Headache
Hallucinations,Paralysis,
How can rabies be transmitted? A) Through coughing B) Through a scratch C) Through a bite D) Through a lick on eyes, nose or mouth E) Through sharing utensils
Through a scratch,Through a bite,Through a lick on eyes, nose or mouth,
What should you do if you're traveling to a part of the world where rabies is common? A) Avoid vaccination B) Seek travel health advice C) Get vaccinated D) Ignore animal bites E) Avoid medical help
Seek travel health advice,Get vaccinated,

What should you do if you have been bitten or scratched by an animal that may have rabies? A) Ignore it B) Apply a bandage C) Seek medical help immediately D) Take herbal remedies E) Wait for symptoms
Seek medical help immediately,

What is Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS)? A: A condition that affects the signals sent from the nerves to the muscles. B: A condition that affects the heart. C: A condition that affects the kidneys. D: A condition that affects the digestive system. E: A condition that affects the bones.
A
What are the main symptoms of LEMS? A: Weakness in the legs, arms, neck, and face. B: High fever and chills. C: Chest pain and shortness of breath. D: Headaches and seizures. E: Nausea and vomiting.
A
What causes LEMS? A: The immune system mistakenly attacking and damaging the nerves. B: Bacterial infection. C: Viral infection. D: Genetic mutation. E: Nutrient deficiency.
A
Which tests can be used to diagnose LEMS? A: Blood tests, nerve studies, and scans. B: X-rays and ultrasounds. C: MRI and PET scans only. D: Skin biopsy and blood tests. E: Urine tests and ECG.
A
What is the main treatment for LEMS? A: Medicine to help nerve signals reach the muscles. B: Surgery to remove affected nerves. C: Physical therapy only. D: Chemotherapy. E: Radiation therapy.
A

What is the outlook for people with LEMS not associated with cancer? A: It does not affect life expectancy. B: It significantly shortens life expectancy. C: It causes severe disability. D: It requires long-term hospitalization. E: It is always fatal.
A

Which medicine is commonly used to help nerve signals reach the muscles in LEMS? A: 3,4-diaminopyridine and pyridostigmine. B: Aspirin and ibuprofen. C: Antibiotics. D: Antihistamines. E: Antidepressants.
A

What is plasmapheresis used for in the treatment of LEMS? A: A procedure to filter out the antibodies attacking your nerves. B: A procedure to increase blood flow. C: A procedure to remove toxins. D: A procedure to boost the immune system. E: A procedure to reduce inflammation.
A

What is immunoglobulin therapy used for in the treatment of LEMS? A: Injections of antibodies from donated blood to temporarily stop your immune system attacking your nerves. B: Injections to boost the immune system. C: Injections to reduce pain. D: Injections to improve mobility. E: Injections to prevent infections.
A

What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) related to LEMS? A: It helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. B: It provides financial support for patients. C: It offers counseling services. D: It supplies medication. E: It conducts clinical trials.
A
